samples.prompt: A supervillain who desires world domination encounters a supervillain who desires world destruction. Neither of them will bend to the other.
samples.output:
In a world teetering on the edge of chaos, where governments trembled at the mention of their names, two figures emerged from the shadows—each a legend in their own right, each feared by billions. Dr. Victor Malifax, the calculated genius with a mind as sharp as a guillotine, sought nothing less than total world domination. Not out of malice, but because he believed only under his rule could humanity achieve true order. Standing in stark opposition was Nihilix, a being of raw, apocalyptic power whose only desire was to see the world burn, not out of hatred, but because he believed the universe would be better off without the stain of humanity.

Their first encounter took place in the ruins of Moscow, after a massive EMP wave—Malifax’s doing—had shut down the city’s defenses, allowing him to install one of his global command nodes. As his mechanized forces secured the perimeter, the sky split apart with crimson lightning. From the heavens descended Nihilix, wreathed in swirling void energy, his eyes like dying stars.

Malifax, standing atop a makeshift dais cobbled together from broken architecture, regarded the intruder with the cold precision of a machine. “You’re interfering with progress,” he said, brushing dust from his immaculate coat. “I’ve calculated optimal sociopolitical restructuring models. This city is the first step.”

Nihilix laughed—an eerie, hollow sound that echoed like screams through a vacuum. “Progress?” he spat. “You wish to place a collar on a rabid beast and call it peace. I seek to end the beast.”

Malifax’s eyes narrowed. “Without civilization, there is nothing. No art, no science, no reason. Only entropy.”

“Exactly,” Nihilix replied, descending to the ground with a blast of heat that melted the pavement beneath him. “Entropy is truth. Your order is an illusion. A cage. I offer freedom through oblivion.”

Their ideologies, diametrically opposed, clashed like titanic forces of nature. Malifax, with his vast intellect and technology, had already seized control of communication satellites, crippled world currencies, and turned rogue nations into client states. He was inches away from uniting Earth beneath his iron hand. Nihilix, on the other hand, was a force of nature—cosmic, ancient, and seemingly unstoppable. Wherever he walked, tectonic plates shifted, seas boiled, and stars dimmed. The world knew him as the Endbringer.

The two supervillains fought not just with weapons, but with ideals. Malifax deployed synthetic armies, drones, and AI-directed missiles in an attempt to contain Nihilix. In turn, Nihilix unleashed storms of antimatter, black-hole singularities, and planet-scarring cataclysms. Their battles raged across continents, leveling cities and reshaping geography. But neither could gain the upper hand.

What made matters worse was their mutual refusal to compromise. Malifax could not allow Nihilix to destroy the world—it was the very thing he sought to rule. Nihilix could not tolerate a world preserved and suppressed under Malifax’s regime—it was the very thing he sought to annihilate. Their goals were irreconcilable, and cooperation was impossible.

The world’s remaining heroes, scattered and diminished, watched helplessly from the sidelines, unable to stop either of these titans. They debated whether to support one villain to stop the other. But the choice between tyranny and annihilation was a bitter one.

In a secret bunker beneath the Andes, Malifax convened with his most advanced AI, Sovereign. “I cannot defeat him through brute force,” Malifax admitted. “He is too powerful, too unpredictable.”

Sovereign's voice was calm and clinical. “Then you must outthink him. Distraction. Deception. Divide and conquer.”

Meanwhile, Nihilix stood atop the smoldering remains of what had once been Tokyo, speaking to the void. “He clings to life like a drowning man to driftwood. But life is suffering. I must make him see.”

The battle shifted to psychological warfare. Malifax hacked into Nihilix’s energy dispersal networks using new, quantum-based programming. For a brief moment, he was able to contain the Endbringer in a stasis field orbiting the moon. But Nihilix’s will was too strong. He shattered the prison and returned with fury, leveling three of Malifax’s command centers in a single day.

In retaliation, Malifax released a neural broadcast into the atmosphere—Project Epiphany. It temporarily gave humanity a taste of what life under his rule would be: no war, no hunger, no inequality. For 24 hours, the world experienced utopia. But then Nihilix appeared, and in a single gesture, erased the illusion. “They must choose,” he said. “And when they see the truth, they will choose nothing.”

But humanity didn’t choose. It was paralyzed, caught in the crossfire of two gods. Some began to worship Nihilix, seeing in him a messianic figure who would release them from the prison of existence. Others rallied behind Malifax, preferring the iron cage of structure over the abyss of nothingness.

As the stalemate dragged on, the Earth itself began to suffer. Climate systems collapsed, tectonic activity increased, and food supplies dwindled. The world was dying—not from one victor, but from their endless war.

One day, in the ruins of Geneva, the two met again—not as warriors, but as ideologues.

“You’ve proven your point,” Malifax said, walking through ash. “Unchecked entropy is chaos. Even you must see the waste.”

“And you’ve proven yours,” Nihilix replied, standing amidst the crumbled UN headquarters. “Order breeds stagnation. Your utopia is a prison with golden bars.”

They stared at each other, and for a moment, the wind carried only silence.

“What now?” Malifax asked.

Nihilix shook his head. “We are eternal. We do not bend.”

Their visions were too deeply rooted, their beliefs too absolute. And so, their war continued—not because one would win, but because neither could afford to lose.

In the end, perhaps that was the cruelest irony. The world would not fall to a single villain’s ambition, nor perish from a single villain’s wrath. It would be torn apart by two unyielding visions, each convinced of its own righteousness, unable to compromise, unwilling to relent.

And as the last of the stars faded beneath the shadow of their struggle, humanity could only watch and wonder—was it better to be ruled... or to be forgotten?

samples.prompt: There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.
samples.output:
There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.

You may laugh at the idea, of course. Monsters—those childhood specters with glowing eyes and claws sharpened by nightmares—are, by all accounts, figments of overactive imagination. A bump in the night, a creaking floorboard, a shadow moving just a bit too quickly across the wall—these things are easily explained by wind, old wood, or a neighbor's distant headlights. But for anyone who’s lived with a cat, truly lived with one, not merely housed a pet but shared a space with a creature of ancient instinct and careful vigilance, the truth becomes harder to dismiss.

Your cat knows. She always has.

Perhaps you’ve noticed how she sits at the foot of your bed every night, eyes fixed on the dark space beneath you. Her tail flicks, slow and deliberate, as though counting something you cannot see. Or perhaps you’ve heard her, in the hours when the world is hushed and asleep, leaping from the dresser to the floor, skittering under the bed with the urgent grace of a huntress. You think it's a game. You tell yourself she's chasing a dust bunny or a stray sock, and maybe sometimes she is. But not always.

She patrols. She guards. She listens to the low, imperceptible frequencies you cannot hear, feels the vibrations in the floor that escape your notice. There are things that stir when the house is quiet, things that breathe in the gaps between seconds, things that slither just beyond the reach of light. Your cat, with her twitching ears and glowing eyes, is their warden.

You might think she’s aloof, that she only curls against you for warmth or convenience. But the truth is, she’s a sentinel. Her purring is a warding hum, a frequency that monsters cannot abide. When she curls up next to your chest and begins that rhythmic, soothing buzz, she is not only comforting you—she is casting a spell, a protective aura that stretches to the corners of the room. It’s the same reason she sometimes darts to the door and stares at the hallway, her body stiff and alert. She’s not being dramatic. She’s warning them.

You don’t see them because she does.

When you were a child, you feared the gap between the mattress and the floor. You dared not let your feet dangle. You slept with the covers tucked tightly beneath you, a flimsy barrier against the unknown. Back then, you didn’t have a cat. Back then, the things under your bed whispered more loudly. You might remember the dreams—sharp, vivid, and strange. Dreams of long fingers reaching, of cold breath on your skin. You outgrew them, or so you thought.

Then the cat came.

At first, she was a kitten, more fluff than muscle, more mischief than mystery. But even then, she showed signs. She’d stare at empty spaces with unsettling intensity, arch her back at corners of the room that seemed perfectly innocent to you. You laughed, called her dramatic, blamed her antics on kitten curiosity. But over time, the shadows seemed to behave a little better. The strange creaks in the floor happened less often. And those dreams? They faded.

Your cat grew. She learned your rhythms, your moods, your habits. But more importantly, she learned the house—the way it breathed, the way it held silence. She learned where the thin places were, the spots where the veil between the seen and unseen wore down like threadbare carpet. And every night, without fail, she walked the perimeter. She sniffed the corners. She sat beneath your bed, her eyes glinting in the dark, waiting.

The monsters know she is there. They’ve learned to avoid your room. They linger in the attic, in the basement, in the cold spaces between the walls. But they do not come near you, not while she’s watching. You've never thanked her, not really. You bring her treats, scratch behind her ears, and tell her she’s a good girl when she meows for attention. But you’ve never said to her, “Thank you for keeping me safe.” Maybe it’s because you don’t quite believe it. Or maybe it’s because, deep down, you do—and that scares you more than the monsters ever did.

You might wonder what would happen if she were gone. Not just outside for the day, but truly gone. The thought creeps in sometimes, quietly, like a chill under the door. You imagine the first night without her—the empty floor where she used to nap, the silence where her purring once filled the dark. You imagine sleeping alone, truly alone, and you wonder: would the shadows return? Would you dream again of cold fingers and breathless whispers?

You don’t want to find out.

There are no monsters under your bed. Not because they don’t exist, but because your cat does. She is a guardian cloaked in fur, a priestess of purrs and claws, a creature that straddles the worlds of myth and mundane. She is the reason you sleep soundly, the reason your room is warm when the rest of the house feels cold.

So the next time you wake in the middle of the night and see her perched on the edge of the bed, eyes wide and unblinking, don’t shoo her away. Don’t roll over and dismiss her as odd. Watch her. Listen. There’s a language in her silence, a message in the stillness of her body. She is telling you: “I am here. You are safe.”

And you are.

Because while you dream of stars and seas and impossible skies, she is your sentinel in the dark. She is your shield, your spell, your secret weapon against the things that crawl and whisper and wait. She is the reason the monsters have given up. They no longer gather beneath your bed, no longer press their faces to the floorboards, no longer reach for your dangling foot.

They know she is watching.

So sleep well. Leave your feet uncovered if you like. Let your hand dangle off the edge of the bed. Your cat is on duty, and she does not sleep—not truly—until the dawn creeps in through the window and the last of the shadows retreats. The monsters don’t stand a chance.

There are no monsters under your bed. Your cat makes sure of it.

samples.prompt: Write about a world where only randomly chosen people from the Internet are allowed to name children. Changing or lying about your name is punished by death.
samples.output:
In the year 2134, the Naming Protocol had become one of the most sacred and feared institutions in the global order. After centuries of war, inequality, and cultural upheaval, the human race had finally converged on a single, unifying belief: names held power. Not just the power of identity, but the power to shape destiny. And thus, the right to name a child was too consequential to leave in the hands of parents. Instead, names would be assigned by the Global Naming Network—a vast, automated system that randomly selected individuals from the Internet to bestow names upon newborns.

The idea had originated in the early 21st century as a viral art project. A group of performance artists created a website where anyone could submit a name for an unborn child in exchange for a small donation. The project, called "Name Me," attracted global attention when a couple in Finland named their daughter "Sparrowflux" based on a name submitted by a teenager in Brazil. The idea was quirky, even charming. But as the decades rolled on and the Internet became increasingly centralized, weaponized, and regulated, the concept took on a darker, more authoritarian tone.

By 2090, the United Nations—now restructured as the Unified Earth Assembly—formally implemented the Universal Naming Protocol. The rationale was scientific and spiritual. Studies from neural linguistics and behavioral psychology suggested that names influenced a person’s sense of self and interaction with the world. Meanwhile, a growing movement of digital mystics preached that names were echoes of an individual’s quantum signature. In a world where artificial intelligence had solved most logistical problems and governments were more symbolic than functional, the question of identity became humanity’s last frontier.

Under the Protocol, every time a child was born, an encrypted algorithm selected a random user from the global Internet. The chosen user, called the Nominator, would receive a single prompt: a series of anonymized details about the child—birth time, location, parental DNA profiles, and astrological data. They had exactly one hour to submit a name. That name would be recorded in the Global Registry and assigned to the child for life.

There were no second chances. Names could not be changed, shortened, or altered. To do so was considered an act of Identity Evasion, a capital offense punishable by death. The punishment was swift and merciless, carried out by autonomous drones known as Nomadics, which patrolled cities and rural areas alike. Even nicknames were frowned upon, though not technically punishable. Most people didn’t risk it.

The names themselves became increasingly strange and diverse. Some were poetic—like “Celestaria Daylight” or “Thorn in Morning Wind.” Others were cryptic strings of characters, such as “X7-ThetaLake” or “Juno3x.” Many bore the unmistakable fingerprints of Internet humor and memes: “Dankus Prime,” “Yeetoria,” “404 NotFound.” Scholars began cataloging names in massive databases, studying their etymology and the psychological effects they had on individuals. A new academic discipline emerged: Onomastology of the Randomized Self.

At first, people resisted. Protests erupted in major cities. Parents demanded their right to name their offspring. Religious groups decried the system as blasphemous. But the Protocol was ruthless in its enforcement. Within a decade, the resistance crumbled. The first public executions of Identity Evaders were broadcast live, their names read aloud before the final moment. “Let it be known,” the Nomadic drones would say in their sterile, artificial voices, “that [name] has forsaken their given identity and shall be erased.”

For many, the fear of death was enough. But for others, the Protocol became a strange kind of faith. Naming ceremonies, once intimate family affairs, turned into public spectacles. When a child was born, the entire community gathered to watch the announcement of the name, eyes glued to the central screen, breath held. The moment the name appeared, a chorus of reactions would erupt—gasps, laughter, applause, or stunned silence. The Nominator’s username, too, was displayed. Some became minor celebrities. Others vanished into anonymity.

One such name belonged to a girl born in Sector 9-42 of the Pacific Megalopolis. Her name was “GlitterMaw.exe.” Her parents were horrified. They had hoped for something elegant, like “Elena” or “Isadora.” But the name they received was a strange fusion of whimsy and code, the kind of moniker a bored teenager might assign to a video game avatar. Still, they dared not protest. They held their baby close and whispered the name over and over, trying to make it sound like love.

As GlitterMaw.exe grew up, she struggled with her identity. Children at school mocked her. Adults tried to avoid saying her name aloud. She developed a stutter, then a lisp, then a stony silence. But she kept her name, always. She knew the consequences. At the age of sixteen, she began researching the Nominator who had named her. It took months of illegal hacking, encrypted forums, and dark web whispers, but finally, she found them—an old man in a remote corner of what used to be Ukraine. His username was “BlipGod84,” and he had no memory of naming her. “I thought it was a game,” he said during their video call. “I didn’t know it was real.”

GlitterMaw.exe didn’t respond. She simply stared at him for a long time before logging off. The next day, she painted her name across the side of the city’s tallest building. “I am GlitterMaw.exe,” it read. “And I will not be erased.”

Her message struck a chord. Across the globe, others began to reclaim their names—not by changing them, but by embracing them in defiance of the system’s cold indifference. “B0ngRipperZeta,” a poet from the African Union, released a bestselling collection of verses titled *Names Are the Bones of the World.* “WubWubWitch,” a journalist from the Arctic Archipelagos, began a podcast that interviewed people about their names and the stories they carried.

The Naming Protocol still stood. The Nomadics still patrolled. But something had shifted. People began to treat their names not as burdens, but as riddles to be solved. A name like “404 NotFound” became a badge of existential inquiry. A name like “FluffBeastReign” turned into a fashion brand. Humanity had been forced to relinquish control over its most intimate possession—the act of naming a child—but in doing so, it discovered something deeper: that identity was not given, but forged.

And so, in that strange new world where names came from the faceless chaos of the Internet and death was the price of defiance, people learned to wear their names like armor. Not because they had chosen them, but because they had chosen to live with them.

samples.prompt: Begin "After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river."
samples.output:
After the draw, I took his bullets and threw his gun in the river. The cold water swallowed it with a faint splash, the ripples quickly fading into the stillness of the night. For a moment, I just stood there, listening. The crickets had stopped chirping, the wind had died down, and even the moon seemed to hang silently overhead, unwilling to bear witness to what had just transpired.

His body lay motionless in the dust behind me, one hand still twitching weakly, the other sprawled open like a question he hadn’t had time to ask. I didn’t want to look back, but I knew I’d have to. Not for his sake—he had made his choice—but for mine. There are moments in life where you cross a line and there’s no going back. This was mine.

His name was Eli Harper, and once upon a time, I called him brother.

We weren’t related by blood, but in this part of the world, blood doesn’t always decide kinship. We rode together for five years, through every kind of hell the frontier could spit at a man. We fought side by side, shared fire and whiskey, held each other up when our legs could no longer carry us. He was quick with a laugh, quicker with a gun, and for a long while, I thought there was nothing we couldn’t face together.

But things change. People change.

It started with the O’Malley job in Abilene. A simple bank run, in and out before the sheriff even knew what happened. That was the plan. But Eli got greedy. He wanted the vault, not just the till. He blew it open with dynamite, killed two guards in the blast, and shot a teller who’d been hiding behind the counter. She couldn’t have been more than sixteen.

I told him we were done after that. I rode off that night, left him with the money and the mess. Figured he’d skip town, maybe head south to Mexico where the law couldn’t follow. I tried to start fresh, drifted from town to town, taking odd jobs, keeping my head low. But the past has a way of catching up.

He found me in Dry Creek, two years later. Clean-shaven, dressed like a gentleman, and talking like he’d found religion. Said he’d changed. Said he wanted to make things right. I believed him. I wanted to believe him.

We rode together again, just for a little while. Small jobs, nothing illegal. Hauling freight, escorting stagecoaches, that kind of thing. It almost felt like old times. Until the night he stole from the Widow Langley. Took her savings, every cent she had hidden in a false floorboard under the hearth. And when I confronted him, he laughed.

“You still think you’re better than me,” he said. “But we’re the same, you and I. You just don’t want to admit it.”

I walked away again, this time swearing I’d put him down if I ever saw him again.

That was six months ago.

Then came the letter. No name, just a scribbled note: “Eli’s coming. He’s looking for you.”

I knew what that meant. Men like Eli don’t forgive, and they sure as hell don’t forget. So I waited. Made my peace. Cleaned my gun.

He rode into town just before sundown, dust trailing behind him like a storm cloud. He dismounted slowly, like he had all the time in the world. The townsfolk scattered. They knew what was coming.

He found me in the square, standing under the old clock tower. We said nothing at first. Just stared. He was thinner than I remembered, but his eyes still burned with that same fire—cold, angry, relentless.

“I told you I’d find you,” he said.

“I never doubted it.”

“You ready?”

I looked at the sky. The last light of day was slipping beneath the horizon, casting long shadows across the street. It seemed fitting.

“Yeah,” I said. “I’m ready.”

We took our positions, ten paces apart. The whole town watched from behind shutters and doorways. The silence was deafening.

Then came the draw.

I was faster.

He didn’t even get his gun halfway out of the holster before my bullet caught him in the chest. He staggered, blinked in surprise, and dropped to his knees. The gun fell from his hand, clattering against the cobblestones.

I walked over slowly, knelt beside him. He was still breathing, barely.

“You could’ve walked away,” I said.

He coughed, blood bubbling at the corner of his lips. “So could you.”

Maybe he was right.

But it was too late for that now.

I took the bullets from his belt, cold brass gleaming in the moonlight. Then I picked up his revolver and walked to the river. It wasn’t about vengeance anymore. It wasn’t even about justice. It was about ending something that had gone on too long. Something that had poisoned both our lives.

The river was calm, almost serene. I held the gun for a moment, feeling the weight of it in my hand. Then I let it go.

The splash was small, almost insignificant. But to me, it sounded like the closing of a door.

Now, as I stand here with dawn breaking over the horizon, I feel the weight lifting. Not gone, not completely. Some burdens never leave you. But lighter. Manageable.

I don’t know what comes next. Maybe I’ll keep drifting. Maybe I’ll find a place to settle down, grow old, and forget the sound of gunfire. Or maybe I’ll find another ghost from my past, waiting down some dusty road with a score to settle.

But for now, I walk away from the river and into the rising sun. The day is new, and for the first time in a long while, so am I.

samples.prompt: She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring.
samples.output:
She held onto the night, for she feared what the day would bring. In the quiet hours when the world slumbered and the stars blinked their ancient light across the dark dome of sky, she felt safe. The stillness wrapped around her like a protective cloak, shielding her from the relentless march of time and the burdens that came with each sunrise. Night, with all its shadows and whispered promises, was her sanctuary.

It wasn’t always this way. Once, she had loved the day. She had chased the sun across fields of gold, laughed in its warmth, and danced in its brightness. Mornings had once smelled of fresh coffee and new beginnings, afternoons had been filled with color, and evenings had offered the hopeful transition into restful sleep. But life has a way of changing the hues of things, and for her, the light had become something to dread.

It wasn’t any single event that turned her affection from day to night. It was a slow erosion, a series of small heartbreaks that, like water dripping onto stone, eventually carved deep grooves into her spirit. The day, with its clarity, demanded too much. It asked her to face responsibilities she no longer had the strength to bear. It asked her to smile when she had forgotten how. It asked her to be seen when all she wanted was to disappear.

So she clung to the hours after dusk, where expectations faded into the darkness and no one asked questions. In the night, the world was quiet—mercifully quiet. The phone didn’t ring. The emails didn’t come. No one knocked on the door. She could sit with her thoughts without interruption, even if those thoughts weren’t always kind. At least in the night, she felt she could breathe.

Others didn’t understand. They told her that the night was for rest, for release, for letting go. They told her that the day was when life happened, when hope and opportunity blossomed. But to her, the day was a battlefield. The morning sun rising over the horizon didn’t signify a fresh start—it was a harbinger of another round of silent wars she fought within herself. The daylight stripped away the shadows in which she hid, exposing her vulnerabilities like raw nerves. There was no refuge in the glare of the sun.

She would often sit by the window as the city around her gradually fell into slumber. The distant hum of cars faded. The streetlights flickered on, painting pools of amber light onto the pavement below. Somewhere, a dog barked. Somewhere else, laughter echoed from a late-night gathering. These sounds were muted, distant, like memories. They didn’t reach her in any meaningful way, but they reminded her that life continued, even in the dark.

Inside, the only light came from a single lamp, its glow soft and forgiving. She would wrap herself in a blanket and curl up in her favorite chair, a book open on her lap more for comfort than for reading. The words often blurred, her mind drifting elsewhere. Sometimes she would write, pouring her unspoken thoughts into a journal that no one would ever read. It was in these quiet acts that she found a semblance of peace.

Her fear of the day wasn’t rooted in laziness or apathy—it was rooted in pain. Pain that had gone unseen for too long, pain that had been brushed aside with well-meaning platitudes. “You’ll feel better tomorrow,” people would say. “Things always look brighter in the morning.” But for her, the morning was just a cruel reset, a reminder that she had to start all over again. The nights, at least, offered continuity. In the dark, she didn’t have to pretend.

There was a certain honesty to the night. It didn’t ask her to smile or put on a brave face. It allowed her to cry without explanation, to feel without justification. The stars didn’t judge. The moon didn’t demand. The night simply existed, accepting her in whatever form she happened to be. And there was immense comfort in that.

Still, she knew she couldn’t live in the night forever. The world operated on the rhythm of the sun, and she couldn’t stay hidden in the shadows without consequence. Friends grew distant. Opportunities slipped away. Even her body began to rebel against the inverted cycle. But the fear remained, a quiet tremor beneath her skin. What if the day brought more loss? What if it brought reminders of everything she had failed to become? What if it forced her to confront the truth she had long buried?

And yet, somewhere deep within her, a small spark remained. A voice—faint, but persistent—whispered that maybe, just maybe, the day could change. That perhaps the pain that had once taken root in the daylight could be soothed. She didn’t know how. She didn’t know when. But she hadn’t let the spark die completely, and that meant something.

In the meantime, she continued her nightly ritual. She watched the stars and listened to the stillness. She let the darkness hold her while she gathered the courage to face the light again. She didn’t rush it. Healing, she had learned, was not a race. It was a slow unfolding, like the petals of a flower that only bloomed when ready.

So she held onto the night, not because she had given up, but because she was still finding her way. The night was her cocoon, her place of transformation. And though she feared what the day would bring, she also knew that no night lasted forever. Eventually, the sun would rise. And when it did, she hoped to be ready—not to run, but to stand and let its warmth touch her face once more.

samples.prompt: 2 WW2 Pilots develop rivalry after multiple dogfights. Finally one of them dies.
samples.output:
The sky above Europe in 1944 was a treacherous theater of smoke, fire, and roaring engines. Among the countless pilots who crisscrossed the heavens in a deadly ballet of steel and will, two men—Captain James "Hawk" Mallory of the United States Army Air Forces and Hauptmann Erik Weiss of the German Luftwaffe—stood out not only for their skill but for the bitter rivalry that emerged between them. What began as chance encounters in the sky evolved into a personal vendetta, culminating in a final, fateful confrontation that only one of them would survive.

Their first meeting came over the battered skies of Normandy, just days after D-Day. Mallory, flying his P-51 Mustang, was escorting a squadron of B-17s returning from a bombing run deep into German-occupied territory. Weiss, piloting a sleek, grey-painted Focke-Wulf 190, swooped in with his squadron to intercept. In the flurry of maneuvers, tracers lit the sky like fireworks. Mallory and Weiss locked eyes briefly through cockpit glass as they passed within mere yards of each other, both too experienced to be shaken, yet both struck by the presence of a worthy opponent.

Mallory returned to base that evening, his Mustang bearing a few fresh holes but still airworthy. He recounted the encounter to his comrades with a mix of frustration and admiration. "He was good," Mallory admitted. "Damn good. He flies like he’s got ice in his veins."

Unbeknownst to Mallory, Weiss had come away from the fight with a similar impression. To the German ace, the American had flown with an unrelenting ferocity that distinguished him from the rest. It wasn’t long before both pilots started recognizing each other's aircraft in the chaos of battle. The rivalry was born.

Their second meeting came just a week later, over the Ardennes. This time, it was more than a chance skirmish—it was an extended duel. For nearly twenty minutes, they danced through the clouds, twisting and turning, diving and climbing in a deadly pursuit. Neither could gain the upper hand. Fuel gauges dipped toward empty before they broke away, each returning to their respective airfields, frustrated and exhilarated.

Mallory began referring to Weiss in his flight log simply as "the Ghost," noting each encounter with increasing obsession. "Saw the Ghost again today," one entry read. "He’s learning my tricks. I’ll have to be better next time." Weiss, too, began keeping track of the American pilot, calling him "Der Falke"—The Falcon—for his sharp, aggressive style.

Over the months that followed, their aerial duels became legend among their squadrons. Stories spread of how the two aces seemed to find each other in the vast theater of war, as if drawn together by fate. Each encounter was a testament to their unparalleled skill, and each one ended inconclusively—until the final day.

It was late September, and the Allies were pushing deeper into German-held territory. Intelligence reported a large German armored column moving near Aachen, and Mallory’s squadron was sent to provide air cover for a bombing run aimed at crippling it. As the bombers released their payload, a group of Focke-Wulfs appeared on the horizon. At their head was Weiss.

Mallory recognized the distinctive trim on Weiss’s aircraft immediately. Something in his gut told him this would be their last dance.

They broke from the fray almost instinctively, leaving the rest of the battle behind as they climbed higher into the sun. Weiss rolled his fighter and dove, trying to draw Mallory into a trap. But the American had seen this maneuver before. He countered with a corkscrew dive, forcing Weiss to pull up hard. The two jets leveled out at tree-top height, weaving through anti-aircraft fire and smoke columns rising from the ground.

For nearly fifteen minutes they fought, every ounce of skill and instinct pushed to the limit. Mallory’s brow was soaked with sweat beneath his helmet, his hands gripping the controls with white-knuckled focus. Weiss, too, was a picture of control and intensity, his face set, his eyes scanning for the smallest mistake.

Then it happened.

A glancing burst from Mallory’s guns struck Weiss’s right wing. The Focke-Wulf shuddered, trailing smoke, but Weiss managed to keep control. He veered left, climbing toward the clouds, and Mallory followed. They emerged into a blinding sea of white, visibility near zero. Mallory scanned frantically, heart hammering. Then, from above and behind, came the glint of sunlight on metal.

Weiss had maneuvered into position for the kill.

Mallory saw him a second too late. The first burst ripped across the tail of the Mustang, but Mallory yanked the stick hard, rolling out of the line of fire. The second burst missed, and now, for the first time, Weiss had overcommitted.

Mallory pulled a tight loop, cutting through the clouds like a blade. He came down on Weiss’s six, leveling out with his guns aligned. He hesitated for a fraction of a second—long enough to wonder if this was the end of something significant, something more than just war.

Then he fired.

The bullets tore through the Focke-Wulf’s fuselage. Smoke and flames erupted from the engine as the aircraft spiraled downward. Mallory followed, watching helplessly as Weiss tried to level out. At the last moment, the German pilot ejected, his parachute deploying just before the plane smashed into a forest below.

Mallory circled once, watching the canopy drift toward the earth. A strange emptiness settled in his chest. The rivalry that had defined his war, that had sharpened his edge and kept him alive, was over.

Weiss did not survive the landing. Whether it was a failed parachute or enemy ground fire, no one could say for certain. Mallory learned of his rival’s fate days later, from intercepted German communications.

He didn’t celebrate.

Back at base, Mallory sat alone beside his aircraft, staring at the sky. The war raged on, but something had changed. He had won their final duel—but it didn’t feel like victory. The Ghost was gone.

Years later, long after the war was over, Mallory visited a cemetery in Germany. He stood before a modest headstone marked with Erik Weiss’s name, hands in his pockets, head bowed. Perhaps it was respect. Perhaps it was closure. He left a single item on the grave: a pilot’s patch, worn and faded, bearing the image of a falcon.

“I’ll see you in the skies,” he whispered, and walked away.

samples.prompt: My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.
samples.output:
My heart was beating like a drum. This was it. There was no going back.

The hallway stretched before me like a tunnel, dimly lit and impossibly long. I could hear the soft shuffle of feet behind me, but I didn’t dare look back. This moment—this breathless, wild, terrifying moment—was everything I had worked for. Or feared. Or both. My palms were slick with sweat, and I could feel the pounding in my chest echoing in my ears. My heart, relentless and loud, seemed to be trying to warn me, to scream at me to run. But I didn’t run. I couldn’t.

The door ahead loomed like a monolith. Its dark wood surface was smooth, polished, and completely unremarkable, and yet it held the weight of my entire future. Beyond that door was the culmination of years of work, sacrifice, and secrets. I reached out, feeling the cool metal of the handle beneath my trembling fingers. My breath caught. I hesitated.

It wasn’t supposed to be like this. When I first started this journey, I had dreams. Simple ones, really. I wanted to make something of myself, to feel like I belonged in a world that so often felt like it had no place for me. I wasn’t chasing fame or recognition. I wanted to matter—to someone, to anyone. But somewhere along the way, the path twisted. Opportunities became obligations. Choices became compromises. And moments like this, once full of promise, now felt like the edge of a cliff.

I could still hear Professor Langley’s voice in my head—stern, meticulous, and always just a little disappointed. “This project will define you,” he used to say, adjusting his glasses with that maddening precision. “Not just your career, but your character.” At the time, I thought he was exaggerating. I thought he was trying to scare us into working harder. But now, standing in front of the door to the presentation chamber, I realized he wasn’t warning us—he was preparing us.

I took a breath. Then another. I had rehearsed this presentation a hundred times, each iteration more refined than the last. I had memorized every slide, every statistic, every transition. But nothing could prepare me for the weight of this moment. The panel of scientists and investors waiting inside didn’t just hold the keys to my future—they held the power to validate or destroy everything I had built.

I pushed the door open.

The room was silent except for the soft hum of the projector and the tapping of fingers on laptop keys. Five faces turned to me, each one carefully impassive. Dr. Simmons gave a curt nod, gesturing me forward. My legs felt like lead as I stepped into the room, the door clicking shut behind me with an ominous finality. No going back.

I placed my notes on the podium, though I knew I wouldn’t need them. I glanced at the screen behind me, where the first slide—“Revolutionizing Renewable Energy”—glowed in bold letters. I cleared my throat.

“Good afternoon,” I began, surprised by how steady my voice sounded. “Thank you for giving me the opportunity to present my findings.”

The next twenty minutes were a blur of words and images. I spoke of solar grids optimized through machine learning, of energy storage systems built to last decades instead of years, of sustainable technologies that could bring power to even the most remote corners of the world. As I talked, I watched their faces. Some skeptical, some intrigued. A few scribbled notes. One or two leaned forward. That was a good sign, right?

But I knew the real test was yet to come.

As I reached the final slide, I paused. This was the part I hadn’t shared with anyone—not even my advisor. This was the leap.

“There’s one more thing,” I said, and for the first time, my voice wavered. “What I’ve shown you today is just the framework. The real innovation lies in what we’ve been developing behind the scenes.”

I pressed a button, and the image on the screen shifted. A glowing sphere appeared—my prototype. Compact, elegant, and unlike anything currently on the market. I explained how it worked, how it could absorb, store, and redistribute energy with unprecedented efficiency. I detailed the tests we had run, the simulations, the early field trials. And then I said the words I had been dreading:

“It’s not perfect yet. It still requires refinement. But it works. And it has the potential to change everything.”

Silence. The kind that stretches and grows, filling the room until it feels like a physical presence. I stood still, hands clenched at my sides, waiting.

Dr. Simmons leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers. “You’re asking us to believe in something that hasn’t been peer-reviewed, hasn’t been independently verified, and is based on a process that you admit is still unstable.”

I nodded. “Yes. I’m asking you to believe in what it can become.”

Another pause. Then, slowly, Dr. Simmons smiled.

And just like that, the tension broke.

Questions came, rapid-fire and relentless. Technical details, ethical concerns, scalability, funding needs. I answered them all, some more confidently than others. And through it all, I felt that wild drumbeat in my chest begin to settle. Not because the fear had gone away, but because I was finally facing it head-on.

When the presentation ended, they thanked me. Politely, professionally, noncommittally. I wouldn’t know their decision for days, maybe weeks. But as I stepped out of that room and into the crisp air of the hallway, something inside me shifted.

I had done it. I had taken the leap.

The hallway was still long, still dim, but it no longer felt like a tunnel. More like a bridge. A path to something new. My heart was still beating, but now it was in rhythm with something else—hope.

This was it. There was no going back.

And maybe that was a good thing.

samples.prompt: You decide to try out a new cafe. You get your latte and sit outside. A few minutes later, a hooded stranger sits down across from you. Startled, you look up, only to find your own face staring back at you.
samples.output:
It was a chilly autumn afternoon when I wandered into the small cafe on the corner of Maple and 3rd. The kind of place that wore its charm like an old sweater—threadbare yet comforting. The sign above the door read “The Wandering Bean,” and something about the name pulled me in. Maybe it was the way the golden light spilled through the windows or the scent of freshly ground coffee beans that seemed to wrap itself around me like a familiar embrace. I was new to the neighborhood, still learning the rhythm of the streets and the quirks of its people, and the cafe seemed like a good place to pause and observe.

Inside, soft jazz played over the speakers, and the barista, a woman with silver hair and a constellation of freckles, smiled as I ordered a vanilla oat milk latte. I took the drink outside and found a small table nestled near a hedge of burning bush, its fiery leaves trembling in the wind. The street was quiet, save for the occasional hum of a passing car and the distant laughter of children walking home from school. I sipped my latte, the warmth of it seeping into my chest, and allowed myself to relax for the first time in days.

I was halfway through my drink, lost in thought, when I noticed someone approaching. The figure wore a long, slate-gray hoodie with the hood drawn up, obscuring their face. They moved with a strange stillness, and something about their presence made my skin tighten. Without a word, the person pulled out the chair across from me and sat down.

I blinked. "Excuse me," I said, unsure whether to be annoyed or concerned. "Do I know you?"

The hooded figure reached up and slowly pulled back the hood.

My breath caught. I stared, stunned into silence. It was my face.

Not someone who resembled me. Not a twin. Me. Down to the faint scar on my left eyebrow from when I fell off my bike at age ten. Down to the small mole on the base of my neck. Every detail was exact.

“What the…” I whispered, my voice barely audible over the rustling leaves.

The other me smiled faintly. “I know this is a lot to take in,” they said, voice matching mine perfectly, with the same inflections and rhythm. “But we don’t have much time.”

My heart pounded in my chest. I glanced around, expecting someone to laugh or pull out a camera and shout “Gotcha!” But no one was watching. The street had emptied, as if the world had paused for this moment.

“Who are you?” I demanded, trying to keep my voice steady. “What is this? Are you some kind of...cosplayer? A prankster?”

The doppelgänger shook their head. “I’m you. From the future. Or at least, a possible version of your future.”

I laughed, but it came out hollow. “Right. Because that makes sense.”

“I didn’t believe it either when it first happened to me,” they said, leaning forward, eyes locked onto mine. “But listen. There’s something coming. A decision you’re going to make in the next few days. It might seem small, but it’s going to change everything.”

I stared at them, trying to process what I was hearing. “You expect me to believe that you’re some future version of me who came back in time to warn me about…a decision?”

“Yes,” they said simply.

“What kind of decision?”

The other me hesitated. “I can’t tell you exactly. If I do, it could alter things in ways I can’t predict. But I’m here to give you a choice. To show you that you have one.”

I took a deep breath, trying to ground myself. The warm ceramic cup in my hand, the scent of roasted coffee, the breeze brushing against my skin—everything felt real. Too real. “Okay,” I said cautiously. “Let’s say I believe you. Why now? Why here?”

“Because this is the moment you start to listen. To stop numbing yourself with routine and noise. This is the moment you’re open to change.”

I frowned. “You make it sound like I’m sleepwalking through my life.”

“Aren’t you?” they asked gently.

I didn’t answer. Instead, I looked away, watching a leaf spiral down to the pavement. Maybe they were right. I'd been going through the motions for a long time. A job I didn’t love but didn’t hate enough to leave. Friends I rarely saw. Dreams I’d shelved in favor of stability. I told myself I was being practical. But maybe I was just afraid.

The other me reached into their pocket and pulled out a small, folded piece of paper. They slid it across the table. “When the time comes, read this. You’ll know when.”

I stared at the paper, then looked back at them. “What happens if I don’t?”

Their expression darkened, just for a second. “Then everything stays the same. And that’s not a good thing.”

Before I could ask more, they stood. “I have to go,” they said, pulling the hood back over their head.

“Wait—” I reached out, but they were already turning the corner, vanishing into the shadows between buildings.

I sat there for a long moment, stunned. The air felt heavier, charged with something I couldn’t name. I looked down at the folded paper on the table. My hand trembled as I picked it up. It was light, almost weightless, and yet it seemed to hum with significance.

I didn’t open it.

Not yet.

Instead, I slipped it into my coat pocket, finished my latte, and sat there as the sun dipped below the rooftops, painting the sky in hues of gold and crimson.

Days passed. I replayed the encounter over and over in my mind, questioning my sanity, wondering if I’d imagined it all. But I couldn’t ignore the paper in my pocket, a constant reminder that something had shifted.

Then, one morning, I stood at a crossroads—figuratively and literally. A job offer had come in from a company across the country. A dream opportunity, but one that required me to leave everything behind. I stood on the sidewalk, heart pounding, unsure.

And then I remembered the paper.

With trembling fingers, I unfolded it.

Inside, in my own handwriting, were four words: “Jump. You’ll grow wings.”

Tears welled in my eyes. I didn’t know what lay ahead, but in that moment, I made my choice.

I jumped.

samples.prompt: A door leads to a different location each time it is opened.
samples.output:
Every time Jenna opened the door, the world shifted beneath her feet.

At first, she thought it was a dream—a trick of light, a figment of her overworked imagination. But the door was real. Solid oak, worn at the edges, with a brass handle that always felt warm to the touch. She had found it three days ago in the attic of the old farmhouse she had inherited from her grandmother. Tucked behind a false wall, the door had no frame, no hinges—just a rectangle of wood standing upright in the center of the dusty room, as if someone had placed it there for safekeeping.

The first time she opened it, she stepped into a forest unlike any she had ever seen. Trees taller than skyscrapers, leaves the size of umbrellas, and a sky that shimmered with a pale green hue. The air was warm and smelled of honey and pine. She had only stayed a few minutes, afraid to venture too far from the door. When she stepped back through, she was once again in her attic, the familiar creak of the floorboards grounding her in reality.

The next day, curiosity got the better of her. She opened the door again, half-expecting to see the same forest. Instead, she was greeted by the salty scent of the sea. Before her stretched a vast, endless beach with sand as white as snow and waves that rolled in without a sound. The sun—too large, too red—hung low in the sky, casting shadows that danced around her feet. She walked along the shore for what felt like hours, collecting smooth blue stones and watching strange, bird-like creatures glide through the air.

Each opening brought her somewhere new. A city suspended in the sky, its buildings floating on invisible currents. A cavern of glowing crystals that sang when touched. A snowy tundra dotted with giant, slow-moving beasts that watched her with intelligent eyes. Sometimes the places were beautiful, serene. Other times, they were desolate, eerie, filled with the whisper of things just out of sight.

Jenna kept a notebook, recording every detail she could remember. The temperature, the smells, the sounds. She sketched landscapes, noted the positions of stars, tried to make sense of any patterns. But the door gave no clues. There was no mechanism she could see, no switch or dial to influence where it would take her. It simply opened—sometimes creaking, sometimes silent—and offered her a view into another world.

She stopped telling people. The few friends she had left thought she was grieving, hallucinating, maybe even losing her mind. But Jenna knew what she saw. What she felt. The door was real, and it was hers.

Over time, she became bolder. She packed a backpack with supplies—water, food, a flashlight, a compass. She ventured farther into these strange worlds, taking photographs when she could, though sometimes the images refused to develop, as if the places themselves rejected being captured. She met people—beings, really—who didn’t speak, but communicated with gestures, light, or even music. Some were kind, offering her gifts of fruit or small trinkets. Others were cautious, retreating into the shadows at her approach.

One day, she stepped into what looked like a library. It was enormous, stretching beyond the limits of her vision, with books stacked in spirals that floated in midair. A figure approached her—a tall, robed creature with no face but eyes that glowed like lanterns. It gestured to a book, and when she opened it, she saw her own face on the first page. The text shifted as she read, recounting her journeys, her thoughts. The last page was blank. She looked up, startled, but the creature was gone. The door stood behind her, waiting.

There were rules, she realized. The door never opened to the same place twice. If she stayed too long, it would vanish. She learned this the hard way when she spent an entire day exploring a floating island covered in bioluminescent moss. She had returned to find the door gone, the space where it had been now just air. Panic had set in, but after walking for hours, she found it again—standing in a glade of tall grass, swaying slightly as if in a breeze.

She began to wonder what the door wanted. If it was simply a passage, or something more. A test? A gift? A curse?

The idea of closing it forever crossed her mind more than once. She could board it up, bury it, pretend it had never existed. But each time she thought about it, the pull returned—that magnetic urge to see what lay beyond. She wasn’t sure if it was curiosity or something deeper, something older. The door was a mystery, yes, but it also felt like a calling.

Then came the day it opened to a mirror of her own world. The same farmhouse, the same trees outside the window. But the sun was larger, the air heavier. She stepped out and found herself face to face with another version of herself—older, tired, eyes filled with sorrow. They didn’t speak, but the look they exchanged said everything. Jenna turned back and stepped through the door, heart pounding.

After that, she changed. She became more cautious, more thoughtful. She still explored, still documented, but now she wondered not just what was out there, but what it meant. Each world was a possibility, a glimpse into a life she might have lived, a choice she might have made. The door wasn’t just a portal—it was a reflection.

Years passed. The notebook became a series of volumes, each one filled with impossible stories. She grew older, though the door never did. It remained the same—unmoving, unchanging, eternal. Sometimes it frightened her, how it defied logic, time, even reality itself. But it also comforted her. In a world where everything changed, the door remained.

One evening, she opened it and found nothing. Just darkness. No sound, no scent, no wind. Just black. She hesitated. This had never happened before. Slowly, she stepped forward.

And the door closed behind her.

samples.prompt: You're writing a horror novel, and the events in the book start happening in real life.
samples.output:
It started, as most horror stories do, with a blank page and a flicker of unease.

I had always considered myself a grounded writer. I didn’t believe in ghosts or demons or cursed objects. My horror novels were methodically constructed—scares built on psychological tension, not supernatural fluff. I wrote about the things that kept people up at night: the creak of a floorboard when you're alone, the shadow that lingers just too long, the voice that calls your name when no one is there. I understood fear because I had studied it, not because I believed in it.

When I began writing “The Hollow Ones,” I was in a slump. Three months overdue on a deadline and desperate for a spark, I turned to an old idea that had haunted the back of my mind since childhood. When I was eight, I had a recurring dream about a town that didn’t exist, a place shrouded in mist where everyone wore masks and no one spoke. As a child, I called it Hollow Hollow. It terrified me, but I never told anyone. It felt private, sacred somehow.

Now, as an adult, I decided to name the fictional town in my novel after that dream—Hollow Hollow. In the story, a writer retreats to this secluded town for inspiration, only to discover that the townspeople are not what they seem. They wear antique porcelain masks, speak in riddles, and worship an unseen entity called "The Whisperer." The deeper the protagonist delves, the more he realizes that the town itself feeds on stories, especially those involving fear and suffering.

I wrote feverishly. The words poured out of me, like they had been waiting years to be told. The plot unfolded effortlessly, characters came alive with frightening clarity, and the town of Hollow Hollow seemed more real with every page. I dreamed about it most nights. I told myself that was normal—writers often dream of their work. But the dreams began to change. They were no longer passive observations. I was there, walking the fog-choked streets, hearing the scritch of those masks turning to face me, feeling the cold breath of something watching from the shadows.

Still, I pressed on. The book was nearly finished when the first real-world coincidence occurred.

It was small, at first. In chapter twelve, my protagonist finds a strange bird with no eyes perched on his windowsill. The next morning, I found a dead bird beneath my own window. Not eyeless, of course, but its eyes were clouded over, milky and unnatural. I brushed it off as coincidence.

Then came the phone calls.

In chapter fifteen, I described a scene where the protagonist receives a call from an unknown number. When he answers, all he hears is a whisper repeating his name. It’s the first direct communication from The Whisperer. That night, my phone rang at 3:12 a.m. I shouldn’t have answered, but I did.

A breath. Then: “We see you, Elias.”

My name. Whispered.

I hung up, heart racing, and told myself someone was playing a prank. Maybe a hacker got hold of my manuscript. Maybe it was a fan who somehow got an early draft. But I hadn’t shared it with anyone yet—not my agent, not my editor. It was saved on a single laptop, unconnected to the cloud. My office had no windows, and I worked alone.

I didn’t sleep that night.

More incidents followed. I described a symbol carved into a tree outside the protagonist’s cabin—a spiraling eye, bleeding at the center. A few days later, I found the same symbol etched into the bark of the oak in my backyard. I couldn’t explain it. I lived on a three-acre lot, isolated from my neighbors. I hadn’t shown anyone the drawing.

I stopped writing for a week, hoping the strange phenomena would stop. They didn’t. Instead, the silence of my house became oppressive. The air felt wrong, too still. I began hearing sounds—soft tapping on the windows, footsteps on the upper floor when I was downstairs. I live alone. I stopped checking. I didn’t want to know what I might see.

I tried deleting the manuscript. I opened the file, hovered my cursor over the trash icon, and hesitated. Something in me resisted—every fiber of my being screamed not to do it. My hand trembled. Then the power went out. Dead silence. When it came back minutes later, the file was gone. But when I checked my physical notes, the ones I had scribbled in notebooks and on sticky notes, the story was still there—more detailed than I remembered writing.

I tried burning them. I lit a match, dropped it into the fireplace, and fed the pages to the flame. They didn’t burn. The fire licked around them, but the paper remained untouched. Not even the ink smudged. I stared until my eyes watered from the smoke, but the story refused to be destroyed.

That night, I dreamed of Hollow Hollow again. Only this time, it wasn’t a dream.

I woke up in a place that smelled of moss and rot. The fog was so thick I could barely see my own hands. I heard the sound of glass clinking—masks. I turned, and they were there. The townspeople. Dozens of them, standing in a circle around me, their white porcelain faces staring blankly. One stepped forward, held out a book.

My book.

The cover read: “The Hollow Ones” by Elias Reed.

I woke up screaming.

The next morning, I received a package in the mail. No return address. Inside was a single copy of my book, professionally bound, with my name on the cover. Exactly as I saw it in the dream.

I haven’t told anyone. Who would believe me?

Now, when I write, the words don’t feel like mine. They come in a rush, in a voice that isn’t quite my own. I dream of Hollow Hollow every night, and each time I go deeper. I see the Whisperer now—a figure shrouded in smoke, with a mouth that never moves but always speaks. It tells me stories. It tells me what to write.

And I can’t stop.

The last time I tried, I blacked out. Woke up eight hours later with fresh pages on my desk. I don’t remember writing them. But the handwriting is mine.

I think the book is writing itself now. Or maybe the town is. The more people read it, the more real it becomes. The more it spreads.

I finished the final chapter yesterday. In it, the protagonist disappears. The last line reads: “He was last seen entering the fog, the townspeople waiting with open arms.”

I can hear them now, outside my window.

The masks clink.

The fog thickens.

If you find this, don’t read the book.

Don’t look for Hollow Hollow.

Because once you see it, it sees you.

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
The Grim Reaper's Midlife Crisis

For centuries, he had been the constant shadow trailing behind every heartbeat, the whisper in the silence after a last breath. Cloaked in black, scythe in hand, the Grim Reaper had performed his eternal duty with unflinching precision. He was the final escort, the last face seen before the unknown. There were no sick days, no retirement plans, no weekends. Death was, after all, a full-time job.

But even Death has his limits.

It started slowly—barely noticeable at first. He began arriving late to appointments, missing the precise moment a soul slipped from its earthly shell. He found himself lingering longer than necessary, watching families mourn, their grief oddly stirring something inside him. For the first time in millennia, he asked himself, “What’s the point?”

It was a question that had never occurred to him before. His job had always been clear and necessary. Life ended. He arrived. He guided. That was the cycle. But now, standing at the edge of eternity with his gleaming scythe dulled by the weight of centuries, the Grim Reaper found himself in the throes of an existential crisis. Not just any crisis—a midlife crisis.

Of course, “midlife” is a generous term when one is immortal. Still, time had a peculiar way of pressing upon even the timeless. After eons of unwavering service, he realized he was, for lack of a better term, burned out.

He began experimenting, trying to rediscover a sense of purpose. He traded in his iconic robes for jeans and a leather jacket. The cloak, he decided, was cliché. He tried hobbies. Painting brought a brief flicker of joy, until every canvas inevitably turned into some grim depiction of mortality. He tried cooking, but it was hard to enjoy a soufflé when your very presence caused the milk to curdle and eggs to rot. He even took up yoga—though the instructor found it unsettling to have a skeletal figure looming silently in the back of the studio, attempting downward dog.

He turned to therapy, seeking answers in the modern way. After all, if humans could talk through their crises, perhaps he could too. Unfortunately, not many therapists were prepared to counsel Death itself. He eventually found one—Dr. Miranda Shaw—a woman with a reputation for taking on unusual clients. She didn’t flinch when he walked into her office. She simply gestured to the couch and said, “So, what brings you in today?”

He mused aloud about the futility of his work, about the endless parades of souls, the repetition, the lack of appreciation. He spoke of the loneliness, the way no one truly understood him. Miranda listened patiently, nodding, occasionally jotting notes. At one point, she asked, “What would you do if you weren’t the Grim Reaper?”

The question struck him like a thunderclap. He had never considered that he could be anything else. That perhaps, his identity was not solely defined by his job. He didn’t have an answer, but the idea nestled itself in his mind like a seed.

He began exploring. He visited museums, wandered through bustling cities, stood unnoticed in the middle of Times Square and watched life pulse around him. He took long walks through forests, marveling at the cycles of growth and decay. He began seeing death not as an end, but as part of a broader tapestry. It was not destruction, but transformation.

Still, the job called, and the souls waited. He couldn’t abandon them. But he started changing the way he approached his work. No longer the cold harbinger, he became a compassionate guide. He took time to listen to the dying, to hear their stories, their regrets, their joys. He began to see beauty in the fragility of life.

His fellow immortals noticed the change. Fate, ever pragmatic, raised an eyebrow. Time chuckled and said, “It was bound to happen sooner or later.” Even the Fates whispered about his transformation. Death had become… soft? No, not soft—aware.

He started mentoring new reapers, sharing his insights. “Don’t just take the soul,” he would say. “Witness it. Honor it. Each one is a universe unto itself.”

Somewhere along the line, he picked up a sketchbook. Not to capture death, but life. He drew the way a child clutches their mother’s hand, the way lovers’ eyes meet for the last time, the way an old man smiles at his dog before taking his final breath. His drawings were filled with tenderness, with a reverence he had never known he possessed.

There were still hard days. Mass tragedies, plagues, acts of violence—they weighed heavily on him. But instead of numbness, he met them with empathy. He learned to mourn. Not as a weakness, but as a tribute to those whose stories had ended.

One afternoon, while sitting on a park bench beside a hospice nurse who could somehow see him, she asked, “Do you ever wish you were alive?”

He paused. “No,” he said. “But I wish I had known what living meant sooner.”

The Grim Reaper’s midlife crisis didn’t end with a sports car or a fling with a mysterious stranger. It wasn’t solved overnight or by some grand epiphany. It was a slow, painful, beautiful unraveling—and reweaving—of identity. He came to understand that while he was Death, he was not devoid of life. His role was not to extinguish, but to usher. Not to sever, but to carry forward.

He still wore black, but now it was by choice. He still carried the scythe, though more as a symbol than a weapon. And when he arrived to collect a soul, he no longer loomed. He sat beside them, held their hand if they wished, and said, “It’s all right. I’m with you.”

In his own way, Death had found meaning not in the end, but in the connections forged in those final moments. The crisis had not undone him—it had reshaped him.

Because even for the eternal, there comes a time to ask not what you are, but who.

samples.prompt: You thought that when you wished to be the smartest in the world, you would get smarter, not everyone else dumber. Society is in shambles.
samples.output:
When I stood atop that windswept hill, clutching the antique coin I had found in my grandfather’s attic, I didn’t think anything would happen. The old man used to ramble about the coin’s magic, about how he never dared use it because wishes always came with consequences. I’d always chalked it up to senility, but in that moment—frustrated after failing my third job interview in a week—I whispered into the wind: “I wish to be the smartest person in the world.”

There was no flash of light. No thunderclap. Just silence, and then the breeze picked up again. I laughed at myself, embarrassed, and headed home. The next morning, everything was different.

At first, I didn’t notice anything unusual. The barista at my usual coffee shop fumbled with the register, staring at the buttons like they were runes. “Sorry,” she muttered, “they changed the system.” Odd, but not impossible. Then the bus driver asked me if I knew how to get downtown. Again, strange—he’d driven the same route for years. But it wasn’t until I got to the library that I realized something was deeply, terribly wrong.

The library was in chaos. Books were strewn across the floor, computers sat idle with blinking cursors, and the few staff members wandered aimlessly, asking patrons if they remembered how to check out a book. I offered to help, thinking maybe a power outage had reset the system. But when I sat down at the terminal, everything was functioning normally. I navigated it with ease, checking out my book in seconds.

“Wow,” one worker said, eyes wide. “You must be some kind of genius.”

It wasn’t until I got home and turned on the news that the horror truly hit. The headlines were jumbled, the newscasters stumbling over their scripts. One of them actually said, “We’re doing our best, folks. Things are just... different today.” Scientists were reportedly baffled; people were forgetting simple tasks, basic knowledge, even words. A neuroscientist on one segment confessed to forgetting how to tie his shoes that morning.

I sat on my couch, the book from the library open in my lap, but I couldn’t read. My mind was spinning. What had I done?

I hadn’t asked to be the only one who could still think clearly. I had wished to be the smartest, expecting some kind of enlightenment—maybe a sudden understanding of quantum physics, or a photographic memory. I thought I’d gain intelligence, not steal it from the world.

Over the next few days, things got worse. The power grid began failing. With no one able to manage complex systems, entire cities went dark. Planes were grounded, hospitals turned into chaotic warehouses of suffering, and governments were paralyzed. People looked up at me like I was a prophet, asking me what to do, how to fix it all. I didn’t know where to begin.

I tried to teach them, at first. I gathered groups and started with the basics—math, reading, history. But their minds couldn’t hold the information. It was as if their capacity for learning had diminished, as if the knowledge had been drained and locked away somewhere outside their reach. I wrote manuals, recorded videos, even attempted to recreate educational systems, but nothing stuck. Their attention spans were shattered, their curiosity dulled.

The worst part was watching my friends and family fade. My sister, once a brilliant engineer, now struggled to assemble a sandwich. My childhood best friend, who used to beat me at chess without breaking a sweat, now stared blankly at the board, unsure of the rules.

I was alone.

And yet, my mind had never been sharper. I could see patterns in nature I had never noticed before. I understood languages after hearing them once. I solved mathematical problems that had stumped humanity for centuries. But what was the point? I had no peers to share discoveries with, no mentors to challenge me. Every conversation felt like talking to a mirror that couldn’t reflect.

I began to wonder if this was some kind of ironic punishment. I had asked for more, not realizing that intelligence is only meaningful when it’s shared. Knowledge, after all, is a communal force. We build on each other’s ideas, correct each other’s errors, inspire each other’s creativity. Alone, intelligence is a sterile light in an empty room.

As months passed, I became something of a caretaker. I taught people how to farm using the simplest methods I could devise, how to purify water, how to care for the sick using herbal remedies and basic hygiene. I kept people alive, but civilization was crumbling. The internet had long since gone dark. Books decayed on forgotten shelves. I tried to preserve what I could, writing down everything I remembered in meticulous journals, hoping that someday someone else might rise from the ashes of this intellectual drought and find them.

But each night, as I lay under the stars, I asked myself the same question: could I undo it?

I returned to the hill many times, the coin heavy in my pocket. I whispered into the wind, begged for a reversal. “Please,” I said, “give it back. Take my intelligence if you must, just restore theirs.” But nothing happened. Whatever mechanism had granted my wish had no interest in undoing it.

One day, as I was teaching a child how to count using pebbles, I saw something in her eyes—a spark. It was faint, but it was there. She asked questions, real ones, not just parroting back what I said. She experimented, tried different arrangements of stones just to see what would happen. I felt a flicker of hope.

Perhaps the world hadn’t lost its capacity for intelligence, just its immediate access to it. Maybe the knowledge had been buried, not destroyed. Maybe, just maybe, the human mind, resilient and tenacious, could climb its way back up.

That became my purpose. Not to wallow in guilt or loneliness, but to rebuild. To seed the world with knowledge, little by little. I became the gardener of minds, planting ideas in the fertile soil of curiosity, nurturing them with patience and love.

I would never forgive myself for the wish I made, but I could atone through effort. And maybe, one day, a child’s child would stand atop that same hill, holding the old coin, and understand the true cost of wanting to be the smartest person in the world.

And maybe they would choose differently.

samples.prompt: "Stop."Sam spoke sharply and with certainty. My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. "That isn't a human."The entity who held the form of a human turned its head sharply. Sam was right; this clearly wasn't a human. I couldn't tell you how I knew it- I just knew.
samples.output:
"Stop." Sam spoke sharply and with certainty.

My brother only spoke like this when something was truly wrong. His voice cut through the thick fog of confusion that had settled over the evening like a damp blanket. It wasn't the kind of tone he used when he was annoyed or joking—it carried weight, finality, and something else I couldn’t quite name. It was the kind of voice that made you listen before your brain even processed the words.

"That isn't a human."

The entity—because now I understood, without a shadow of a doubt, that a word like 'person' didn’t fit—turned its head sharply in our direction. Too sharply. The movement was off, like a marionette pulled by strings that didn’t understand the subtleties of human motion.

I froze. My breath caught somewhere between my lungs and lips, refusing to move. My heart stuttered and then picked up with a fury, pounding in my chest like a warning drum.

Sam stepped slightly in front of me, protective by instinct. He was always the older brother, always the cautious one, but this was different. His body was taut, like a wire pulled too tight, ready to snap or strike. His eyes never left the thing in front of us.

It had the shape of a man. Roughly six feet tall, broad shoulders, a face that at first glance appeared symmetrical and unremarkable. Brown hair, neutral expression. But the longer you looked, the more it unraveled. The eyes were too still, too empty, like glass marbles that reflected light but held no life. The mouth was stretched in a smile that never touched the eyes, and the skin—there was something wrong with the skin. It was too smooth, too uniform, like rubber made to look like flesh.

I couldn’t tell you how I knew it—how I was so certain it wasn’t human—but I just knew. Some primal instinct deep inside me screamed that this thing didn’t belong. My skin crawled as though ants marched just beneath the surface, and the air around us felt heavier, like the atmosphere itself recoiled from the entity’s presence.

The thing took a step forward, and Sam raised a hand, palm out.

"Don’t come any closer," he said. His voice was calm, firm, but I could see the tension in his jaw, the way his shoulders were squared.

The entity halted, head tilting slightly, as if puzzled by the command. Then it blinked—too slowly, a beat too long—and when it opened its eyes again, something glimmered behind them. A flicker of something alien. Not emotion. Not thought. Something else. Something that chilled me to the marrow.

"You are mistaken," it said, and the voice was worse than I could have imagined. It wasn’t robotic—it was too smooth, too pleasant, like a voice designed by committee to sound comforting. It was the kind of voice you’d hear in a commercial, or on a help line—utterly devoid of authenticity. The words were perfect, but somehow… hollow.

Sam didn’t move. He held his ground, eyes locked on the thing.

"I said don’t come closer."

The entity paused, and then the smile widened—too wide. It stretched the skin in a way that seemed impossible, like it was testing the limits of its own disguise. The corners of its mouth reached almost to the ears, revealing teeth that were just a little too uniform, too white, like a dentist's model. It was a parody of friendliness, and it made my stomach twist.

I whispered, "What is it?" but I didn’t expect an answer.

Sam’s eyes didn’t leave the creature. "I don’t know," he said quietly. "But it’s watching us. Learning."

The entity took another step forward, slower this time, as if testing our reaction. I could hear the crunch of gravel beneath its feet, but the sound was off—too soft, like the weight wasn’t quite right.

"We should go," I said, tugging lightly at Sam’s sleeve. "Now."

He nodded slightly, but didn’t move. "Back away slowly," he murmured. "Don’t turn your back on it."

I did as he said, legs trembling, each step feeling like it took years. The thing’s head followed every movement, never blinking, never looking away. It didn’t take another step, but I could feel it calculating, measuring.

When we finally reached the edge of the clearing, Sam grabbed my hand and pulled me into the treeline. We didn’t run, not yet. Not until we were out of sight.

Then we ran.

Branches slapped our faces and tore at our clothes, the darkness swallowing us whole. I didn’t know where we were going—just away. Away from that thing, that mockery of humanity. And as we ran, my mind kept replaying the way it had spoken, the way it had looked at us. Not with curiosity, but with hunger. Not with confusion, but with purpose.

We didn’t stop until we reached the old ranger station. It hadn’t been used in years, but the door was still intact, and Sam slammed it shut behind us, bolting it with shaking hands. We collapsed against the wall, gasping for breath.

For a long time, neither of us spoke. The silence wrapped around us, thick and suffocating.

Finally, I said, "What the hell was that?"

Sam was pale, sweat beading on his forehead. "I don’t know. But it wasn’t alone."

I looked at him sharply. "What do you mean?"

He hesitated. "When it looked at me… I saw something. Reflections. Like… other faces. Dozens of them. Maybe hundreds. Like it was part of something bigger."

I shuddered, the cold in my bones spreading. “What do we do?”

Sam stared at the door, then out the cracked window toward the darkness.

“We learn,” he said. “Just like it’s learning us.”

And in that moment, I realized the rules had changed. The world was not what we thought it was. There were things hiding in plain sight, wearing our faces, mimicking our lives. And we had just seen behind the curtain.

We weren’t ready. But we had no choice.

Because now it knew we knew. And it wasn’t going to stop.
