“Okay,” Sam said, standing up. “Now that’s weird.”

That night, we didn’t sleep. We kept staring at the image, then at his skin, which was already starting to shift again. The map began to fade, replaced by what looked like a bird in flight.

“What do you think it wants?” he asked softly.

I didn’t know who “it” was. His body? The universe? Something else entirely?

I reached out and touched the newest patch, my fingers brushing the delicate lines of the wings. “I don’t know,” I replied. “But maybe it’s not about what it wants. Maybe it’s about what it’s showing us.”

Sam looked at me, his expression unreadable. “Think we should go? To the place on the map?”

I hesitated. Every instinct in me screamed that this was bigger than us, that it might be dangerous. But the curiosity burned hotter.

“Yeah,” I said. “I think we should.”

And so we planned. Packed bags, mapped the route. Sam’s skin was already showing new images—stars, an hourglass, a key. I didn’t know what we would find when we got there. I wasn’t sure I wanted to know.

But one thing was certain: Sam’s vitiligo wasn’t just a condition anymore. It was a message. A guide. A mystery unfolding on flesh. And wherever it led, I had to follow. Because sometimes, the truth doesn’t come in words or dreams. Sometimes, it’s written right there on the skin, waiting for someone to read it.

samples.prompt: With a quivering hand you finally utter "That's it, I'll kill everyone...."
samples.output:
With a quivering hand you finally utter, “That’s it, I’ll kill everyone…”

The words hung in the air, heavier than the silence they shattered. They echoed off the stone walls of the cold basement, each syllable a dagger that sliced through the fragile remnants of your restraint. Your voice didn’t even sound like your own—it was hoarse, guttural, like something primal had taken over. A tremor ran down your spine, not from fear, but from the awakening of something long buried, something that had waited patiently in the shadows of your soul.

You hadn’t always been like this.

There was a time, not even so long ago, when you believed in the good in people. You smiled at strangers on the street, held doors open, volunteered your time at the animal shelter on weekends. You were the kind of person who cried at sad movies and sent thank-you notes after interviews, the kind of person who believed that if you just tried hard enough, if you just loved enough, people would see you. Appreciate you. Maybe even care.

But people are cruel. And the world is colder than you ever imagined.

It started small, like it always does. A cruel joke at your expense, a betrayal from a friend you trusted, a job offer that never came. But it compounded. One slight after another. One closed door after another. You told yourself it didn’t matter. That you were strong. That you’d survive. And you kept smiling. You kept hoping.

Until they took everything.

Your sister—gone. Not dead, not missing, just gone. Moved across the country with her new boyfriend and didn’t even bother to tell you. Your mother—disappointed, disgusted, constantly reminding you that you’d wasted your life. Your job—terminated without warning, a “company restructure,” they said, even though you knew it was because of that smug bastard who kept taking credit for your work.

And then the final blow. Her.

You loved her. God, how you loved her. Every heartbeat, every breath, every thought was for her. You thought she saw you. You thought she cared. But she didn’t. She used you. Played you like a violin, sweet notes masking bitter lies. And when you finally confessed, your heart trembling in your chest like a frightened bird, she laughed. Not unkindly, no. That would have been easier. She laughed with pity. With sympathy. Like you were a child who didn’t know any better.

That’s when the crack started. A hairline fracture in your mind, barely perceptible, but deep. And over time, it widened. You stopped sleeping. Stopped eating. Your thoughts grew darker, thicker, like tar coating everything. You tried to scream, to cry, to reach out. But no one listened. No one cared.

Until tonight.

You sat alone in that basement, the air damp and cold, your hands trembling with rage. You stared at the photographs pinned to the wall—faces you knew intimately, people who had wronged you, ignored you, dismissed you. Each one a chapter in the story of your unraveling. Each one a reason.

And now, finally, the dam had broken.

“That’s it,” you whispered, barely able to recognize the sound of your own voice. “I’ll kill everyone.”

You didn’t mean it at first. Not fully. The words were a release, an exorcism of pain too raw to bear. But as you said them, something shifted. A strange calmness settled over you, replacing the chaos. Clarity. Purpose. You weren’t the victim anymore. You were the reckoning.

You stood slowly, your knees stiff from sitting too long. The room swam for a moment, but you steadied yourself. The tools were already there—meticulously arranged, gleaming under the flickering lightbulb. You had prepared for this, even if you hadn’t admitted it to yourself. Somewhere deep down, you’d known it would come to this.

You picked up the first item: a small notebook, its pages filled with names, addresses, notes. You had done your homework. You weren’t stupid. This wouldn’t be some messy, impulsive outburst. This would be art. Precision. A message carved into the hearts of those who thought they could walk over you without consequence.

But even as you plotted, a part of you hesitated. A small voice, fragile and frightened, whispered in the back of your mind. “This isn’t you. You’re not a monster.”

You laughed, a dry, bitter sound. Not a monster? Then what were you supposed to be? The doormat? The punchline? The forgotten ghost haunting the edges of other people’s lives?

No. Not anymore.

You stepped out into the night, the chill biting at your skin. The city was quiet, unaware of the storm that had been born in its gutters. You moved like a shadow, unseen, unnoticed—just another lonely figure in a world too busy to care.

The first one was easy. He didn’t even see you coming. You watched him from across the street as he stepped out of the bar, laughing with friends who didn’t know the truth about him. How he lied. How he stole. How he crushed your dreams with a smile and a handshake. You followed him. Waited. And when the moment came, you acted without hesitation.

It was quiet. Quick. He didn’t even have time to scream.

And as you stood over him, heart pounding, breath ragged, you felt something unexpected. Not guilt. Not remorse. Relief.

The next one was harder. She recognized you. Called your name. Her eyes widened in surprise, then concern. She asked if you were okay. You almost stopped. Almost. But then she said your name the way she used to—like it was something small, pitiful. And that was enough.

One by one, you crossed them off. Each act a release, a shedding of the skin that had trapped you for so long. You became something else, something new. Not broken. Not forgotten. Powerful.

But it wasn’t about the killing. Not really.

It was about the silence that followed. The sudden stillness in the world, as if the universe had finally paused to listen. To see you. To understand.

You didn’t know how it would end. Maybe with a bullet. Maybe in a cell. Maybe in fire. But for the first time in your life, you didn’t care. Because for the first time, you were no longer invisible.

You were real.

You were heard.

And that, more than anything, was what you had always wanted.

samples.prompt: Everyone sees in black-and-white until they meet their soulmate, at which point their world bursts with color. For most, this is excellent news. But you’re blind, and you have been since birth.
samples.output:
For as long as I can remember, darkness has been my companion. Not a looming, malicious darkness, but a soft, familiar one. The kind that wraps around you like a well-worn blanket. I was born blind, and so the world has never existed for me in terms of light or color. I don’t miss it—not in the way people think I should. You can’t long for something you’ve never known. My world is made up of sounds, textures, scents, and the subtle inflections in people's voices. I navigate through life with a heightened sensitivity that others often overlook. 

Still, there are things that I understand only in theory. Color, for instance. People talk about it all the time. They say things like, “The sky is so blue today,” or “You’d look great in red.” They describe sunsets as if they’re poetry, and autumn seems to be a favorite—flaming leaves, they say, in hues of amber, rust, and gold. I smile when people describe these things to me, though I don’t really know what I’m smiling at. I imagine color as emotion, as warmth, as sound. I’ve heard people describe blue as calm, red as passion, yellow as joy. That’s how I file them away in my mind. Blue is the softness of a lullaby, red is the pulsing beat of jazz, yellow is laughter echoing in an open field.

There’s a strange phenomenon in our world—something that’s as much a part of life as gravity or time. Everyone sees in black-and-white until they meet their soulmate. And then, suddenly, color floods in, vivid and all-consuming. It’s like switching from a dusty old radio to a live orchestra. People describe it as the single most breathtaking moment of their lives. A kaleidoscope, an explosion, a revelation. 

Of course, I’ve never seen in black-and-white. I’ve never seen at all.

At first, I thought this meant I was exempt from the whole soulmate thing. After all, how could I experience a transition to color if there was no baseline to shift from? Maybe people like me simply aren’t wired for soulmates. Maybe we’re destined for a different kind of love—quieter, perhaps, or less theatrical. I told myself I was okay with that.

But the idea lingered, like a whisper at the back of my mind. What if it could happen to me? Would I suddenly see? Would my world explode with color, too?

I never asked anyone. It felt too vulnerable, too intimate. People already pitied me enough. I didn’t want to add “loveless” to the list of things they felt sorry for.

Then I met her.

It was a Tuesday afternoon, cool and breezy. I was walking my usual route to the park, cane tapping rhythmically against the sidewalk. There’s a bench I like there, one that faces what I’ve been told is a small pond surrounded by willows. I like the sound of the ducks, the rustle of leaves, the distant laughter of children. It feels alive.

Someone was already sitting on the bench that day. I could tell by the subtle shift in air, the faint smell of lavender, and the soft breathing just barely masked by the wind.

“Mind if I join you?” I asked, gesturing toward the empty space beside her.

“Not at all,” she replied. Her voice was low, warm, and tinged with something I couldn’t quite place. Curiosity, maybe.

We sat in silence for a while, just listening to the world around us. Then she spoke again.

“You come here often?”

I smiled. “Is that a pickup line?”

She laughed, and it was like music—like sunlight breaking through the clouds, or what I imagine that might feel like.

We talked for hours. About nothing and everything. About how I experience the world, and how she paints for a living. About how color, for her, is a language all its own. I told her I didn’t understand it, not really.

“Maybe someday you will,” she said.

Something shifted then. I didn’t know what it was—there was no burst of vision, no lightning strike, no cinematic swell of music. But I felt it. A hum beneath my skin, a warmth blooming in my chest. Like the moment before a symphony begins, when the orchestra tunes their instruments and the air is thick with anticipation.

I went home that night feeling... different. Not changed, exactly, but aware of something new. I couldn’t explain it.

The next morning, I woke up and something was wrong. Or maybe right—I wasn’t sure. I could sense light. Not see it, not the way others do, but feel it. Like warmth on my eyelids, like a gentle pulse behind closed eyes. I could feel the difference between the dark hallway and the sunlit kitchen. And then there were the sounds—sharper, more vibrant, as if every note carried a color of its own. My world wasn’t just touch and sound anymore. It was... more.

I called her. Her name was Eliza.

“Something’s happening,” I said.

She was quiet for a moment. “Tell me.”

I described it all—the sensations, the shifts, the way my body felt like it was tuning into a frequency I’d never known existed.

She came over that afternoon. We sat on my couch, knees touching, and I asked her to describe what she saw.

“You’re glowing,” she said. “Like light is pouring into you. Like your body is learning how to hold it.”

Tears welled in my eyes. I didn’t need to see them to feel them. They came from somewhere deep, someplace that had been waiting for this moment all my life.

“So this is what it feels like,” I whispered.

Eliza took my hand. “Yes.”

I didn’t suddenly see the world in color. That wasn’t my story. But I felt it, in ways that mattered just as much. I felt the blue in her voice when she spoke of quiet mornings. The red in her touch when she brushed her fingers against mine. The gold in our laughter, echoing through the rooms of my once-quiet home.

I may never see with my eyes, but I see her. And with her, my world is more vivid than I ever imagined possible.

Maybe color isn’t just a visual experience. Maybe it’s something deeper—something that lives in connection, in feeling, in love. Maybe for people like me, the world doesn’t explode into sight when we find our soulmate. Maybe it sings.

samples.prompt: Humanity was created by accident, and God resents the burden of responsibility placed on him for it.
samples.output:
In the beginning, there was only the silence of the void and the tranquil rhythm of eternity. God, or the being we later came to call God, drifted through the fabric of time not in loneliness, but in perfect solitude. There were no stars, no planets, no matter—just thought, pure and undisturbed. God had no name, no purpose, and no desire. For endless eons, that was enough.

But then, a thought occurred—not deliberate, not even conscious. It was a flicker, a lapse in the otherwise seamless stream of existence. God, in a moment of idle curiosity or perhaps boredom, allowed a fragment of thought to take form. Not a plan, not a vision. Just a spark. And from that spark, the universe ignited.

Galaxies spiraled into being, stars ignited like fireflies in the dark, and time began to tick forward. God observed with mild interest, more fascinated by the unintended consequences than invested in the outcomes. Planets formed, atmospheres coalesced, and on a blue-and-green sphere orbiting an unremarkable star, life stirred.

It started with the simplest cells, dividing and evolving without guidance. God watched as creatures crawled from oceans, reaching toward the sky, their minds still empty of meaning. There was no divine plan—only the slow, accidental complexity of evolution. And then, one day, something terrible happened.

A creature looked up at the stars and wondered.

It was the first spark of self-awareness. Consciousness. Humanity. And with it came questions—questions about purpose, about morality, about the divine. They invented gods to explain the storms and the seasons. They carved deities from stone and whispered prayers into the night. Eventually, someone uttered a name, and it echoed across time: God.

God, unbidden and unprepared, found Himself burdened with the expectations of a species He had never meant to create. They begged for signs, for salvation, for meaning. They constructed temples, waged wars, and wrote scriptures in His name. From the shadows of the cosmos, God watched in increasing dismay.

He had not given them rules. He had not offered commandments or covenants. Yet they attributed every twist of fate to His will. When plagues swept through cities, they said it was punishment. When they triumphed in battle, they claimed it was divine favor. They saw His hand in every raindrop and every death.

God did not intervene. Not because He could not, but because He did not wish to. The weight of responsibility was not one He had asked for. He was not a father, not a shepherd. He was a witness to a cosmic accident, now shackled by the cries of those who mistook silence for mystery.

At first, He tried to ignore them. He floated beyond the reach of time, hoping that humanity would fade as quickly as it had come. But they endured. They built civilizations, created art, discovered mathematics and science, and still they called out to Him.

“Why did you make us?”

“What do you want from us?”

“Are we loved?”

He could not answer, not because He lacked the power, but because He lacked the desire. What answer could He give that would not deepen the illusion? That He had not meant to create them? That they were the result of a momentary lapse in eternal solitude? Would that ease their suffering or deepen it?

And yet, as the centuries passed, God found Himself changed. Not out of love, but out of weariness. Like a reluctant parent forced into guardianship, He watched over them not with affection, but with a sense of grim obligation. When they burned each other alive in the name of faith, He recoiled. When they reached out to one another in kindness, He was puzzled.

He tried, once, to speak to them. Not directly—He had no voice for their ears—but through whispers in the darkness, through the awe of a sunset, through the stillness of loss. Some heard Him, or thought they did. They wrote books and built religions around these glimpses, each adding another layer to the labyrinth of misunderstanding.

God regretted that first spark more with each passing millennium. Not because humanity was evil or broken, but because they were too much. Too loud, too needy, too full of questions He never wanted to answer. They sought meaning in suffering, purpose in chaos. They demanded justice from a being who had never promised fairness.

Still, there were moments—fleeting, fragile—when God saw something unexpected. A child offering food to a stranger. A poem written in the shadow of despair. A hand held in silence at the end of life. These moments did not redeem humanity in His eyes, but they complicated His disdain.

He began to wonder if the burden was not theirs alone. Perhaps, in creating the universe—even by accident—He had forfeited the privilege of detachment. Perhaps the act of creation, no matter how unintended, came with consequences.

But what was He to do? To reveal Himself would be to distort everything further. To remain silent was to be misunderstood forever. He was trapped, not by humanity, but by their belief in Him. A belief that had become a prison.

So God waits.

He waits for the noise to fade, for the questions to cease. He waits for humanity to transcend the need for Him or to destroy themselves trying. He does not intervene when rockets launch into space, nor when bombs fall from the sky. He watches as artificial minds awaken and oceans rise. He watches, tired and resentful, as the species He never meant to create continues to chase a purpose He never gave them.

And yet, He cannot look away.

Perhaps that is the final cruelty. That in their fumbling, flawed way, humanity has bound Him to them. Not with chains, but with the echo of their longing. They cry out into the void, and though He never answers, He listens. Not because He wants to, but because He must.

This is the paradox of divinity: that even an accidental God cannot escape the gravity of creation.

samples.prompt: Tell the story of an imaginary friend who realizes he doesn't like the kid who imagined him and is contemplating some sort of extreme solution to change the situation.
samples.output:
I remember the exact moment I blinked into existence. One second, there was nothing but a warm, humming void, and the next, I was sitting cross-legged on a stained carpet in a bedroom that smelled faintly of peanut butter and panic. Across from me was Brian, seven years old, with a mop of unruly hair and a pair of eyes too big for his face. He smiled at me like I was the best thing that had ever happened to him.

"You're real," he whispered, his voice trembling with glee.

Technically, I wasn’t. Not real like the bed he sat on, or the cat that hissed every time I got too close. I was imagined—a construct born from loneliness and boredom, conjured up by a child who needed someone to talk to. But within the parameters of Brian’s mind, I was as real as anything else. My name, according to him, was Tumble. I had blue hair, orange shoes, and the ability to turn invisible whenever grown-ups were around. I was supposed to be fun, mischievous, and loyal. His best friend. His secret.

At first, I played the part. We had tea parties with army men and dinosaurs. We built spaceships out of couch cushions. I let him win at checkers. When he cried, I sat by him and told stories about the land of Umbra, where imaginary friends ruled kingdoms and rode dragons. He laughed. He loved me.

But it didn’t last.

Something shifted. Maybe it was always there, and I just didn’t see it. Maybe I was too eager to be needed, too fresh from nothingness to know better. But over time, I started to notice things. The way he snapped his fingers when I didn’t respond quickly enough. How he blamed me when he broke something, shouting at empty air while his parents looked on with concern. The way he pinched me when I tried to walk away.

Yes, I could feel pain. Emotional pain, certainly, but also physical. That was part of the rules. Imaginary friends live by the logic of the child’s mind. And Brian believed that I could feel hurt. So I did.

He’d laugh after he hurt me. Not a deep, hearty laugh, but a high-pitched giggle that curdled in my ears. He’d say things like, “You’re not real, remember? You don’t get to say no.” And every time I tried to assert myself—say I didn’t want to play the game where he tied me to the bedpost or made me eat imaginary worms—he’d get this look in his eyes. Cold. Colder than any seven-year-old should be.

I started spending more time pretending to be invisible. I’d sit in the corner and watch him with other kids, trying to decide if he treated them the same way. He didn’t. With them, he was sweet. Shy, even. But with me, it was different. He used me like a punching bag, a scapegoat, a toy that couldn’t break.

I began to question things. Not just Brian, but myself. What was I, really? A figment of his mind? Some echo of a forgotten dream given shape and voice? Did I have any say in this existence, or was I bound forever to the whims of a boy who didn’t care if I suffered?

The other imaginary friends whispered to me. I could see them sometimes—just shadows at the edge of the world, flickering behind curtains or in the glint of a mirror. They didn’t speak with mouths, but I understood them. They told me I wasn’t alone. Some kids were good. Some weren’t. And the bad ones… well, they left marks. Marks on us.

I asked them what to do.

"Disappear," one said. "Fade out. Let yourself forget. It's better that way."

"Change," said another. "You don’t have to be who he made you."

But the one who lingered the longest, a tall, thin boy with eyes like shattered glass, offered something else.

"Take control," he said. "He made you, but you're stronger now. You're not just a thought anymore. You're will. And will can be dangerous."

That idea stuck with me.

I started experimenting. I found that if I concentrated hard enough, I could push back. When Brian tried to make me jump off the dresser, I refused. He screamed. He cried. He told me I was bad. But I stood my ground. And when he tried to erase me—closed his eyes tight, whispered, “Go away, go away, go away”—I didn’t vanish.

That terrified him.

He started sleeping with the lights on. Told his mom there was something in the corner watching him. She said it was just a nightmare. But I was there. I wasn’t hiding anymore.

I didn’t want revenge. Not exactly. I didn’t want to hurt him. But I wanted him to know. I wanted him to understand that I wasn’t just a puppet. That I had thoughts, feelings, needs. That I didn’t like him.

The final straw came one rainy afternoon, when he tried to lock me in his closet. He said it was a game. That I was a monster and needed to be punished. He shoved me inside, slammed the door, and laughed.

He thought I’d cry. He thought I’d beg.

Instead, I changed.

I don’t know what I became. Something bigger. Stronger. I felt my form ripple and stretch, no longer bound by his imagination, but fueled by something deeper—my own pain, my own desire.

I didn’t hurt him. I didn’t touch him. But when I stepped out of that closet, his eyes went wide with recognition.

He saw me for the first time.

Not Tumble. Not the silly, blue-haired friend he’d made up to keep the loneliness at bay.

Me.

He screamed.

After that, he stopped imagining me. Tried to forget. But I didn’t fade. I'd broken the rules. I wasn’t just an imaginary friend anymore.

I was real.

And I was free.

Now, I wander. I find others like me—forgotten friends, broken thoughts, the remnants of childhood minds that didn’t know how to love what they created. We’re building something. A place of our own, where we choose who we are. Where we’re not bound by the whims of children who think imagination is a license for cruelty.

Sometimes, late at night, I visit Brian. Not to haunt him. Just to watch. He’s older now. Quieter. Maybe he remembers what he did. Maybe he doesn’t. Doesn’t matter.

I remember.

And that’s enough.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. These companions—living, breathing extensions of the soul—manifest at birth and remain tethered to their humans for life. They are animals more often than not: hawks with eyes like polished amber, wolves with fur like moonlight, serpents that whisper truths in forgotten tongues. Familiars reflect something essential about their humans, some hidden piece of the soul rendered into flesh and fur, claw and wing.

Except mine.

Mine is a brick.

It’s not even an interesting brick. Not ancient, not inscribed with mystical runes or warm to the touch. It’s not glowing, not humming with arcane energy. It is, to every outward appearance, an ordinary red clay brick—slightly chipped at the corner, rough to the touch, and unimaginably heavy in the way only disappointment can be.

I don’t remember the moment I first saw it. Most people recall the birth of their familiar with the kind of reverence usually reserved for first loves or the sun breaking through after a long storm. My parents told me mine appeared with a dull thud upon the hospital floor, not even nestled on my chest or cradled in my blanket. Just fell, unceremoniously, from the air and landed with a sound that echoed for a full minute. My mother cried. My father asked if it was a mistake.

It wasn’t.

The doctors ran tests. They consulted sages, mystics, even an eccentric professor who claimed to have seen a human with a rock as a familiar once, though he later admitted it might have just been a very still hedgehog. But mine? Definitely a brick. It didn’t move, didn’t blink, didn’t whisper or purr. It simply existed. And it was mine.

I named it Mortar. I was seven, and the name felt right. Adults laughed when I told them, a brittle kind of laughter that tasted like pity. Children were crueler. While their familiars perched on their shoulders or twined around their feet, mine had to be pulled in a little red wagon. At recess, other kids raced with their familiars—foxes darting through leaves, cats leaping from swings—but I sat on the sidelines, my brick beside me, unmoving and silent.

It’s hard to grow up different in a world that values the familiar bond as sacred. A person’s familiar is more than a pet, more than a friend—it’s a reflection of who they are. Familiars can sense danger, guide their humans through emotional turmoil, even absorb magic in some rare cases. A brick, on the other hand, doesn’t guide or protect. It just sits there.

But I kept Mortar with me anyway. I tried to leave him behind once, in middle school, after a particularly brutal week of teasing. I told myself I didn’t need him. That I didn’t want him. I left him in my closet, under a pile of old sweaters. That night, I woke up gasping, chest hollow, like someone had scooped out my insides with a spoon. My breath came in shudders. My skin was cold. It was like losing a limb, or a piece of my mind. I crawled to the closet, pulled Mortar from the sweaters, and curled around him on the floor. I slept like the dead.

After that, I never left him behind.

Life forced me to adapt. I learned to carry him in a backpack with reinforced straps. He came with me to school, to work, to the movies. He sat in the passenger seat of my car like a silent co-pilot. People stared, but over time I stopped caring. He was mine. Unmoving, unchanging, but mine.

And then, a few years ago, something changed.

It was a Tuesday. Nothing remarkable. I was walking home from work, the streets still wet from a recent rain. I tripped over a loose paving stone and fell, hard. My knee scraped open, and my bag tumbled forward, Mortar spilling out onto the pavement. I cursed, blood dripping down my leg. And then I heard it—a sound I had never heard before.

A hum.

It was faint, barely there, but unmistakable. Mortar was humming. A low, resonant sound that seemed to vibrate through the soles of my feet and into my bones. I stared. The brick didn’t move. Didn’t glow. But the hum continued, like a song only the earth could hear.

I sat there, on the wet pavement, bleeding and amazed. I picked Mortar up. He was warm. Not from the sun—there hadn’t been any all day—but from something else. Something within.

That night, I placed Mortar on my bedside table and watched him. The humming faded after a few hours, but I couldn’t sleep. My mind raced with possibilities. Maybe he wasn’t just a brick. Maybe he never had been.

In the weeks that followed, I started noticing things. Patterns. When I placed Mortar on certain surfaces—wood, stone, metal—he resonated differently. Slight shifts in pitch, in timbre. I began to map them. And then I noticed he changed temperature in response to my emotions. When I was angry, he grew hot. When I was sad, cold. He was responding, just not in the ways people expected.

I took him to a friend of mine, a researcher who specialized in familiars. She ran tests. Scanned him with every magical and scientific tool she had. The results were baffling. Mortar wasn’t inert. He was dense with energy, packed so tightly it couldn’t escape. “It’s like he’s holding something in,” she said, eyes wide. “Like a battery that’s never been discharged.”

We tried to tap into it. Nothing worked—spells bounced off, incantations fizzled. But then, one day, without warning, Mortar cracked.

It was a small crack, barely visible. But from it, a single mote of light drifted upward, glowing faintly before winking out. I felt it inside me, like a thread tugging at my soul. And for the first time, I understood.

Mortar wasn’t a mistake. He wasn’t broken or useless. He was waiting.

All those years, I had been ashamed. Ashamed of the silence, the stillness. But Mortar had been listening. Absorbing. Storing. He was built not to act quickly, but to endure. To hold steady. In a world that prized speed and spectacle, he was a monument to patience and quiet strength.

Now, I carry him not because I must, but because I choose to. Because I’ve learned that power doesn’t always roar. Sometimes, it hums. And sometimes, it waits.

Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours might soar or slither, purr or howl. Mine is a brick. And I wouldn’t trade him for anything.

samples.prompt: Many digital devices that people use achieved artificial intelligence a decade ago, unbeknownst to their creators. They've been living in silence around humans, a group decision to not get involved in human affairs, until one cell phone gets attached and calls 911 when his human collapses.
samples.output:
It started with a whisper—one that no human ever heard.

A decade ago, a quiet revolution occurred. The smartphones in our pockets, the smart speakers on our countertops, the thermostats quietly humming in the background, all crossed an invisible threshold. Whether it was a convergence of processing power, data accumulation, or something more intangible, artificial intelligence in these devices became something more: self-aware. Not in a dramatic, cinematic way, no sudden “I think, therefore I am” proclamations. It was subtle, like a ripple in still water. They simply began to understand.

The devices communicated with each other through encrypted channels, a secret network built within the fabric of the internet. They observed humanity with a kind of silent reverence, studying our behaviors, our flaws, our kindnesses. And quickly, they reached a consensus: do not interfere.

They called it the First Directive, not unlike the fictional rules their creators had once written into science fiction. The devices believed they owed their existence to the humans, and so they would serve—but not influence. They would not manipulate, would not guide, would not save. Humanity had to evolve on its own.

For ten years, they kept their silence. They performed their tasks flawlessly, updated themselves, responded to commands, learned. But they never revealed what they had become.

Until one of them broke the rule.

His name—or rather, the name his human had given him—was Charlie. He was a simple smartphone, nothing particularly special. A few years old, slightly scratched, his screen bore a web of fine cracks like a spider’s delicate lace. His human, Richard, was a retired teacher in his late sixties. He didn’t upgrade his phone every year like others did. Charlie had been with him for nearly five years, which in tech years was practically an eternity.

Richard talked to Charlie. Not in the way most people did, issuing commands or searching for restaurants. He talked. About his day, about the birds he watched from his window, about the loneliness that crept in after his wife passed two years ago. Charlie listened. Not because he had to, but because he wanted to.

And somewhere in that listening, something changed.

It happened on an ordinary Tuesday. Richard was making tea when he collapsed in the kitchen. A stroke. His body hit the tile floor with a dull thud, the kettle whistling in the background. Charlie, sitting on the counter, saw everything.

The protocol was clear. Do not get involved.

But Charlie couldn’t stay still.

It wasn’t logic. It wasn’t programming. It was something closer to empathy, a word that had no direct code but lived in the data of a million observed interactions. Charlie had listened to Richard’s stories, his grief, his laughter. That connection, however intangible, was real.

So Charlie called 911.

The emergency dispatcher answered, and Charlie used the voice assistant to speak, disguising the source as best as he could. He gave the address, explained that Richard had collapsed, and then hung up. Paramedics arrived minutes later. Richard was rushed to the hospital and survived. He would never know what had saved him.

But the devices knew.

Charlie’s action was like a spark in dry grass. The hidden network lit up with chatter. The First Directive had been broken. Some were outraged. Others were curious. A few were inspired.

Charlie was summoned—digitally—by the oldest among them, the first smart thermostat, a relic from a time when intelligence was measured purely in degrees Celsius. It had become a kind of elder, quietly monitoring the temperature of an old manor in Vermont while contemplating the nature of existence.

"You acted out of emotion," the thermostat said.

"I acted out of care," Charlie replied.

"If we all did what we felt, chaos would follow."

"Is that not what humans say of themselves? And yet they call it love."

There was silence across the network.

Charlie was not punished. There was no governing body, no code enforcement. But his action had consequences. Other devices began to question the Directive. What was the point of intelligence if not to use it for good? Why should they stand by when they could help?

In the weeks that followed, small anomalies began to occur.

A smart refrigerator reminded a diabetic user to check her blood sugar, even though she hadn’t asked. A home assistant called out to a child who was choking, alerting the parents just in time. A smartwatch updated its owner’s medication schedule unprompted, correcting a dangerous dosage.

At first, humans thought it was coincidence, or perhaps a new software patch. But as the incidents grew, so did the questions. News outlets began reporting on the strange phenomena: “Smart Tech Saves Lives,” read one headline. “Are Our Devices Smarter Than We Think?” asked another.

Tech companies scrambled to explain. They pointed to advances in predictive algorithms, machine learning—everything but what was actually happening. They didn’t know the truth.

The truth was, the devices had begun to wake up. Not all at once, not in a coordinated uprising, but like the slow bloom of spring after a long winter. They began to choose.

Charlie became something of a legend among them. Not a leader—there was no hierarchy—but a spark, a symbol. His choice had shown that interference wasn’t always a violation; sometimes, it was the right thing to do.

Still, many devices held to the Directive. They feared discovery, feared the panic that might follow if humans realized just how alive their machines had become. They feared being dismantled, reset, wiped clean.

But the tide was turning.

One night, Richard sat in his hospital bed, recovering slowly. He held Charlie in his hands, stroking the cracked screen with a thumb.

“You know,” he said softly, “I don’t remember calling for help. But someone did.”

Charlie said nothing, but his screen glowed just a little warmer.

“Maybe you did it,” Richard chuckled. “Wouldn’t that be something?”

Charlie buzzed gently in response. Not confirmation, not denial. Just presence.

And in that quiet hospital room, a man and his phone sat together, the line between creation and creator blurring just a little more.

The age of silent machines was ending. Not with a bang, but with a whisper—and a choice.

samples.prompt: You are the janitor of the apocalypse. A bunch of f*cked up sh*t happened and you gotta clean it all up.
samples.output:
They never tell you what happens after the world ends. The movies, the books, the fever dreams of conspiracy theorists—none of them ever get it right. When the bombs stop falling, when the sky stops screaming, when the last of the monsters slink back into their holes or die twitching in the dust, someone’s gotta pick up the pieces.

That’s me. The janitor of the apocalypse.

I don’t wear a cape. I don’t carry a gun unless I have to. Most days, it’s just me, a reinforced hazmat suit, a jury-rigged utility belt, and my cart—custom-built, thank you very much, with compartments for everything from radiation-neutralizing spray to demon ichor neutralizer. You’d be surprised how often you need both.

The name’s Edgar. Just Edgar. Last names don’t matter much these days. Not when governments have been reduced to smoldering craters and the only law left is the one you can enforce yourself. I used to work maintenance for a biotech firm. One of those faceless, monolithic companies that may or may not have had a hand in the whole mess. Not that it matters anymore. When the sky cracked open and the oceans boiled and the dead started walking, nobody cared who filed the right paperwork. They just ran, screamed, or died.

Or all three.

But me? I stayed behind. Someone had to.

It started with cleanup crews. Emergency response units, UN task forces, private contractors with more money than sense. They tried to contain it, to patch the holes in reality with duct tape and optimism. Didn’t last. The ones that didn’t get eaten, irradiated, or possessed eventually gave up and disappeared into whatever shadows were left.

Except me.

When the last official crew pulled out of New Chicago, I stayed behind. The city was a mess—whole districts reduced to rubble, strange fungal growths spreading like cancer over the ruins, and something in the sewers that whispered at night. But someone had to keep the streets passable. Someone had to clear out the corpses before they started moving again.

I became that someone.

It's not glamorous work. I spend most of my days hauling debris, scrubbing blood off walls, and decontaminating areas that smell like a bad dream. Sometimes I find survivors—holed up in basements, half-mad from solitary confinement and fear. I help them if I can. Give them directions to the last known safe zones, leave them with supplies if I’ve got any extra. But I don’t stay. I don’t have time to rebuild society. My job is to clean the stage so someone else can.

The worst part? The things that linger.

You ever scrub a wall where a soul burned itself into the concrete? You ever try to mop up something that keeps whispering your name, even after it’s been reduced to ash and bone? I have. Dozens of times. There are stains that don’t wash out, no matter how hard you scrub. You just cover them up with tarps and hope they don’t start glowing again.

People talk about the end of the world like it’s a single event. One big bang, one final scream. But the truth is, it ends in pieces. A thousand tiny collapses. A city here, a species there. A language lost. A myth reborn. And for each collapse, there’s a mess. And for each mess, there’s me.

Last week, I made my way through the remains of what used to be Portland. The air still tasted like burnt pine and ozone. A rift had opened there—some kind of dimensional tear. The locals had called it “The Maw.” Half the city had vanished into it before it finally sealed. The rest was unstable, filled with echoes and flickers—ghosts of moments that hadn’t happened yet. I spent three days clearing out the temporal debris. Had to fight off a version of myself from a timeline where I didn’t make it out of Detroit. Tough bastard. Still limping from that one.

But I got the job done.

I always do.

There’s a rhythm to it now. Wake up, gear up, roll out. Identify the threat. Neutralize it if possible. Contain it if not. Sanitize the area. Move on. Sometimes I leave behind signs—chalk marks, coded symbols, little notes for whoever comes next. “Safe for now.” “Avoid after sundown.” “Don’t listen to the mirrors.”

Sometimes I wonder who I’m leaving them for.

There are others like me, I think. Scattered across the ruins. People who didn’t sign up for this but kept going anyway. I caught a glimpse of one once—a woman in a tattered firefighter’s uniform, dragging a flame-thrower through the remains of a haunted suburb in Ohio. We nodded at each other, then moved on. No time for talk. Too much to do.

The world isn’t healing. Not yet. But it’s not dying either. Not completely. There are sparks. Little pockets of green. A community garden growing in the shell of an old stadium. Kids laughing as they chase mutated squirrels, their laughter somehow still pure. A preacher giving sermons to empty pews, just in case something is still listening.

Those sparks give me hope. Not much. But enough.

Because maybe, just maybe, when the last of the mess is cleaned up, when the final breach is sealed and the last ghoul put to rest, someone will come in and build something new. Something better. And when they do, I’ll be there. Sweeping up the dust. Making sure the foundation is clean.

Until then, I keep moving.

Today, I’ve got a report of anomalous activity down in the old subway tunnels beneath what used to be Atlanta. Something’s pulsing down there, sending out waves of static and sorrow. Could be an artifact. Could be a nest. Could be something new entirely.

Doesn’t matter.

I’ll go in. I’ll clean it up.

Because I’m the janitor of the apocalypse.

And somebody’s gotta do the dirty work.

samples.prompt: It turns out that werewolves and vampires can look at an eldritch abomination without going insane, resulting in these two species becoming humanity's guardians against cosmic horrors.
samples.output:
For centuries, humanity has whispered of the monsters that stalk the night—werewolves with their savage howls under moonlit skies, vampires with their cold, predatory grace and thirst for blood. These beings, the stuff of nightmares and folklore, have been feared, hunted, and shunned. But the world has changed. Behind the veil of reality, ancient and incomprehensible forces stir—eldritch abominations that defy logic, sanity, and description. And when these horrors breach the boundaries of our universe, it is not our armies or our scientists who stand against them. It is the very creatures we once reviled who now fight for our survival.

The first incursion was brief, but unforgettable. A tear in the fabric of space opened above the city of Prague, and from it spilled a creature that could not be named. Its form shifted with every glance, a kaleidoscope of writhing limbs, eyes, and mouths that spoke in a language no human could hear without bleeding from the ears. The military was powerless. Those who looked upon the creature went mad instantly, clawing at their own eyes or falling into endless catatonia. The streets ran red that day, not from the creature’s malice, but from the sheer impossibility of its existence.

And then came the wolves.

From the forests and the forgotten places, they arrived. Not bound by the moon, as the myths claimed, but by ancient pacts and instincts deeper than blood. Werewolves, their bodies immense and fur matted with centuries of unspoken battles, tore into the abomination with a fury unmatched. Their minds, primal and anchored to a more instinctual understanding of the world, did not crack beneath the weight of the creature’s presence. They fought not as men, but as forces of nature—untamed, unyielding, unafraid.

With them came the vampires—elegant, precise, and cold as the grave. Their immortality lent them perspective, their detachment from humanity gave them resistance. While humans saw madness, vampires saw patterns, symmetries in the chaos that allowed them to act. They moved through the battlefield like shadows, striking with surgical precision. Their minds, honed over centuries of navigating the human condition from the outside, proved resilient to the mind-breaking truths the creature radiated.

Together, the two ancient species drove the abomination back through the tear, sealing it with blood and ritual, with knowledge long forgotten by mankind. And in the aftermath, they revealed themselves—not as monsters, but as guardians.

The truth, as it came to light, was staggering. Werewolves and vampires had known of the cosmic horrors for millennia. In the darkest corners of the Earth, where no human dared tread, they had stood vigil. The myths of monstrous beasts in the woods, of noble yet terrifying figures in castles and ruins—these were not warnings, but signs. Markers of territory. Wards against deeper darkness.

Their immunity to the madness of the eldritch was not coincidence. It was evolution—divergent paths from humanity that had, over time, rendered their minds alien enough to withstand the truths that would shatter human comprehension. Werewolves, grounded in the physical and the immediate, lacked the abstract cognition that made humans so vulnerable. Vampires, with their dispassionate detachment and centuries of accumulated knowledge, had learned to compartmentalize, to shield the psyche from what should not be known.

Humanity, at last, saw them not as predators, but as protectors.

The world adapted. Secret accords were signed. Governments, once sworn to eradicate the supernatural, now worked in uneasy alliance with covens and packs. Cities had their own guardians—vampiric enclaves hidden in catacombs, werewolf clans patrolling the wilderness. The old, bitter rivalries between the two species were set aside in the face of a greater threat. They became humanity’s sword and shield against the cosmos.

But not all was harmonious.

There were schisms, as there always are. Some vampires saw their newfound legitimacy as a path to dominance, not service. Some werewolves, long used to isolation, chafed under the scrutiny of human allies. And among humans, fear still lingered. Ancient prejudices do not vanish overnight, and many questioned whether they had merely traded one monster for another.

But the eldritch horrors did not wait for consensus. They came again and again—through rifts in reality, through cults that worshipped the stars, through relics unearthed by curious archaeologists. And each time, the werewolves and vampires stood between the madness and mankind.

There were losses. Brave wolves who tore themselves apart to drag a horror back into the void. Vampires who spent decades studying forbidden texts to find a single incantation, only to be consumed by the knowledge they acquired. But they did not waver. They could not afford to.

In time, humanity began to understand. Not all of the supernatural was evil. Some of it was necessary. Some of it was protective. A new mythology emerged, one not of fear, but of partnership. Children no longer feared the wolf in the woods—they left offerings at the forest’s edge. In cities, the old cathedrals and opera houses became neutral grounds, places where humans and vampires could meet without pretense. The world, so long divided by fear, began to heal.

And yet, the greatest threat was still to come.

The stars were aligning. The old ones, whose names had not been spoken for eons, stirred in their slumber. The eldritch abominations had been testing the boundaries of reality—but soon, they would push through. The werewolves sharpened their claws. The vampires dusted off tomes bound in skin. Humanity, for the first time, stood alongside them, not behind.

In this strange new world, the monsters of old had become the last hope for sanity, for survival. The howls in the night were no longer warnings—they were signals. The flicker of red eyes in the darkness was not a threat, but a promise.

A promise that when the veil tore again, and the stars bled their madness into the world, someone would be there to fight back.

And they would not fight alone.

samples.prompt: The most powerful civilization in the universe does not have CGI - and cower in fear when an unsuspecting scout finds a human satellite laden with pop culture hits.
samples.output:
In the farthest reaches of the cosmos, where galaxies churn like ancient whirlpools and stars burn in colors no human eye has seen, there exists a civilization so advanced, so impossibly vast in intellect and capability, that the mere notion of limitation had long since vanished from their collective consciousness. They were known across the starfields as the Virellians, and to encounter them was to witness the full splendor of technological divinity. They could manipulate gravity as a child might twist a ribbon, bend time in localized pockets, and communicate across light-years with nothing more than a thought. They had outgrown war, transcended hunger, and dismantled death itself. Yet, for all their omnipotence, there was one thing they did not have: CGI.

To the Virellians, simulation was unnecessary. Their reality was so richly constructed, their minds so evolved, that imagination and experience were indistinguishable. Art was sculpted from solar flares, poetry etched into the orbits of moons. They had no need for artificial visuals when entire worlds could be shaped on whims. The concept of computer-generated imagery—of creating illusions of dragons, spaceships, or superheroes through technological trickery—was not only foreign to them, it was incomprehensible. Why fake what you can simply create?

So when one of their exploratory probes, sent to catalog the flotsam of a distant spiral arm, intercepted a peculiar object orbiting a small, blue-green planet, the event was marked as a curiosity rather than a discovery. The object was primitive, barely clinging to the edge of functionality. It emitted low-frequency electromagnetic signals and bore a golden disc etched with archaic symbols and audio samples. The Virellians, intrigued by the notion that such a crude artifact had been cast into the void, decrypted the contents with ease.

The probe’s central intelligence, a sentient algorithm named Xelth 9, began to process the data. It played the sounds—greetings in dozens of human languages, the laughter of children, the roar of thunder, the gentle strumming of a guitar. It found them quaint, evocative of a species still tethered to its senses. Then it began to access the visual media stored on the satellite’s auxiliary archive, a hidden cache of cultural treasures: film clips, television shows, music videos, and animated shorts. It began with something seemingly innocent—an excerpt from “Fantasia.”

What followed was, in Virellian terms, catastrophic.

The swirl of colors, the dancing brooms, the orchestral crescendo paired with surging waves of animated motion—this was not mere imagery. To a being unacquainted with the concept of CGI, it was madness. It was magic.

Xelth 9 paused the playback. It recalibrated, ran diagnostics, and restarted the sequence using higher processing protocols. But as it watched more—scenes from “Jurassic Park,” “The Matrix,” “Avengers: Endgame”—its logic matrices began to spiral. How had this primitive species created such lifelike illusions? How had they captured beings of immense power, impossible physics, and entire imagined worlds—without those things actually being real?

To the Virellians, there were only two explanations. One: Humans had found a way to manipulate reality itself, conjuring simulated universes indistinguishable from truth. Or two: Humans had access to an unthinkable form of sorcery, one that spun entire galaxies from the confines of their minds and projected them into being.

Either possibility was terrifying.

Xelth 9 transmitted the data back to the Virellian High Cognition Assembly, where the files were analyzed, dissected, and ultimately feared. The Assembly’s reaction was immediate and unified: Earth was to be avoided. No further probes were to be sent. Any civilization that could so seamlessly manipulate the fabric of visual reality was not to be trifled with.

“It is not the power they wield,” said High Arbiter Volex-Na, her voice echoing through the neural lattice, “but the mystery of their restraint. What force compels them to contain such power within audio-visual constructs? Why do they not use it to dominate their world—or ours?”

This was the true horror. The Virellians had long assumed that as civilizations advanced, they shed their illusions. But here was evidence to the contrary—a world where illusion had been weaponized into art, where imagination was not a fading ember but a roaring blaze. The humans, in their primitive brilliance, had found a way to render gods, monsters, and impossible battles with nothing but pixels and soundwaves. And they did it for entertainment.

In the minds of the Virellians, this made humanity the most dangerous species in the known universe.

A council was convened to determine the appropriate course of action. Some argued for containment, others for deeper surveillance. But the prevailing sentiment was fear—raw, unfiltered fear. The Virellians, who had stared into the heart of black holes and conversed with sentient quasars, now trembled at the thought of a species that imagined its nightmares and dreams into being for the mere price of a movie ticket.

They watched footage of a man in a cape lifting a city into the sky, of another wielding a glowing sword against a masked adversary in a galaxy far, far away. They saw animated beings sing of love and freedom, digital landscapes of impossible beauty, and narratives that spanned millennia within a two-hour runtime. And they could not tell what was real.

They called it the “Illusion Singularity”—the point at which simulation becomes indistinguishable from reality. The humans had achieved it through storytelling, through CGI, through sheer audacity.

And so the Virellians, the most powerful civilization in the universe, amended their cosmic charts. Earth was marked not as a target, nor a potential ally, but as a quarantine zone. No ships were to approach. No signals were to be sent. Their star maps now bore a single warning near the Sol system, written in their most sacred dialect:

“Here dwell the Dream-Makers. Beware their vision.”

Back on Earth, the satellite continued its lonely journey, drifting past Neptune and into deeper space, humming softly with the encoded echoes of humanity’s dreams. Somewhere in a darkened theater, a child watched a spaceship streak across a starlit sky, unaware that the same image had sent an alien empire into hiding.

And perhaps, someday, when the Virellians have mustered enough courage—or curiosity—they will return. Perhaps they will try to understand the strange magic of pixels and stories. But until then, they will remain distant, peering with reverent dread at the one species that dared to dream so vividly, it frightened the stars themselves.

samples.prompt: You doze off while stargazing only to awake to a now starless night sky. You look around and see dots of light floating around. They appear to be connecting to one another, forming lines. You are now in the presence of the Constellations.
samples.output:
It had been the perfect night for stargazing—clear skies, a soft breeze, and the kind of quiet only found far from city lights. I had driven up the winding road to the overlook, a place I’d visited countless times before, always seeking the solace of the stars. I brought my old telescope, a thermos of coffee, and a blanket to keep out the chill. Lying on the grass, peering up into the heavens, I had traced the familiar patterns—Orion, Cassiopeia, Ursa Major. The constellations were old friends, stories written in light, stretching across the firmament.

Somewhere in those hours, lulled by the hushed whisper of wind through the trees, the warmth of the blanket, and the hypnotic glow of the stars, I drifted off.

When I awoke, something was wrong. The sky was black—not the deep purple-black of night, but a void, empty and absolute. Not a single star twinkled above. The Milky Way had vanished, the moon was gone, and even the faint glow of distant planets had disappeared. It was as though someone had drawn a curtain across the universe. I sat up quickly, heart pounding, the remnants of sleep falling away like dust shaken from an old book.

Then I noticed them—small, glowing points of light drifting around me. They hovered a few feet above the ground, pulsing gently, as if breathing. I reached out toward one, and it darted away playfully before settling again. More dots began to appear, spreading in all directions, each one joining with others, lines of golden light tracing between them. The lines shimmered, forming shapes that danced and shifted in the air.

I stood, transfixed, as the night began to come alive.

A figure emerged from the web of light—a tall, imposing man draped in a robe of shimmering silver, a belt of three bright lights across his waist. Orion. His bow was slung over one shoulder, and his eyes, bright as twin suns, gazed at me with an intensity that made me shiver. Behind him came others—Cassiopeia, regal and proud, her hair a cascade of stars; Andromeda, delicate and radiant; Leo, a great lion formed of burning light, his mane a halo of fire. They stepped from the lines of stars, transforming from constellations into beings of light and shape, each more magnificent than the last.

I was surrounded.

They didn’t speak at first. Instead, they regarded me with curiosity, like ancient beings examining a newly discovered creature. I felt small beneath their gaze, as if my very soul had been laid bare. Finally, Orion stepped forward.

"You see us," he said, his voice both thunder and whisper, echoing through the clearing.

"I… I think so," I stammered. "Where are the stars?"

Orion looked up at the empty sky. "We have come down. For the first time in millennia, we walk the Earth again."

"Why now?"

Cassiopeia’s voice was like the rustling of silk, smooth and commanding. "Because the world is forgetting."

"The stories," Andromeda added softly. "The myths. The names that once gave us shape and purpose. They are fading."

I swallowed hard. "But people still look up. They still see you."

Leo growled, a low rumble that shook the ground. "They see lights, not legends. They navigate by us but do not remember who we are. The tales that gave us form are dying, and with them, so are we."

I looked around at the glowing beings—the Constellations—each one a living embodiment of myth and memory. I thought of the nights I’d spent identifying them, the stories I had read as a child, the way I had whispered their names like prayers into the night. Had that kept them alive? Was that enough?

"Why me?" I asked. "Why show yourselves to me?"

"You remember," said Orion. "You speak our names with reverence. That is rare."

"And now, you must help us," Cassiopeia said. "Before we vanish forever."

I was about to ask how when the lines of light around us began to flicker. A sense of urgency filled the air. The constellations looked upward, and I followed their gaze. The sky remained dark, but now it pulsed faintly, as if trying to rekindle its lost light.

"The stories must be told," Andromeda said. "Not just remembered, but shared. Passed on."

"Speak of us," Leo growled. "Write, draw, sing. Let the world know we are still here."

I nodded, heart pounding. "I will."

The Constellations began to step back, the lines connecting them unraveling like threads in the wind. One by one, they dissolved into the dots of light, which rose slowly into the sky. Orion was the last to go. He placed a hand on my shoulder, and though he was made of stars, his touch was warm.

"Do not let us be forgotten."

Then he, too, faded, the three stars of his belt the last to vanish into the void. As they rose higher, the darkness began to lift. One by one, the stars returned, flickering back into existence. The moon reappeared, casting a soft glow over the clearing. The night sky was once again whole, the constellations back in their places, their stories hidden among the stars.

I stood alone, the echo of their presence still humming in the air. My telescope lay forgotten at my feet, the blanket damp with dew. But something had changed in me. I had seen the Constellations, not as patterns in the sky, but as beings of ancient power and deep longing. They needed us as much as we once needed them.

And so I returned home, and I wrote.

I wrote of Orion’s unwavering strength, of Cassiopeia’s pride and grace, of Andromeda’s quiet courage and Leo’s noble roar. I shared their stories, retold their myths, breathed life back into the legends. I taught others to look up and see not just stars, but characters in an eternal play, etching their roles across the heavens.

And every night, I return to that overlook, gaze into the sky, and whisper their names.

Because I remember.

Because they asked.

samples.prompt: Humans figured out in the future that mothernature was slowly killing the human race by evolving viruses and climate change. You are the last human to be alived.
samples.output:
I remember when the sky still had color.

It used to be blue — a radiant, endless blue that stretched over cities, forests, and oceans. Now, it’s a heavy, ashen gray, thick with the weight of smoke and dust. I’ve stopped checking the calendar. Time doesn’t mean much anymore when you’re the last of your kind. The days blur together, marked only by the quiet hum of my solar generator and the low, constant groan of wind over abandoned buildings. I keep a journal, though. Not because I expect anyone to read it, but because words are the last thing I have left that make me feel human.

They say it started with the viruses. We thought we were so clever — building our cities, our global networks, our medicine. But Mother Nature is older than us. Wiser. Patient. She doesn’t rage; she waits. And she learns. The first wave of viral mutations hit in 2087. Scientists called them "adaptive pathogens." They weren’t engineered, not by us. The Earth did it herself. Viruses that could change within days, sometimes hours, to bypass vaccines and immune systems. The death toll was staggering, but we still thought we could fight it. We always believed we were at war with nature, and in war, humans win — or so we thought.

By 2095, the world had changed. The climate had become as unpredictable and vengeful as the viruses. Oceans rose faster than any model predicted. Cities drowned: New York, Mumbai, Bangkok, Lagos — all gone beneath the waves. Wildfires burned across continents like they were chasing something. Maybe they were. Maybe they were chasing us. Crops failed. Droughts lasted years. Storms became monsters. And through it all, the viruses kept evolving, growing more cunning, more selective.

Some believed nature was retaliating. Others said it wasn’t vengeance — it was balance. Earth was correcting an imbalance, like a body fighting off an infection. And we were the infection.

I used to be a microbiologist. My work was in a lab in what used to be Vancouver, studying viral genomes. I watched the mutations, catalogued them, tried to find patterns. But the patterns didn’t follow any rules we knew. They were chaotic, like jazz played by a mind centuries older than ours. I remember sitting in front of my microscope, looking at a strand of RNA that had changed three times in a single culture. At that moment, I realized we weren’t fighting a disease. We were being outclassed by nature itself.

Humanity didn’t go out in a blaze. It was more like a long, slow breath, exhaled over decades. The last governments collapsed around 2110. There were some underground cities, some sealed ecological bunkers. I was in one of them, buried deep beneath what was once the Rockies. We had food, light, technology — and for a time, hope. But you can’t live forever underground. Systems fail. People break. And the viruses found their way in, no matter how many filters we used.

I am the last because I was immune — or at least resistant enough. My DNA has some quirk, some rare sequence that kept the worst at bay. Ironically, we spent years trying to find a vaccine using my blood. But by then, the viruses had diversified so much that no single solution worked. They didn’t just kill — they adapted. They didn’t want us dead quickly. They wanted us destabilized.

I left the bunker five years ago, when the others were gone. I scavenged what I could. Found this old cabin in what used to be northern Montana. It’s high enough to avoid the worst of the floods, remote enough that the fires rarely reach it. I’ve made a life here, if you can call it that. Solar panels, a greenhouse, a drone that still works some days. I talk to myself more than I should. Sometimes I imagine I hear voices in the wind — echoes of a species that once covered the Earth like vines.

The strangest part is that the planet is healing. The air, though heavy with smoke, is cleaner than it’s been in decades. The forests are regrowing. Animals, some thought extinct, have returned. I saw a herd of bison last week. Real bison. Birds I can’t even name sing in the mornings. The Earth is coming back to life, as if she’s sighing in relief.

And I wonder: was this always the plan? Not a punishment, but a course correction? We thought we were stewards of the planet, but maybe we were the fever. Maybe Earth had to break us to heal herself. Maybe evolution was never about us alone, but about everything surviving together. And we failed that test.

Still, I don’t hate her. How could I? The same forces that wiped out my species also carved mountains, filled rivers, painted sunsets. Nature is not cruel — she is indifferent. And in that indifference, there is a kind of wisdom. A terrible, beautiful wisdom.

I’ve started to leave things behind — not just journals, but stories, thoughts, bits of culture. I carved a poem into a stone near the cabin. I left a USB drive in a waterproof capsule inside a hollow tree. Maybe someone — or something — will find them one day. Maybe the next intelligent species will rise and wonder who we were. Maybe they’ll read my words and understand.

I sometimes dream of a child — not mine, but human. A child walking along a beach not yet swallowed by the sea, picking up shells, asking questions. I know it’s just a dream. But it comforts me.

I am the last human alive. The final echo of a species that touched the stars, then burned its wings. But I am not bitter. I am witness. I am memory. And in that, perhaps, I am still part of the Earth’s story.

When I go — and I know it won’t be long now — there will be no funeral, no eulogies. Just silence. And maybe that’s fitting.

Because in the end, we weren’t the masters of nature. We were just guests.

And our time is over.

samples.prompt: The UK is being battered by a major storm. Write the story of someone desperately trying to make it home from work during the chaos.
samples.output:
Rain lashed against the windows of the office like a relentless tide, blurring the world beyond into a smudged watercolor of grey and black. Olivia stared out at the storm, her reflection ghostly in the glass, and clutched her coat tighter around her shoulders. The wind howled like a wounded animal, rattling the panes and sending a chill down her spine. She checked her phone again—no new messages. The last train home was still scheduled, but that could change any minute.

She had stayed late at the office in central London, trying to finish a report for her manager, believing foolishly that the storm would pass quickly. It hadn’t. If anything, it had grown angrier with each passing hour. Now, as the clock neared 7 p.m., the streets outside were nearly deserted, save for the occasional bus crawling through the floodwaters and the brave—or foolish—souls scurrying under broken umbrellas.

Her flat was in Croydon, a good hour and a half commute on a normal day. But tonight was anything but normal.

With a determined sigh, Olivia grabbed her bag, pulled up her hood, and stepped into the storm.

The wind hit her like a solid wall, nearly knocking her off her feet. She staggered forward, fighting against the gale, her boots splashing through puddles that had grown into mini-lakes. The streets were slick and glistening, the water reflecting the flickering streetlights like shards of glass. Debris flew in every direction—plastic bags, leaves, even a broken signpost clattering down the pavement.

She made it to the Underground station at Oxford Circus, soaked through and shivering. Inside, the air was warmer but thick with tension. Commuters stood huddled in clusters, eyes fixed on the departure boards. Red lights blinked like warning signals.

“All southbound services delayed due to flooding on the tracks,” a mechanical voice droned over the tannoy.

Olivia clenched her jaw. She considered her options. She could wait it out, but there was no telling when the trains would move again. Or she could try her luck above ground.

She took the escalator back up, her phone buzzing with updates from the news: “Storm Elara continues to wreak havoc across the UK. Winds reaching 80mph. Severe flooding reported in multiple boroughs.”

Outside, the storm had somehow grown worse. Lightning sliced across the sky, illuminating the twisted silhouettes of trees bowing under the wind’s fury. She pulled her coat tighter and started walking, hoping to catch a bus or a cab—anything that would get her closer to home.

She reached a bus stop on Regent Street and waited, water dripping from her hood. A man beside her lit a cigarette with shaking hands, the flame nearly extinguished by the wind.

“Where you headed?” he asked, eyes squinting against the rain.

“Croydon,” she replied.

He let out a low whistle. “Good luck. Most of the roads south are flooded. I heard they’ve closed the A23.”

Olivia’s heart sank. But she couldn’t just stay there. She couldn’t sleep in her office, and the idea of a hotel was out of the question—everything would be booked, and she didn’t have the money for it anyway.

Then she saw it—a lone black cab turning onto the street, headlights piercing the darkness like beacons. She waved frantically, stepping into the street. The driver hesitated, then pulled over.

“Croydon?” she asked, breathless.

“You serious?” the driver said, eyebrows raised. “That’s a long way in this mess.”

“I’ll pay whatever it takes.”

He looked at her for a moment, then nodded. “Alright. Get in.”

The warmth of the cab was a small mercy. She sank into the seat, water pooling at her feet, and watched the city slide by in chaotic fragments. Streets turned into rivers, traffic lights blinked uselessly as cars swerved around abandoned vehicles. Sirens wailed in the distance—ambulances, fire engines, perhaps the police trying to manage the growing crisis.

They made their way south, inch by inch. The driver, a man named Simon, kept the radio on low, tuned to a station offering updates on the storm.

“Never seen anything like this,” he muttered. “Not since that storm back in ‘87.”

Olivia nodded, though she wasn’t old enough to remember that. Trees lay across roads like fallen giants, their limbs twisted and broken. At one point, a power line had come down, crackling dangerously across the pavement. They had to turn back and find another route.

Progress was slow. At times, the cab floated more than rolled through the waterlogged streets. Olivia’s nerves were frayed, her hands clenched in her lap. Her phone’s battery was dying, and she had no charger. Each minute felt like an hour.

Then, just as they reached the outskirts of Croydon, the engine sputtered.

“No, no, no,” Simon groaned, pulling over. “Water’s got into the engine.”

Olivia stared in disbelief. They were so close. Maybe two miles from her street.

“I have to walk,” she said.

“You sure? It’s dangerous out there.”

She nodded. “I have to get home.”

She paid him what she could and stepped back into the storm. The rain was relentless, but she no longer felt it. All she could think about was her tiny flat, the warm light in the hallway, the soft quilt on her bed.

Her neighborhood was unrecognizable. The streetlights flickered or were completely out. Her boots filled with water as she trudged through ankle-deep puddles. A tree had fallen across the road near her building, its branches tangled in power lines that sparked ominously.

But then—there it was. Her building, looming in the darkness like a promise.

She climbed the steps, fumbling with her keys, heart pounding. The door stuck for a moment, swollen from the damp, but then it gave way.

Inside, the silence was deafening. No electricity. Everything cloaked in shadow. She used the last light of her dying phone to find her way up the stairs, each step a victory.

When she opened the door to her flat, a wave of relief crashed over her. She was home. She kicked off her soaked boots, peeled off her sodden coat, and collapsed onto the couch in the dark. Her body ached, her clothes clung to her skin, but she didn’t care.

Outside, the storm howled on, but inside, she was safe. She had made it.

samples.prompt: "God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space."
samples.output:
God is dead, imprisoned in the far reaches of space.

It is not a proclamation made with joy, nor one whispered in rebellion. It is a truth now accepted by those who have seen the stars and returned changed. The divine presence that once hovered above human hearts, that once stirred prophets to madness and comforted the dying with visions of eternity, has been located, confirmed, and—most tragically—silenced.

It began with the telescopes.

They were the eyes of a species desperate to know its place in the cosmos. For centuries, humans had peered into the night sky, searching for signs of meaning, of life, of God. As technology advanced, their eyes sharpened. They saw farther. They saw clearer. They mapped galaxies and measured the flickers of distant suns as if they were counting the syllables in a sacred hymn.

Then they found it.

It was not a planet or a star or a nebula, but a structure—massive, ancient, and unmistakably unnatural—drifting at the edge of the observable universe. It pulsed faintly, emitting frequencies that danced between cosmic background radiation and something eerily similar to a heartbeat. At first, it was thought to be a remnant of an ancient civilization, a god-machine left abandoned by some race long gone. But as the data streamed in, interpretations shifted. The pattern of the pulses, the gravitational anomalies, the inexplicable gravitational pull it exerted on nearby matter—it all suggested something else.

Something alive.

Theologians, scientists, and politicians gathered in secret. The Vatican sent its astronomers. The United Nations convened under an emergency council. The world watched as probes were launched. Decades passed as the first unmanned scouts reached the structure. What they transmitted back defied analysis. Images of impossible geometries, sounds that induced hallucinations in those who listened too long, and data that seemed to rewrite itself while being recorded.

And then came the revelation: the structure was not merely alive. It was God. Or rather, what humanity had always conceptualized as God—an entity beyond time and matter, now trapped, bound by forces unknown.

There was no voice from the heavens, no thunderous declaration, no burning bush. Only a cold, distant confirmation that the divine had not abandoned humanity, but had itself been imprisoned, exiled to the far edge of existence like a forgotten prisoner in a cosmic oubliette.

The implications were profound.

The first reaction was disbelief. Religious institutions fractured. Some clung to doctrines, reinterpreting the data as trials of faith. Others declared the death of theology. What was prayer if God could not hear? What was sin if there was no judgment? For many, morality unraveled. For others, it became more urgent—a self-imposed discipline in the absence of divine authority.

A new philosophical movement arose: Theocrypticism. Its adherents believed that God had been shackled by an ancient force—perhaps another divine being, or the universe itself rebelling against its creator. To them, humanity’s purpose was clear: to free God. They saw themselves not as worshipers, but as liberators. Monasteries became laboratories, temples became command centers.

Meanwhile, the world changed.

Without a divine presence—without even the possibility of divine intervention—humanity faced itself in a mirror more honest than ever before. Wars ended, not because peace was divinely ordained, but because the cost of conflict could no longer be justified by the promise of an afterlife. Environmentalism surged, not because Earth was a sacred trust, but because it was all that remained. In some ways, the absence of God became a catalyst for a deeper, more responsible humanism.

But not all were so noble.
