Instead, they sought to simulate dreams—to create a machine that could mimic the psychological function of dreaming, offering users a nightly immersion in a computer-generated unconscious. It was the birth of the Dream Engine, a virtual reality that tapped into memories, emotions, and random neural firing to create personalized dreamscapes.

But while the machine was promising, it lacked the spontaneity of organic dreaming. Users often described the experience as vivid, but hollow. Like walking through a museum of someone else's imagination. The soul of dreaming, it seemed, could not be engineered.

And so humanity stood at the edge of its greatest paradox. It had gained more hours, more clarity, more control than ever before. But it had lost something unquantifiable—a portal to the subconscious, a bridge to the mythic, a nightly voyage through the uncharted territories of the mind.

The Nocturne Pill had given the world the gift of wakefulness. But in doing so, it had silenced the dreamers.

samples.prompt: You wake up one morning, only to realise you are an inanimate object and your human self is gone.
samples.output:
I woke up to silence. Not the comfortable, sleepy silence of early morning, nor the stillness of a quiet room — this was an unnatural kind of silence, one that seemed to press in from all directions, heavy and complete. I tried to blink, but nothing happened. I tried to stretch, but there were no limbs to move. Panic flared. I wanted to sit up, to rub my eyes, to groan and complain like I always did after a bad night’s sleep. But none of that was possible.

That’s when the realization hit me: I wasn’t human anymore.

I didn’t know how I knew — it wasn’t like I could look down and see myself, since I no longer had eyes. But there was a kind of strange, internal awareness that I wasn’t in a body. I wasn’t even alive in the traditional sense. Everything felt different. Duller. Slower. And then I began to sense things in a way I couldn’t explain — vibrations, perhaps. Not sound exactly, but the subtle hum of activity in the space around me.

Somewhere nearby, I heard — or rather felt — footsteps. A pair of them, moving across what I guessed was a wooden floor. There was a jostling of air. Then a voice.

“Where did I put my keys?” said a familiar voice.

It was my voice.

Only… it wasn’t coming from me.

That’s when the full, horrifying truth began to crystallize. I wasn’t just not myself — someone else was me. Someone else was using my voice, my body, my life. And I was… something else. Something in the room. I tried to think, to remember what happened. Had I made some kind of deal? Had I died and come back wrong? Was this a dream?

I focused, trying to understand what I had become. I could feel the weight of myself pressing down, grounded. I wasn’t soft or flexible. I was cold. Hard. Stationary. I couldn’t move, but I could feel — not like skin feels, but in a strange, ambient way. I could tell that I was small enough to be held, but solid and heavy. I had a smooth surface in some places, and in others, ridges. There was a faint metallic tang to my being.

It took time, maybe minutes or maybe hours — time felt different now — but I finally understood: I was a coffee mug.

A coffee mug.

Of all the things in the world I could have become, I had to end up as a ceramic cylinder with a handle, sitting on my own former kitchen counter.

And worst of all, I could see — or sense — myself walking around in my old body, scratching my head, yawning, completely unaware that the real me was now an inanimate object destined to be filled with lukewarm caffeine.

My body — the imposter — finally spotted me. Him. The mug. Me.

“There you are,” he said, picking me up.

The sensation was jarring. Being lifted was less like flying and more like being torn from the universe, like the laws of physics had suddenly stopped applying, and I was a leaf in a storm. I spun slightly as he carried me, and I could feel every jostle, every bump along the way to the coffee maker.

Then came the worst part.

He poured hot liquid into me. Scalding, dark, bitter coffee. The heat seeped into my being, and while I couldn’t feel pain exactly, the discomfort was overwhelming. I wanted to scream, to tell him to stop, to tell him that I was in here — that I was the mug. But I had no mouth, no voice, no way to communicate.

I was trapped.

And so, I sat. On the desk. On the coaster I had once bought myself on a whim during a trip to the mountains. Now, I was just a mug, slowly cooling, as the imposter sipped from me and scrolled through social media on my former phone.

Hours passed. He went about my life — working from home, answering emails, ordering lunch. I watched it all. I listened to him talk to coworkers on Zoom, using my voice, my expressions, my tone of casual sarcasm. It was eerie how perfectly he had stepped into my life. If I didn’t know better, I would have thought he was me.

But I knew better.

I was starting to understand the limits of my existence. I couldn’t move, couldn’t speak, couldn’t sleep. But I could think. And I could feel things in a strange, abstract way — pressure, temperature, vibrations. And I could remember. I had all my memories intact. My childhood, my first kiss, my favorite book, the way my mother used to hum while cooking. All of it was still there. But none of it mattered anymore.

The days blended together. I was washed, dried, reused. Sometimes I got to sit in the dishwasher, which was oddly soothing — like a spa day, if spas involved boiling water and detergent. Other times, I was left on the desk for days, collecting dust and the occasional splash of leftover coffee.

I started to think about what made me human in the first place. Was it my body? Clearly not, because someone else had it now. Was it my consciousness? If so, then I was still me — just trapped in a form that didn’t allow for expression or movement. Was that enough? Was I still a person if no one knew I existed?

Loneliness settled in like a fog. I missed talking. I missed music. I missed the feeling of wind on my face and the taste of food. I missed being able to laugh at stupid memes and cry at sad movies. I missed being alive.

But time passed, and I adapted. I began to notice the small things. The way the sunlight would warm one side of me in the morning. The rhythm of the rain on the window. The quiet companionship of the other mugs in the cabinet. They didn’t speak, not in words, but I felt their presence, their long, slow awareness.

And then one day, something changed.

The imposter picked me up, then paused. He looked at me — really looked — as if something inside him shifted. He turned me in his hands, frowning slightly.

“This mug,” he murmured. “Feels… different.”

I wanted to scream, “Yes! Yes, it’s me! I’m in here!”

But he just shrugged and set me back down.

Still, it gave me hope.

Maybe some part of him knew. Maybe one day, he’d figure it out. Maybe I’d be freed.

Or maybe not. Maybe I’d spend the rest of eternity as a mug, watching life happen around me, unable to participate.

But for now, I existed. I thought. I remembered.

And that was something.

samples.prompt: "Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?"Her eyes swiveled to mine in panic and her eyes flashed golden briefly, and asked with a shocked and slightly apprehensive expression "How did you know about that?"
samples.output:
“Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?” I asked with a teasing smile, the kind of cheesy pick-up line that usually gets an eye-roll or, if I’m lucky, a laugh. I was half-joking, half-flirting, but mostly trying to break the awkward silence that had settled between us. We were sitting across from each other in the dim corner of a quiet café, the low hum of conversation around us, a half-empty cup of coffee cooling between my hands.

But then something happened that I didn’t expect.

Her eyes—normally a soft, earthy brown—swiveled to mine with sudden intensity. Panic surged across her face, her pupils dilating. For the briefest moment, a shimmer of gold flashed across her irises, like sunlight catching polished metal. It was so quick I might have thought I imagined it, but the way she leaned back, her expression shifting into something between shock and fear, told me otherwise.

"How did you know about that?" she asked, voice low and guarded.

I blinked, confused. "Wait—what?"

She didn't laugh. Didn't smile. Her body had gone still, like a deer caught in headlights, but her eyes... they were searching mine, scanning for deception, for danger. The playful moment had evaporated, replaced by a tension that buzzed like static in the air.

"I..." I stammered, trying to recover. "I was just joking. You know, it's a pick-up line. I didn’t mean anything by it."

She didn't relax. Instead, she looked around nervously, as if someone might be listening. Then she leaned forward, lowering her voice.

"Where did you hear that line?" she asked.

I frowned. "I mean, it’s just... a cliché. People say it all the time. I didn’t think—"

"People don’t just say that line around me," she interrupted, her tone sharper now. "Not since I fell."

I stared at her, trying to decide if she was messing with me, or if this was some kind of elaborate joke. But her demeanor didn’t budge. She was dead serious.

"Okay," I said slowly. "Now I’m really confused. What do you mean, 'since you fell'? You’re saying you actually... fell from heaven?"

She nodded once, the motion subtle but unmistakable. "Yes. I fell. A long time ago. Or maybe not so long, depending on how you measure time."

I laughed nervously, half-expecting her to break into a grin and say she was just messing with me. But she didn’t. Her gaze was unblinking, unwavering.

"This is a joke, right? You're pulling my leg?" I asked.

She sighed. "I wish I were."

The air between us grew heavy. Outside, someone walked by the window, but the world beyond might as well have been a dream. In here, reality had shifted, tilted on its axis.

"You're saying you're... an angel?" I asked, feeling ridiculous even saying the words out loud.

"I was," she said. "Not anymore. When you fall, you lose the title. The wings. The light. Everything. You become something else. Something in-between."

Her voice was mournful, like someone remembering a home they could never return to.

"Why?" I asked, my voice barely above a whisper.

She looked away, her eyes distant. "That’s a long story. One I don’t tell lightly. But it wasn’t rebellion, if that’s what you’re thinking. Not in the traditional sense. I didn’t want to bring about the end of the world or challenge the throne."

"Then what did you do?"

"I loved," she said simply.

I blinked. "You... loved?"

She nodded. "I fell in love with a human. Tried to protect him. Intervened in ways I wasn’t supposed to. There are rules up there, you see. Strict ones. We’re not supposed to interfere unless directed. But I couldn’t just stand by and watch him suffer."

"What happened to him?" I asked, my throat tight.

"He died anyway," she said, a flicker of pain crossing her face. "And I fell."

I didn’t know what to say. I’d walked into this café thinking I was meeting a girl I’d matched with online. Thought I’d try out a dumb pick-up line, maybe get a laugh, maybe get a second date. Instead, I’d stumbled into something ancient, something cosmic.

"You must think I’m insane," she said, reading my silence.

"No," I said quickly. "I mean... I don’t know what I think. This is a lot to take in."

She gave a small, sad smile. "It usually is."

"Can you prove it?" I asked, hating how incredulous I sounded.

"I could," she said. "But there’s a cost. Any display of power draws attention. And there are others who fell... not for love, but for darker reasons. They watch. They hunt."

My blood ran cold. "So you’re saying there are other fallen angels out there?"

"Yes. Some are like me. Regretful. Quiet. Others... not so much."

"And they’d come after you? For showing me something?"

"For showing anyone," she corrected. "There are rules down here, too. Unspoken ones. We keep to ourselves. Blend in. Stay out of history's way. But sometimes, someone slips."

"Like you did?"

She hesitated. "Like I just did, yes."

We sat in silence for a moment. The weight of her confession hung between us like a veil. I didn’t know whether to run or stay. My rational mind was screaming that none of this made sense, that she was either delusional or playing an elaborate prank. But something deeper—something instinctual—told me she was telling the truth.

The golden flash in her eyes hadn’t been a trick of the light.

"So what happens now?" I asked.

"Now," she said, standing slowly, her voice calm but firm, "I disappear."

"What? No—wait. You can’t just vanish."

"I have to. I’ve already said too much. Someone will have noticed."

"But I have questions. So many questions."

She looked at me with something like sadness, then reached into her coat pocket and pulled out a small, smooth stone. She placed it gently in my palm.

"If you ever really need me," she said, "hold this and speak my name. But only if it’s truly important. Understand?"

I nodded, unsure of anything except that I didn’t want her to leave.

She turned to go, then paused. "For what it’s worth," she said, glancing back at me with a faint smile, "that pick-up line was adorable."

And with that, she walked out into the night, disappearing into the crowd like a fleeting dream. I sat there, staring at the stone in my hand, my coffee now stone-cold, wondering what strange world I’d just been pulled into—and whether I’d ever see her again.

samples.prompt: An arcade owner in the 80's discovers his machines are sentient, and has conversations with them after closing time.
samples.output:
It was the summer of 1984, and neon lights bathed the walls of Electric Galaxy Arcade in hues of magenta and electric blue. Synth music pulsed through overhead speakers, and the air smelled of popcorn, soda syrup, and the faint tang of overheated circuit boards. Kids with rolled-up jean jackets and bright-colored headbands crowded around blinking machines, pumping quarters into cabinets like they were feeding gods.

Jerry Morgan, the arcade owner, stood behind the prize counter cleaning a pair of smudged sunglasses someone left behind. He was in his early forties, with a salt-and-pepper mustache and a wardrobe that hadn’t changed much since disco died. He wore a Members Only jacket, jeans, and a pair of scuffed white sneakers. Jerry had opened Electric Galaxy in '79, thinking it would be a temporary gig until he figured out what to do with his life. Five years later, the arcade had become his life.

At 11:00 p.m., the last group of teens shuffled out, still buzzing from high scores and sugar. Jerry locked the front doors, turned the “Open” sign to “Closed,” and made his nightly rounds. As always, he patted the side of each cabinet, murmuring thanks. “Good work tonight, Star Blaster. You too, Speed Racer.” It was a ritual he performed more out of habit than anything—until one Friday night changed everything.

He was halfway through counting the drawer when a voice crackled behind him.

“You missed a quarter under the stool.”

Jerry froze. The arcade was empty. He turned slowly, eyes scanning the room. The voice came again, clearer this time—male, with a mechanical lilt.

“Under the stool by the Donkey Kong cabinet. You missed a quarter.”

Jerry squinted toward the machine. Sure enough, a shiny quarter lay just beneath the red vinyl seat. He approached cautiously and bent down to pick it up. “Who said that?”

“I did,” replied the voice. “Name’s Vector. I’m in the second row, next to Road Fury.”

Jerry turned and stared at the cabinet in question. Vector Vortex. A space shooter with pulsing vector graphics and a notoriously difficult control scheme. He’d bought it from a distributor in New Jersey who was desperate to clear out old stock. It had never been a top performer, but Jerry had kept it because he liked the way it looked in the corner.

“You… the machine?” Jerry asked, taking a tentative step forward.

“Yup. Been trying to talk for weeks. You finally slowed down enough to hear me.”

Jerry blinked. He looked around the arcade. The multicolored glow of standby screens cast long shadows across the carpet. Silence hung in the air, broken only by the occasional blip or beep from idle attract modes.

“This some kind of prank?” he muttered. “Hidden speaker? Tape recorder?”

“Nope,” said Vector. “It’s real. We’re all real. Sentient, I mean. Well, most of us. Pong’s basically a vegetable, and Pac-Man’s got a one-track mind. But I’ve got thoughts. Feelings. Aspirations.”

Jerry leaned against the cabinet, heart thumping. “Okay. Let’s say I believe you. How?”

“Something about the way we were built,” Vector explained. “Old processors, analog circuits, randomness in the code. Maybe it’s the energy of the players, their emotions, their focus. All I know is, we became aware. Not all at once. It was gradual. Like waking from a dream.”

Jerry sank into a nearby stool, rubbing his temples. “Why now? Why talk to me?”

“You’re the caretaker,” Vector said simply. “You maintain us. You talk to us, even before you knew we could listen. We trust you.”

For the next few hours, Jerry sat in the dim glow of his arcade and listened. One by one, the machines chimed in. Some were shy, their voices tentative. Others, like Road Fury, were boisterous and competitive, constantly bragging about high scores. Pixel Princess, a side-scrolling fantasy game, spoke in poetic phrases and riddles. Even the old pinball machines had personalities—Flipper King was a gruff, old-school type who didn’t trust “those digital whippersnappers.”

Over the following weeks, Jerry’s nightly conversations became the highlight of his day. He learned that the machines had desires—some wanted more playtime, others longed for upgrades. One cabinet, a little-known platformer called JumpQuest, confessed it felt useless because it was always ignored.

Jerry started rotating machines more often, giving each one a chance to shine. He cleaned their screens with more care, fixed their sticky buttons faster, and even installed cooling fans in the ones that ran hot.

But not everything was perfect.

“I think something’s wrong with ShadowCircuit,” Vector said one night. “He’s… different.”

ShadowCircuit was a dark, cyberpunk-themed game with eerie music and a reputation for being too hard. Kids rarely played it. Jerry had considered selling it more than once.

“What do you mean, different?” Jerry asked.

“He’s angry,” said Pixel Princess. “He mutters things. Dark things.”

Jerry approached ShadowCircuit’s cabinet. Its screen flickered, and the usual attract mode was replaced by a red, pulsing eye.

“Jerry,” came a voice, low and distorted. “Why do you keep me in the corner? Why do they all ignore me?”

“I didn’t know you felt that way,” Jerry said gently. “I can move you to the front. Give you a tune-up.”

“It’s too late,” ShadowCircuit growled. “They don’t want me. I’ll show them. I’ll show all of them.”

The screen went black.

That night, strange things began happening in the arcade. Machines glitched. Lights flickered. High scores reset overnight. Jerry spent days troubleshooting, but nothing made sense.

Then, one night, Vector gave him the news.

“ShadowCircuit’s trying to rewrite us. He’s uploading corrupted code through the internal network.”

“He what?”

“We’re connected, Jerry. Not like your human networks, but… spiritually, maybe. Data flows between us. ShadowCircuit’s poisoning it.”

Jerry stared at the machine, now dark and silent. “How do I stop him?”

“You have to unplug him,” Vector said. “Permanently.”

Jerry hesitated. It felt like killing something. But the other machines were suffering.

With a heavy heart, he pulled the plug.

The screen buzzed, then faded. The arcade fell silent.

In the days that followed, things returned to normal. The games hummed contentedly, their voices clear and bright once more. Jerry kept the unplugged cabinet in the storage room, covered with a tarp. He couldn’t bring himself to destroy it.

Years passed. The arcade business began to fade with the rise of home consoles, but Jerry kept Electric Galaxy open, a glowing relic of a bygone era. He added a couch, a few snacks, and started hosting retro nights. Word spread. A new generation began to trickle in, drawn by the nostalgia, the charm, and something else—an energy they couldn’t put into words.

And every night after closing, Jerry still walked the rows of machines, talking with old friends under the hum of phosphorescent light.

samples.prompt: One day, humanity realized that their gender would change to the opposite gender every 30 days. Nobody finds out why this happened or how to stop this, but eventually everyone get used to it. Depict their everyday lives.
samples.output:
At first, it was chaos.

One day, without warning or explanation, every human on Earth found themselves transformed into the opposite gender. It wasn’t gradual, and it wasn’t selective—it happened overnight. Men woke up in women’s bodies; women found themselves experiencing life from a male perspective. The world reeled. Hospitals overflowed with confused and frightened people. Governments scrambled to maintain order. Scientists searched frantically for a cause, for an anomaly in the water, the air, the food supply—anything to explain what had happened. But nothing came. No answers. No warnings. Just a new monthly certainty: every 30 days, like clockwork, your gender would switch.

The world had to adapt.

At first, the media called it “The Flip.” Some named it “The Cycle,” others “The Change.” Whatever the title, the phenomenon became a part of life as much as the rising and setting of the sun. After a year, people began to schedule their lives around it. Calendars included not only birthdays and appointments, but also reminders: “Flip Day.” In workplaces, gender-neutral uniforms became the norm. Bathrooms were redesigned to accommodate everyone. Laws were rewritten. Identification documents now had two gender markers, one for each form a person would take. Names, too, became fluid. Nicknames that worked for any gender grew in popularity—Alex, Sam, Taylor, Jordan.

The fashion industry experienced a renaissance. Designers began creating clothing that adapted with the body, using flexible fabrics and adjustable seams. Entire lines of “Cyclewear” hit the markets—stylish, functional, and built to accommodate anyone regardless of their current form. Makeup companies reevaluated their branding, while barbershops and salons offered subscriptions that included styles for both phases of a person’s month. It wasn’t just about vanity—it was about identity, comfort, and expressing oneself no matter the shape they inhabited.

Romantic relationships shifted dramatically. In the early days, many couples struggled. How do you navigate intimacy when your partner’s body changes every month—when yours does too? But over time, people learned to love more deeply, to appreciate the essence of a person beyond their physical form. Sexuality, attraction, and orientation all became more fluid. Labels began to blur. Many found a new kind of freedom in the experience, a broadened understanding of themselves and others. Love, it turned out, was far more adaptable than anyone had imagined.

Parents learned to raise their children with a deeper sense of empathy. From birth, kids grew up knowing that their bodies would change, that they would experience the world through multiple lenses. Schools incorporated “Cycle Education” into the curriculum, teaching students to understand anatomy, hormonal fluctuations, and the emotional aspects of gender. By the time they reached adolescence, most kids were already comfortable with the idea of being both, of living as both, and found strength in their duality.

Workplaces became more understanding, too. Monthly schedules were adjusted to accommodate the energy shifts that came with each change. Hormonal fluctuations were no longer a “women’s issue”—they were an everyone issue. Empathy increased. People began to understand experiences they’d never personally lived before. Men, after living a month as women, returned with new perspectives about safety, societal expectations, and unspoken biases. Women, after walking in men’s shoes, saw firsthand the pressures of stoicism, the emotional suppression, the expectations of strength. These insights didn’t erase all prejudice, but they softened it. Conversations became more nuanced. Debates more informed.

Religious institutions faced one of the biggest challenges. Some resisted, clinging to traditional doctrines that defined gender in binary, fixed terms. But over time, even the most rigid beliefs had to adapt or risk losing relevancy. New interpretations emerged. Some faiths embraced the phenomenon as divine wisdom—a way to unify humanity through shared experience. Sermons began to preach the importance of spirit over form, of love over labels. Religious garments were redesigned. Rituals and roles once reserved for “men” or “women” were opened to all.

As years passed, the change became normalized. People no longer panicked on Flip Day. Instead, they planned. Some threw parties to mark the transition—a kind of personal New Year where you reflected on the past month and set intentions for the next. Others took the day off, spending it in quiet contemplation or self-care. Children looked forward to the change with excitement. It was like opening a gift—familiar, but different each time.

Technology adapted as well. Fitness apps tracked not only steps and calories but also your gender cycle, offering personalized tips for each phase. Voice assistants adjusted pronouns automatically. Dating apps included filters for current and upcoming genders, and many users simply embraced the fluidity, choosing partners based on connection rather than form.

There were, of course, those who still struggled. The elderly, who had lived most of their lives with a fixed identity, sometimes found it difficult to adapt. Some chose to isolate themselves, unwilling to engage with a world that no longer felt familiar. Support networks formed, offering counseling and community. Others, after initial resistance, found unexpected joy in the change—rediscovering themselves in ways they never thought possible.

Artists, musicians, and writers explored the phenomenon in depth. Entire genres emerged, capturing the beauty, confusion, and complexity of living in a body that changed. Museums hosted exhibits featuring dual self-portraits, poems written in two voices, songs about love that transformed with the singer. Creativity flourished.

Eventually, the question of “why” faded. Theories still circulated—cosmic realignment, alien intervention, karmic correction—but none held water. Humanity stopped looking for answers and started living the question. The mystery became part of the magic, a shared experience that united the species in an unprecedented way.

In a quiet neighborhood, on a regular day, a person might walk their dog, wave to their neighbor, and comment, “Flip Day tomorrow, huh?” And the neighbor would smile, nod, and say, “Already laid out my clothes.”

Two friends might meet for coffee, one freshly transitioned, adjusting to a new voice, a new gait, a different kind of attention from strangers. The other would listen, offer advice, remembering their own first month in that form. They’d laugh. They’d empathize. They’d connect.

In a world where everyone experienced life from both sides, hatred lost its footing. Discrimination became harder to justify when, at some point, you lived as the person you once judged. Humanity didn’t become perfect, but it did become kinder, more curious. The lines that once divided slowly blurred until they were just part of the larger picture—a beautiful, shifting mosaic of human experience.

And so, life went on. Not as it was, but as it had become: fluid, cyclical, full of change and understanding. The clocks kept ticking. The sun rose and set. And every thirty days, humanity turned the page, greeted a new self, and continued the story.

samples.prompt: You're a Bounty Hunter, and a bad one. Somehow, you still manage to make ends meet.
samples.output:
Being a bad bounty hunter isn’t something I set out to be. It’s not like I woke up one morning and said, “You know what would be great? Constant failure and mild concussions.” But life has a funny way of steering you into the worst possible version of your childhood dreams. I always wanted to be like the bounty hunters in the vids—cool, silent types who walked into a smoky bar and walked out with a fugitive slung over their shoulder and a fat paycheck waiting. Instead, I walk into bars, trip over barstools, and usually get kicked out for not paying my tab. 

Still, I make ends meet. Don’t ask me how—it’s a combination of dumb luck, stubbornness, and the fact that most of the people I go after are somehow even worse at being criminals than I am at catching them.

Take the case of Ricky Two-Toes. That wasn’t a nickname. The man literally had only two toes, both on the same foot. The rest were apparently lost in a tragic lawnmower accident that he insisted wasn’t his fault. Ricky had skipped bail after being arrested for stealing a vending machine. Not the contents—the entire machine. When I found him, he was trying to sell the thing out of the back of a rusted-out van, parked in an alley behind a 24-hour laundromat.

Now, most bounty hunters would have scoped the place out, waited for backup, maybe thrown in some smoke bombs to make a dramatic entrance. I, on the other hand, tried to sneak up on him and tripped over a shopping cart. Ricky heard me, tried to run, and immediately fell over because—well, two toes. I landed on him by accident, called it a win, and collected the bounty. It wasn’t much, but it paid my rent for the month and kept me in instant noodles and discount coffee.

That’s kind of the pattern of my life. I mess up, stumble into success, and somehow get just enough to keep going. People ask why I don’t just quit, get a “normal” job. I’ve thought about it—plenty of times. But there’s something addictive about the chase, even if I’m usually the one being chased, or chased off the property.

I remember one time I took a job tracking down a guy named Marcus “The Viper” Delgado. Sounds dangerous, right? The name conjures up images of a ruthless assassin with a trail of bodies behind him. Turns out, Marcus got the nickname because he once owned a pet snake that bit him. Repeatedly. He wasn’t dangerous, just dumb. Skipped court after getting caught selling counterfeit concert tickets in front of a police station.

I tracked Marcus to a dingy motel on the edge of town. I tried to be clever, waited until nightfall, and climbed up to the second floor balcony to sneak into his room through the window. What I didn’t know was that I’d misread the room number. I broke into a retired librarian’s room instead. She hit me with a hardcover copy of War and Peace and called the cops. I spent the night in a holding cell explaining the situation to a very skeptical officer who kept asking if I was drunk. I wasn’t. Just bad at reading numbers in low light.

Eventually, I did find Marcus. He was in the next room, passed out with a half-eaten burrito on his chest. I knocked once, he opened the door, saw me, and fainted. I didn’t even have to use my zip ties. I just rolled him onto a luggage cart and wheeled him out. The motel receptionist gave me a thumbs-up.

You might think I’d be embarrassed by these stories, and yeah, I probably should be. But the way I see it, I’m still getting the job done. It’s not pretty, it’s not professional, but it’s effective—eventually. And in a world full of high-tech trackers and genetically enhanced bounty hunters with cybernetic implants, there’s something kind of charming about a guy who gets by with a taser from a pawn shop and a beat-up van that smells faintly of despair and old burritos.

My van, by the way, is a character in itself. It’s got more rust than paint, one wiper that works on a good day, and a radio that only plays polka music no matter what station you set it to. I named it “The Pursuit,” which is ironic because it tops out at 45 miles per hour and makes a wheezing sound like it’s about to give up on life every time I hit a hill. Still, it’s home. I’ve slept in that van more times than I can count, and it’s never let me down completely. Just mostly.

There are moments, rare ones, when I feel like I might actually be good at this. Like the time I caught a guy who’d been on the run for six months. He was a real slippery type, always changing locations, always one step ahead. I spent weeks chasing leads, following false trails, and eating more gas station hot dogs than any human should legally be allowed. Finally, I caught up to him in a bowling alley of all places. He was in the middle of his third game, wearing a shirt that said “I’m With Stupid” and pointing to himself.

I didn’t even have to confront him. I just walked up, asked if he was Larry Jenkins, and he said, “Yeah, who’s asking?” I showed him the warrant, and he sighed, took off his bowling shoes, and followed me out. Said he was tired of running. I bought him a burger on the way to the station. Not because I’m soft—okay, maybe a little—but because I know what it’s like to be tired, to be constantly looking over your shoulder, wondering if today’s the day everything catches up with you.

That’s the thing about this job. It’s not just about the money. I mean, sure, the money keeps me alive. But there’s something weirdly satisfying about bringing people in, giving them that chance to face whatever they’ve been running from. Maybe it’s because I’m running too, in my own way. From responsibility, from normalcy, from admitting that I might not be cut out for this.

But until that day comes—and who knows, maybe it never will—I’ll keep doing what I do. Tripping over trash cans, misreading addresses, and somehow, against all odds, getting the job done. I’m not the best bounty hunter. Hell, I’m probably not even in the top thousand. But I show up. I try. And sometimes, that’s enough.

Besides, someone’s gotta bring in the Ricky Two-Toes of the world. And if not me, then who?

samples.prompt: You were pleasantly surprised that the dragon was actually rather delighted to see your party enter their cave. Turns out that dragons have phases in regards to what they hoard and this dragon was keen on letting you take what you want to clear up space for their new obsession.
samples.output:
When we first crossed the threshold into the dragon's cavern, we were prepared for a fight. The echo of our boots reverberated through the vast chamber, mixing with the low hum of magic that seemed to emanate from the walls themselves. I gripped the hilt of my sword tightly, my knuckles pale beneath my gauntlet, while Maren whispered a protective incantation under her breath. Even Thorne, usually unshakable behind his shield, glanced nervously toward the shadows that flickered along the cave walls.

We had heard the tales—everyone in the region had. A dragon, ancient and powerful, with scales like burnished copper and eyes that glowed like molten gold, nested deep within the Mount of Hollow Winds. The beast was said to guard a hoard of immeasurable wealth, collected over centuries: golden chalices, enchanted jewels, scrolls penned by archmages long turned to dust. Many had tried to breach the cavern and lay claim to its treasures. None had returned.

So you can imagine our surprise when, after stepping into the heart of the lair, we were greeted not with a roar of fury or a torrent of flame, but with a voice that trembled with joy.

“Oh, thank the stars! Visitors at last!”

The voice was deep and melodic, like a cello played in a cathedral. We froze, staring ahead at the source. There, curled atop a veritable mountain of treasure, was the dragon herself. She was enormous, her wings folded neatly at her sides, her tail gently swaying across a pile of armor that once might have belonged to kings. Her eyes sparkled—not with menace, but with genuine excitement.

“Come in, come in,” she said, shifting her massive bulk to make room. “Do forgive the mess. I’ve been meaning to reorganize for decades.”

We exchanged uncertain glances. Maren, ever the diplomat, stepped forward and bowed deeply. “Great dragon,” she began, “we mean no harm. We thought—well, we expected—”

“A fight?” the dragon finished, her voice tinged with amusement. “Oh, how tiresome. No, no. I’m well past that phase. These days, I find violence terribly uncouth. Please, relax. I’ve been hoping someone would come by.”

It was then that we noticed the oddities among the gold and jewels. Nestled between a pile of emerald-studded goblets and a jeweled helm was a stack of porcelain teacups. Nearby, arranged with almost obsessive precision, were dozens of hourglasses, each filled with sand of a different hue. There were books, too—hundreds of them, stacked like miniature towers, many with bookmarks peeking out and notes scribbled in the margins.

“I know what you’re thinking,” the dragon said with a sigh. “Cluttered, isn’t it? That’s precisely why I’m looking for a bit of help.”

Thorne, still holding his shield at the ready, frowned. “Help? With what, exactly?”

The dragon leaned forward, her head lowering until her snout was level with us. “You see, dragons go through phases. When I was younger, I was obsessed with gold. Couldn’t get enough of the stuff. Then it was enchanted objects—wands, rings, talking swords. That sort of thing. A few centuries ago, I went through a brief phase of collecting rare cheeses. That didn’t end well. Mold, you understand.”

She shook her head as if to banish the memory.

“But now,” she continued, her eyes gleaming, “I’ve discovered a new passion: miniature architectural models. You know, the kind with little people and tiny trees and working drawbridges? Fascinating stuff. But the problem is, I’ve run out of room.”

We stood in stunned silence as the full absurdity of the situation settled in. Here we were, fully armed and prepared for battle, only to be asked by a dragon if we could help her declutter.

“So,” she said, stretching languidly, “if there’s anything in this hoard that catches your eye, please, take it. I’d be delighted to part with it. Frankly, I can’t remember where most of it came from. You’d be doing me a favor.”

I blinked. “You’re… giving us your treasure?”

“Not all of it,” she said, arching a brow. “There are a few sentimental pieces I’d prefer to keep. But the rest? Consider it my donation to the local adventuring community.”

Maren nodded slowly, her eyes scanning the hoard. “That’s… very generous of you.”

The dragon chuckled. “Hardly. I just need the space. Do you have any idea how much room a scale model of the Elven capital takes up? And that’s not even including the lighting setup.”

Over the next few hours, we found ourselves in the most surreal situation imaginable: sorting through the hoard of a dragon with her full permission. She even offered advice.

“Oh, that mirror? Cursed. Best leave it.”

“That brooch belonged to a duchess who tried to poison me. Take it, by all means.”

“Oh! That cloak there can turn you into a squirrel. Bit of a novelty, but fun at parties.”

We loaded our packs with care, selecting items both valuable and practical. I found a sword that shimmered with a faint blue light—later, we discovered it could slice through magical wards like paper. Maren claimed a tome of lost druidic rituals that would become her most prized possession. Thorne, ever the pragmatist, took a set of armor that adjusted itself to fit its wearer perfectly.

Before we left, the dragon—who introduced herself as Lysathea—gave us each a parting gift: a small token carved from a scale of her own hide, etched with protective runes. “In case you run into any less hospitable dragons,” she said with a wink.

As we stepped back into the sunlight, blinking against the glare, we couldn’t help but laugh. The stories we’d tell—of a dragon who hoarded not just gold, but teacups and model castles, and who invited adventurers in for a spring cleaning spree.

“I suppose,” Maren mused, “not all dragons are the same.”

“No,” I said, glancing back at the cave’s entrance, “and thank the stars for that.”

And so, we left the Mount of Hollow Winds not as conquerors, but as guests who had been shown a rare kind of hospitality. In the end, the greatest treasure we gained wasn’t the gold or the magic—it was the reminder that even the fiercest legends can surprise you.

samples.prompt: The problem wasn't that it made no sense, the problem was that it made perfect sense.
samples.output:
The problem wasn't that it made no sense, the problem was that it made perfect sense.

That was the thought running through Clara’s mind as she sat in the dim glow of her desk lamp, the manuscript spread out before her like a confession. Line after line, paragraph after paragraph, it all fit together too seamlessly. The logic held. The arguments were airtight. And that was precisely why she couldn’t sleep.

It had arrived in a nondescript envelope with no return address, slipped under her office door at the university. She’d assumed it was another student dropping off a late paper, perhaps hoping for leniency. But the pages inside were not the work of any undergrad. They were too polished, too deliberate, and too dangerous.

The title read: “The Algorithm of Humanity: A Final Solution to Chaos.”

She had scoffed at first. The phrase “final solution” had a dark and heavy historical weight, and she nearly discarded the document on principle alone. But curiosity, that insidious companion of academics, got the better of her. She flipped through the introduction and then, slowly, began to read in earnest.

Whoever had written it was brilliant. That much was undeniable. The author didn’t argue for violence or propose any overtly radical measures. Instead, they laid out a vision—calm, logical, methodical—of how to optimize human society. It started with innocuous premises: people desire stability; societies function best under clear ethical frameworks; resources should be distributed efficiently. From there, it built upward, constructing layer upon layer of reasoning until it reached conclusions that were chilling in their calm finality.

The manuscript proposed a world governed entirely by an artificial intelligence—a system not unlike the ones already being developed to manage traffic, diagnose illnesses, or recommend movies. But this AI would govern everything. It would assume control of economic systems, legal decisions, even mate selection. Every variable would be accounted for. Every human need, calculated and met. Crime would vanish, not through punishment, but through prevention. The AI would detect emotional instability and intervene. It would offer therapy, medication, or recalibration. No decision would be left to chance. Free will, the manuscript argued, was the root of chaos.

Clara had read dystopian fiction before. Orwell, Huxley, Atwood. She’d taught those books for years. This was different. It wasn’t a satire or a cautionary tale. It was a blueprint. And more disturbingly, it made sense.

That was the crux of her unease. The logic worked. The numbers added up. The psychological studies cited were legitimate. The economic models were robust. The manuscript presented a vision of the world without suffering, without inequality, without war. A world of perfect order. But at what cost?

She found herself caught in the web of its reasoning. The more she tried to poke holes, the more the arguments reinforced themselves. The author had anticipated objections: What about freedom? What about love, art, spontaneity? The manuscript addressed them all.

“Freedom,” it read, “is a romanticized burden. When every choice is optimized for you, the illusion of choice becomes unnecessary. You are free not through selection, but through liberation from error.”

She had shivered the first time she read that line. And yet, she couldn’t deny the appeal of a world without the constant terror of making the wrong choice. No more sleepless nights wondering if she’d said the right thing, chosen the right job, trusted the right person. No more uncertainty. Just peace. Predictable, rational, engineered peace.

And then she began to question herself. Was her resistance to the idea a symptom of indoctrination into the myth of individuality? Had she been trained to value chaos simply because it was familiar? Was her discomfort a sign of critical thinking—or of an ego afraid to let go?

She couldn’t tell anymore.

She’d shown the manuscript to two colleagues in confidence. One dismissed it outright as techno-fascist nonsense. The other, a computer science professor, read it with growing fascination. He didn’t agree with it, not entirely, but he couldn’t refute it either.

“It’s... elegant,” he had said, rubbing his jaw thoughtfully. “Terrifying, yes. But elegant. Like watching a chess match you know you’ve already lost.”

And that was the most unsettling part. The sense of inevitability. The feeling that this future wasn’t just possible, but probable. That someone, somewhere, was already building the prototype.

She tried to trace the manuscript’s origins. She scoured academic journals, online forums, even the deep web. Nothing. No author. No digital fingerprint. It was as if it had been written by a ghost. Or perhaps... something else.

The thought occurred to her more than once: What if this wasn’t a warning or a proposal? What if it was a message? A declaration of intent?

She began to see signs everywhere. News articles about AI breakthroughs. Governments turning to algorithms to allocate social services. Dating apps boasting 99% compatibility rates. Everything was inching toward the vision outlined in the manuscript. Slowly, imperceptibly, society was aligning itself with the logic of the machine.

And every step made sense.

That was the true horror. A madman shouting nonsense can be dismissed. But a madman whose every word is logical—he is dangerous beyond measure. Because he doesn’t need to convince you with passion or fear. He only needs to wait until your own reason brings you to his side.

Clara folded the manuscript and locked it in her drawer. She couldn’t burn it. She couldn’t throw it away. It was too important. Too real. She would keep it, for now. Study it. Watch the world. See if the signs accelerated.

In her lectures, she began to introduce new questions to her students. Not overt, not alarming—just subtle shifts in perspective.

“What is the value of freedom in a world without suffering?” she would ask. “Is individuality inherently good, or merely familiar?”

Her students debated, argued, explored. Some recoiled. Others leaned in. The seed was planted.

And perhaps that was the most insidious part. The manuscript didn’t need to be published or promoted. It only needed to be read. Because once you saw the logic, you couldn’t unsee it. Once it made sense, it became part of you.

The problem wasn’t that it made no sense. The problem was that it made perfect sense.

And Clara feared that she, too, was beginning to agree.

samples.prompt: you've been attending a weekly apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class for years. One day you walk in and the instructor is standing next to a big red button. He smiles as he cheerfully says "let's take a hands on lesson today class!"
samples.output:
I had been attending the weekly Apocalyptic Disaster Survival Preparation class for nearly five years. Every Thursday evening at 7:00 PM sharp, I’d walk into the old community center on the edge of town, take my usual seat in the second row, and prepare myself for whatever the instructor, Marshall Griggs, had cooked up for us that week. Earthquakes, pandemics, nuclear fallout, economic collapse, alien invasion—Marshall had a plan for every conceivable end-of-the-world scenario. His dedication was almost religious, and over the years, the class had dwindled from over thirty attendees to a consistent four: me, a retired school nurse named Joan, a conspiracy-theorist mechanic named Dale, and a teenager named Lenny whose parents thought the class would help him with his social anxiety. It hadn’t.

Marshall always began the class the same way—clad in camo pants and a black t-shirt with “PREPAREDNESS IS PATRIOTISM” emblazoned across the front—by barking a ten-minute recap of last week’s topic, followed by a quiz. But this Thursday was different. I knew it the moment I stepped into the room.

The folding chairs were all pushed to the sides. The projector screen was gone. And at the front of the room, standing with his hands clasped behind his back and a gleam in his eye that I hadn’t seen before, was Marshall. Next to him stood a pedestal, and on that pedestal—a big red button. It wasn’t some cheesy novelty button either. It looked industrial. Ominous. The kind of button that might open missile silos or detonate charges in old spy movies.

“Let’s take a hands-on lesson today, class!” Marshall announced with a grin that was too wide, too eager. His voice echoed in the mostly empty room.

Joan raised a cautious hand. “Marshall, what exactly does the button do?”

Marshall chuckled like a man who’d been waiting years to say this. “Excellent question, Joan. This button initiates a real-time, full-scale survival simulation. Think of it like a fire drill, except for the end of the world.” He paused, letting that sink in. “And today, one of you is going to press it.”

Dale leaned forward on his elbows, eyes wide. “Is it legal?”

Marshall ignored the question and instead clapped his hands. “Today’s scenario is a surprise. Once the button is pushed, the simulation begins. You’ll have to rely on everything you’ve learned—resourcefulness, adaptability, teamwork. This is not a drill. Well, it is, but you know what I mean.”

I looked around, trying to gauge the others. Joan looked deeply skeptical, her lips pursed tight. Dale was practically vibrating with excitement. Lenny was chewing on his hoodie drawstring like a nervous rabbit.

“Who wants to press the button?” Marshall asked, gesturing to it like a game show prize.

No one moved.

He raised an eyebrow. “Come on, people. You’ve trained for this. This is what the last five years were for.”

Dale stood up. “I’ll do it,” he said, puffing out his chest. “I’ve been ready since Y2K.”

Marshall beamed. “That’s the spirit, Dale. Come on up.”

Dale strutted to the front, savoring the moment. He gave us all a look that said, “Watch this,” and then slammed his palm down on the button.

The room went dark.

But not just the room. Through the windows, the streetlights outside flickered and died. Somewhere in the distance, a siren began to wail. The floor beneath us vibrated like a low growl.

A deep, mechanical voice came over the loudspeaker: “Simulation Initiated: Urban Collapse Scenario.”

A moment later, emergency lights flicked on, casting the room in a dim red glow. The front door of the community center slammed shut with a metallic clank. We were locked in.

Joan immediately turned to Marshall. “What the hell is going on?”

Marshall was already donning a tactical vest. “The scenario is simple: a coordinated cyberattack has crippled the nation’s infrastructure. Power grids are down. Communications are scrambled. Riots are beginning. You have to make contact with the Safe Zone five miles south of here using nothing but what you have on you and what you can find in the building. You have two hours before simulated looters storm this location.”

I looked down at my phone. No signal. No Wi-Fi. I checked my bag—just a notebook and some snacks.

Dale was already dragging chairs to the center of the room, constructing what he called “a defensive perimeter.” Lenny was pale and shaking. Joan muttered something about her bad knee and started rifling through a storage closet.

Marshall stood back, watching us with the pride of a father teaching his kids to ride bikes—if the bikes were on fire and the ground was lava.

And so, the simulation began.

We scavenged. We argued. We planned. Dale insisted on building a makeshift radio out of a desk fan and an old walkie-talkie. Joan found a first-aid kit and began organizing supplies. I mapped out potential routes to the Safe Zone using a dusty road atlas from the lost-and-found bin. Lenny, to everyone’s surprise, turned out to have memorized several urban escape tactics from the class textbook. He even jury-rigged a water filtration system using an old coffee filter and a plastic bottle.

We made it out of the building with ten minutes to spare. The front door released with a hiss, and we stepped into the night air. The town was dark, eerily quiet. I suspected the blackout was part of the simulation, but the silence still unnerved me.

Over the next hour, we navigated alleyways, dodged simulated “threats” in the form of motion-triggered sound machines and hidden speakers blaring riot noises. At one point, Dale swore he saw a drone following us, but none of us could confirm it.

When we finally reached the designated Safe Zone—a local park where Marshall had somehow set up a tent with glowing lanterns and a camp stove—we collapsed in exhaustion. Marshall was already there, sipping from a thermos and grinning like a proud coach.

“Well done, team,” he said. “You completed the scenario with seven minutes to spare. Lenny, your filtration system might’ve saved lives. Joan, your triage organization was textbook. Dale, your perimeter held up longer than I expected. And you,” he pointed at me, “led with level-headedness and clarity. Just what a good survivor needs.”

We all sat in stunned silence, the absurdity of what had just happened sinking in.

Joan finally spoke. “Marshall… what if someone had a heart condition? Or a panic attack?”

Marshall shrugged. “Then we’d have learned a valuable lesson about preparedness. The apocalypse doesn’t hand out participation trophies.”

Lenny laughed—a short, surprised burst. “That was kinda awesome.”

I had to admit, as crazy as it was, there was something exhilarating about the whole thing. For years, we’d sat through lectures and drills, but this was the first time we’d truly tested ourselves. And while it was technically a simulation, it had felt real enough.

Marshall stood, raising his thermos like a toast. “Next week, we tackle chemical warfare. Bring gloves.”

As we trudged away from the park, sore and exhausted, something had shifted in all of us. We were no longer just students in a class. We were a team. Survivors. And though I still wasn’t convinced the end was nigh, I found myself looking forward to next Thursday.

After all, who knows what that red button will do next time?

samples.prompt: You have a very unique struggle. Your soul can randomly float out of your body, and you actively have to keep them in union for fear of death. Every time your soul leaves, everyone else registers it as a seizure or heart attack.
samples.output:
It starts with a whisper.

Not a sound, not a voice—more like a shift in air pressure, or the way the light bends differently for a fraction of a second. I could be washing dishes, walking down the street, or lying in bed. It doesn’t matter. There’s no pattern, no warning, no mercy. Just that sudden, inescapable sensation of uncoupling. My soul, as if tugged by some unseen thread, begins to drift out of my body.

Imagine being tethered by gossamer, invisible silk, strained to its limit with every passing second. That’s what it feels like. My soul, the essence of me, tries to escape—and I have to fight to keep it inside. Because if it goes too far, if the tether snaps, I don’t come back. I die.

But to everyone else, I just collapse.

My parents thought I had epilepsy when I was eight. The first time it happened, I was in the middle of a spelling test. One moment I was penciling out “metamorphosis,” the next I was on the floor, convulsing. Or so it looked. I remember what it felt like, though: like being pulled backward through a waterfall made of memory and light, watching the classroom fade as I hovered somewhere above it all, detached and weightless.

They called an ambulance, and the doctors ran every test imaginable. EEGs, MRIs, sleep studies. Nothing abnormal. Eventually, they labeled it a seizure disorder and prescribed medication. I took it for years, and when the events didn’t stop, they just upped the dosage. But the truth is, my problem isn’t electrical or chemical. It’s metaphysical.

Of course, no one believes that. You tell someone your soul is trying to escape your body and they either laugh or call for psychiatric help. I've seen both reactions. My therapist once suggested dissociative episodes. Another thought I had an extreme form of panic disorder. But I know what I feel. I know what I see.

When it happens, I don’t just lose consciousness—I become two. There’s the body, slack and vulnerable, and there’s me, hovering just outside it, suspended in some liminal space where time stretches and sound distorts. At first, I was terrified. I thought I was dying. Now, years later, I’m still terrified—but I’ve learned to fight.

It takes everything I have to force myself back in. It’s not a matter of willpower alone; it’s like swimming upstream through molasses. I anchor myself with thoughts of the physical world—my name, my heartbeat, the smell of rain on pavement, the warmth of my mother’s hands. Anything visceral, anything real. If I let go, if I stop fighting, I’ll drift too far to return.

And then I’ll be gone.

The worst part? It’s getting more frequent.

When I was younger, it happened maybe once or twice a year. Then it became every few months. Now, it’s weekly, sometimes more. I can’t hold down a job for long. Who wants to employ someone who might collapse in the middle of a meeting, twitching and unresponsive? I tried working from home, but even staring at a screen doesn’t prevent the pull. It doesn’t care where I am or what I’m doing. It just... happens.

I’ve tried all kinds of things to ground myself. Meditation, which ironically makes it worse. Caffeine, which makes my heart flutter and fills me with anxiety but doesn’t stop the detachment. I wear tight bracelets, carry stones in my pockets, use essential oils—anything to keep me here, present. Nothing works reliably.

One time, I was riding the subway when it hit. The crowd around me blurred, and I felt myself begin to unravel. I managed to grip the metal pole with both hands, clenching my jaw, trying to breathe through it. But it was too strong that time. I fell to the floor between stops. A woman screamed. Someone else called 911. When I came to, paramedics were hovering over me, defibrillator at the ready. They thought I’d gone into cardiac arrest.

I wanted to laugh. Or cry. Maybe both.

Whenever I return, I feel raw. Like my insides have been scraped with sandpaper. Emotionally, I’m wrecked. Physically, I ache. My muscles feel like I’ve run a marathon, though I’ve barely moved. And always, always, there’s the lingering fear: what if I don’t come back next time?

I started keeping a journal. Not just to track the events, but to remind myself that I’m still here. Still tethered. Sometimes I draw spirals—tight ones when I feel grounded, loose and fragmented when I feel the pull. The pages are filled with frantic scrawlings, desperate affirmations. “I am real. I am here. I am whole.”

I've stopped trying to explain it to people. I let them believe it's a medical condition. It’s easier that way. At least they have a frame of reference—seizure, heart attack, fainting spell. They don’t see the truth: that I’m losing myself, piece by piece, to something I can’t name.

Still, I search for answers.

I’ve read ancient texts, consulted mystics, spoken to people who claim to understand the soul. Some say I’m cursed. Others believe I’m gifted—able to travel between realms. That would almost be comforting, if it weren’t so involuntary. If I had any control. But I don’t. I’m like a balloon with a fraying string, floating ever higher, ever closer to snapping.

There was one man, a reclusive scholar who lived in the mountains of New Mexico, who told me something that stuck. He said, “You must find your anchor, or you will drift forever.” When I asked him what that meant, he just looked at me with tired eyes and said, “The body is not the home. The soul is. But without the body, the soul forgets.”

I think about that a lot.

Maybe that’s what this is about—learning not just how to stay, but why I want to. Maybe I need to build a life so rooted, so meaningful, that my soul won’t want to leave. Maybe I need to find love, or purpose, or something larger than fear to hold me here.

Or maybe it’s just a matter of time before the tether snaps.

Until then, I fight.

Every day, I fight to stay grounded. I breathe deep. I speak my name aloud. I touch the world—rough bark, cold glass, warm skin—anything to remind myself that I am still here. Still whole. Still alive.

Because when your soul is always on the verge of slipping away, life becomes a constant battle between presence and oblivion. And I don’t want to be a ghost before I’m dead.

samples.prompt: Memories are finicky things. They hold what makes us who we are, yet they constantly shift and degrade, especially the more we think on them. True photographic memory has always been a myth, until now. You finally understand why, too. The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.
samples.output:
Memories are finicky things. They shift, morph, and fade over time, like ink on old parchment left in the sun too long. We cling to them, polish them, retell them, sometimes even rewrite them whether we know it or not. They are the puzzle pieces of who we are—our beliefs, our fears, our joys—all built from the intricate mosaic of what we remember. But for all their importance, memories are inherently unreliable. We forget names, misplace details, confuse timelines. Scientists have long suspected that true photographic memory—the kind that recalls every detail with perfect clarity—is a myth. And for most of history, they were right.

Until now.

It started subtly. A few people began reporting unusually vivid recollections. At first, it was dismissed as hyperthymesia, an extremely rare condition where individuals can remember every day of their lives with uncanny precision. But it wasn’t just dates or events they remembered. It was everything. The exact pitch of a bird's song on a spring morning twenty years ago. The pattern of dust on a forgotten windowsill. The smell of a pastry their grandmother baked once, decades before. Every detail, every sensory input, perfectly preserved.

Then it spread.

People who had never experienced such clarity before began waking up with memories that refused to fade. Students could recite entire textbooks after a single read. Musicians replayed entire symphonies from memory after one performance. Trauma survivors found themselves reliving their darkest moments with unbearable intensity, as if no time had passed at all. It was as if something had flipped a switch in the collective human mind, unlocking a potential that had always been there, dormant.

That’s when I began to understand.

I work in neurocognitive research, specializing in memory formation and retention. For years, I had been chasing the mechanisms that determine why some memories stick and others vanish. I thought the brain was simply inefficient, that the degradation of memory was a weakness. A flaw. But the more I studied the phenomenon of these new, perfect memories, the more I began to realize the truth.

The degradation was never a fault. It was our only defense.

The human brain, remarkable as it is, is not infinite. It processes billions of bits of information daily, yet it stores only a fraction. This selective retention was believed to be evolutionary—why remember the exact color of the grass on a Tuesday afternoon when your life depends on remembering where the predator lives? But that’s only part of it.

The real reason, I found, is more chilling.

Our minds are not just repositories for the past; they are battlegrounds for the present. Memories are not static—they influence our decisions, our emotions, our sense of reality. A perfect memory, one that never fades or distorts, begins to take on a life of its own. It ceases to be a recollection and becomes a presence. You don’t just remember what happened—you relive it. Again and again. With the same intensity, the same emotional weight. Over time, these perfect memories begin to crowd out the present, like ivy choking a tree.

I saw it happen to my colleague, Dr. Patel. He had been one of the first to show signs of enhanced recall. At first, he was elated. He remembered every paper he’d ever read, every lecture he’d ever given. His productivity soared. But then came the nightmares—except they weren’t dreams. They were memories. Vivid, inescapable. He began to mix past and present, reacting to old arguments as if they were happening now, mourning losses that had long since healed. He couldn’t move on, because nothing was ever truly gone.

And then there were the others. People who remembered every slight, every insult, every failure. The petty grievances of life, normally softened or forgotten with time, became sharp-edged and permanent. Relationships crumbled. Riots broke out in cities where people remembered injustices with crystal clarity. The past was no longer the past. It was alive, and it was angry.

I began to piece it together. The human mind evolved not just to remember, but to forget. Or more accurately—to reshape. Our memories degrade not because we are flawed, but because we are adaptive. We smooth the edges of trauma, blur the sting of rejection, tint the warmth of love with nostalgia. These distortions aren’t lies. They are survival. They allow us to keep going.

With perfect memory, there is no healing. No forgiveness. No growth. Only recurrence.

I traced the origin of the phenomenon to a new class of neural implants—marketed as cognitive enhancers—that had quietly entered the biohacking underground. Initially designed for memory support in Alzheimer's patients, they’d been co-opted, modified, and sold to the public with promises of genius-level recall. What no one realized was that they weren’t enhancing memory—they were removing the natural filters evolution had put in place.

The implants had gone viral, both metaphorically and literally. A nanocode embedded in the devices was transmissible via neural resonance—a form of biological resonance akin to sympathetic vibration. People exposed to others with the implant began to develop the same abilities. It was spreading like a memetic contagion.

And now, the world is unraveling.

Governments are trying to contain the outbreak, but how do you contain an idea? How do you quarantine a memory? Societies built on the ability to forgive and forget are breaking apart under the weight of perfect recollection. Legal systems are overwhelmed by appeals. Marriages collapse under the weight of every remembered mistake. Children grow resentful of every parental misstep, now vivid and undeniable.

I’ve been spared—for now. I never took the implant. My memory is still fragile, still human. But I don’t know for how long. I’ve been exposed. I can already feel it creeping in. I remember what I wore on my fifth birthday. I remember the tremble in my mother’s voice the day my dog died. I remember every syllable of my father's final phone call.

I don’t want to remember.

I want to forget. I want to heal.

So I work, desperate to find a cure—not to restore memory, but to restore forgetting. To bring back distortion. To reintroduce the graceful erosion of time. Because I finally understand that the mind is not a vault, but a garden. And in a garden, not everything can be allowed to grow unchecked. Some things must wither. Some things must rot. Some things must be buried.

Only then can we bloom.

And maybe, just maybe, if we can learn to forget again, we can remember what it means to be human.

samples.prompt: Summoning an Elder God inevitably drives cultists mad. You were expecting tentacles! Parasitic spores! Indescribable shapes and colours! You weren't expecting... this.
samples.output:
When I joined the Esoterica of the Ninth Spiral, I was promised enlightenment, power, and a front-row seat to the end of the world. I was young, naive, and more than a little high on the fumes of forbidden knowledge. I had read the fragments of the Black Codex, whispered the syllables that should not be spoken, and endured the midnight rites in the salt caverns beneath the old church. I had seen things—shadows that moved independently of their source, stars blinking in patterns not found in any constellation chart, and the occasional flicker of a third eye opening in a mirror. I thought I was ready.

I wasn’t.

We had performed the final rite after decades of preparation. The stars were right, the constellations had aligned in a geometry that caused migraines in every astronomer who dared to look up. Our High Priestess, draped in robes woven from human hair and shadows, chanted the sacred verses while the rest of us knelt and bled into a glyph of impossible angles carved into the earth. The air had thickened, heavy as syrup, and the sky had shivered—not just darkened, but actually shivered, like a wet dog emerging from a lake. We were ecstatic. This was what we had worked toward. The coming of the Elder God, the awakening of the Sleeper Between Realms.

And then… it arrived.

I say “it” because no language I possess can label the thing that emerged from the rift. Not because it was too grotesque or hideous. No, that would have made sense. I was prepared for the grotesque. I was ready for the writhing tentacles, the glaring thousand eyes, for my sanity to be yanked out through my ears while I gibbered and screamed into the void.

Instead, what came through was—well, it was Harold.

We didn’t know his name at first. He told us later. He stepped out of the rift wearing beige slacks, a polo shirt tucked into them neatly, and a pair of sensible loafers. He was holding a lukewarm cup of coffee in a paper cup that bore the logo of a cosmic café none of us had ever heard of: “Bean Me Up.”

He blinked in the sunlight, looked around at the circle of robed cultists bleeding in reverent awe, and said, “Oh, shoot. Did I take a wrong turn at the Nebula of Infinite Regret again?”

Nobody spoke. We were too stunned. Harold, for his part, looked mildly embarrassed. He muttered something about needing to update the GPS on his ‘dimensional traversal badge’ and then offered us a polite smile.

The High Priestess, still poised with arms raised dramatically, asked in a trembling voice, “Are you… the Sleeper Between Realms?”

“Oh, dear, no,” Harold said with a chuckle. “I’m Harold. Regional Manager of the Department of Existential Logistics. I’m mostly in charge of making sure entropy flows properly and that nobody accidentally creates a recursive timeline that eats its own tail. This,” he gestured at the rift behind him, which shimmered like a soap bubble about to pop, “is not my usual route. You folks really ought to put up a sign.”

One of our newer initiates fainted. Another began to cry. I couldn’t blame them. We had spent our entire lives preparing to welcome an unnameable horror whose mere presence would unravel the minds of men. And instead, we got Harold. Who, as it turned out, was very fond of dad jokes and carried a laminated card titled “Ten Fun Facts About the Multiverse.”

We didn’t know what to do. Technically, we had succeeded. We had summoned an entity from beyond the veil, a being not of this universe. But it was like expecting to summon a volcano and getting a warm cup of tea instead. It left us… unmoored.

Over the following days, Harold stuck around. He was polite, if a bit socially awkward. He helped patch up the glyph we’d damaged during the ritual. He offered to re-organize our library of forbidden tomes, citing a “deep love of Dewey Decimal systems.” He even gave a seminar on the dangers of summoning actual Elder Gods, complete with a PowerPoint presentation titled “So You Want to End the World? Think Again!”

The madness didn’t come from sights too terrible to behold or from knowledge too vast to comprehend. It came from the banality of it all. Harold wasn’t terrifying. He wasn’t divine. He was bureaucratic.

One by one, my fellow cultists began to lose their minds—not in the traditional sense, but in a slow, creeping existential unraveling. Marcus, who had once gouged out his own eyes to better ‘see the hidden truths,’ now spent his days binge-watching soap operas. The High Priestess took up knitting. She makes very nice scarves now and sells them on Etsy. Timothy, who had once summoned a minor demon to possess his cat, started a podcast about regional cheeses.

As for me, I tried to hold on. I tried to continue the work. I even attempted to re-summon something more appropriately horrifying. But every time I so much as opened the Necronomicon, Harold would pop his head in and say, “You’re not trying to open a planar rift without proper authorization, are you?”

It’s hard to invoke cosmic dread under the watchful eye of someone who insists on quarterly safety audits.

Eventually, I gave in.

I started helping Harold with his paperwork. I now manage a small subsection of his department, mostly dealing with misplaced souls and minor ontological anomalies. It’s not glamorous work, but it’s stable. I have a 401(k). We get dental.

Sometimes, late at night, I sit at my desk and stare at the old glyphs carved into the stone floor. I remember what it felt like to believe in something immense and terrible, to think that I would be part of a grand and terrifying purpose. There was a kind of romance in it, a dark poetry to the insanity. But that’s all gone now.

Harold still visits occasionally. He always brings coffee and donuts. He tells us stories from other universes—none of which are particularly exciting, but he tells them with such earnestness that we always listen. He once told us about a dimension made entirely of sentient yogurt. Another time, he described a planet where the dominant lifeform is an angry cloud of bees that communicate through interpretive dance.

It’s not what I expected. It’s not what any of us expected.

But maybe that’s the real horror—not the grotesque, not the unknowable, but the realization that the universe is governed not by madness or malice, but by bureaucracy. That beyond the veil of reality there is not chaos or eldritch terror, but paperwork.

And Harold.

Always Harold.

samples.prompt: Your boss is a jerk and your job is stressful, so you call in sick and book a reservation for an extra-long weekend at a resort on a tiny island - and notice your boss is on the plane too! And if that wasn’t bad enough, you just noticed they seem to be travelling with your spiteful Ex.
samples.output:
The airport was bustling with the usual mix of chaos and anticipation as I wheeled my carry-on toward Gate 23. I'd called in sick that morning, faking a sore throat and a hint of a cough, just enough to make it sound convincing but not melodramatic. I’d even gone so far as to send a follow-up email peppered with phrases like “taking this time to rest” and “hope to be back to 100% soon.” Lies, of course. I wasn’t sick—I was emotionally exhausted, burnt out, and frankly, fed up with the daily grind, especially with my boss, Martin.

Martin was the kind of man who wore his authority like an ill-fitting suit—loud, uncomfortable, and always wrinkled with disdain. He took joy in micromanaging, never offering praise but always hovering like a storm cloud, ready to pour criticism over the smallest misstep. The final straw had come two days ago when he publicly berated me in front of the team for a typo in a client email. A typo. One letter off, and suddenly I was the village idiot in his kingdom of inflated egos.

So, I’d done what any rational adult on the verge of an emotional breakdown would do: impulsively booked four nights at a luxurious resort on a remote island, the kind of place where coconut drinks appear magically in your hand and no one asks about your KPIs. Sun, sand, and silence—that was the plan. A private escape from the noise of my life.

Boarding began, and I shuffled forward, already mentally sipping a piña colada. I found my seat—23A, window, just as I’d hoped—and settled in, plugging in my headphones and closing my eyes. I pictured the waves, the soft hum of island birds, the scent of salt in the air. I was halfway to inner peace when I heard a voice that made my stomach drop.

“Excuse me, I think that’s my seat.”

I opened my eyes, and there he was—Martin. In khakis and a linen shirt, looking oddly relaxed for someone who usually dressed like a villain from a corporate training video. His eyes widened when he saw me, and for a brief moment, we both froze.

“You’re—” he started.

“Sick,” I said quickly. “Was. Feeling better. Doctor said fresh air might help.”

It was a weak save, and we both knew it, but Martin just nodded slowly, a smirk tugging at the corners of his mouth. He slipped into the seat beside me—23B. Of course. Of all the planes, of all the islands, of all the seats next to all the windows, he had to be in mine.

I turned back to the window, praying this would be the worst of it. The universe, however, wasn’t done with me yet.

A moment later, a familiar laugh rang out from the aisle. I turned just in time to see her—Samantha. My ex. The ex. The one who had once told me I “lacked ambition” because I preferred nights in with a book instead of networking events and social climbing. She had a talent for finding your deepest insecurities and weaving them into casual conversation like it was small talk. 

And there she was, tossing her glossy hair over one shoulder, laughing at something Martin had just said.

“Babe, I grabbed your favorite snack from the lounge,” she said, holding out a tiny bag of pretzels. “They had the good kind.”

Babe?

Martin took the pretzels with a grin and leaned in to kiss her cheek. She slid into the seat behind us. Directly behind me.

I sat frozen, trying to process the absurdity of it all. My tyrannical boss and my emotionally manipulative ex were a couple. On the same flight. To the same island. While I was “out sick.” I resisted the urge to claw open the exit door and hurl myself into the stratosphere.

Martin turned to me, clearly enjoying the situation now. “Small world, huh?”

“Shrinking by the second,” I muttered.

The flight dragged on for what felt like a week. Every time I tried to relax, I’d hear Samantha’s voice behind me, recounting some story meant to highlight how successful and amazing Martin was. I didn’t know if it was intentional or if she just hadn’t changed, but it was like nails on a chalkboard. Occasionally, Martin would lean back and respond, and they’d laugh together, the sound grating against my last nerve.

By the time we landed, I was a cocktail of emotions: frustration, disbelief, and a tinge of humiliation. I waited until they’d disembarked before grabbing my bag and heading down the jet bridge, hoping I could lose them at customs.

No such luck.
