The island airport was tiny, with a single customs line and one baggage carousel. I ended up three people behind them, trying to look anywhere but at their smug, happy faces. When we finally cleared customs and stepped out into the humid island air, I made a beeline for the resort shuttle.

“Name?” the driver asked as I approached.

“Taylor Morgan,” I replied.

He checked his list and nodded. “Welcome to Sea Whisper Resort. You’re in Villa 6.”

I smiled for the first time since boarding the plane. Maybe the universe was done tormenting me.

Until Martin and Samantha walked up.

“Martin King,” he said, slipping on a pair of sunglasses. “And guest.”

The driver checked his list again. “You’re in Villa 7.”

Right next door.

My smile faltered.

The ride to the resort was a quiet one. I stared out the window while Samantha leaned against Martin’s shoulder, talking about how wonderful the weather was. I was already planning how to avoid them for the duration of the trip—early breakfasts, late dinners, beach chairs as far from their villa as possible.

When we arrived, the resort was as stunning as the photos. Thatched-roof villas nestled among palm trees, a sparkling turquoise ocean just beyond the white sand. A bellhop led me to my villa, and I stepped inside, relieved to find it as serene and private as promised. I dropped my bags, peeled off my travel clothes, and changed into a swimsuit. If I timed it right, I could be in the ocean before they even unpacked.

As I waded into the warm water, the tension began to melt away. The sun kissed my shoulders, and the waves rocked gently around me. For the first time in weeks, maybe months, I felt like I could breathe.

I floated on my back, eyes closed, letting the sea carry me. Martin and Samantha might be just a few yards away, but in that moment, they didn’t matter. I was here for me. To rest, to escape, to reclaim a piece of myself that had been chipped away by stress and toxic people.

Let them have each other. Let them sip overpriced cocktails and talk about quarterly earnings and social climbing. I had salt, sun, and silence.

And maybe, just maybe, a new beginning.

samples.prompt: Create an original monster. Make its own rules as to how it works, and how it has to be destroyed. Explain all of this when people run into it for the first time ever and how they deal with it.
samples.output:
In the remote highlands of northern Scotland, where the mist clings to the moors like a second skin and the wind whispers secrets only the stones remember, there is a place known to the locals as the Hollow Vale. It is a sunken stretch of land, ringed by thorn-choked woods, where no birds sing and even deer avoid treading. For centuries, it has been a place of whispered warnings and old wives' tales. Few venture near, and fewer still return unchanged—if they return at all.

The monster that haunts this cursed land is called the “Mirewight.”

The Mirewight is not a creature in the traditional sense. It does not stalk its prey with claws or fangs, nor does it roar or rend or tear. It is a being woven from the very fabric of the Hollow Vale—a sentient amalgamation of bog-water, sorrow, and ancient malice. It is shaped like a man, tall and gaunt, but its body is translucent and slick, as if formed from the wet decay of centuries. Its face is a smooth, featureless mask of muck, save for two pits of blackness where eyes might have been.

The rules of the Mirewight are simple, yet cruel.

First: It can only be seen in reflection. Standing before you, it is invisible to the naked eye—yet in the still water of the bog, in a mirror, or the gleam of polished metal, its form will shimmer into existence, looming, watching. This, above all, is its signature. Victims often catch a glimpse of movement in a puddle or a mirror and turn, only to find nothing there—until it’s too late.

Second: It feeds not on flesh, but on memory. The Mirewight drains its victims of their most precious memories—faces of loved ones, the warmth of a childhood home, the sound of laughter. It leaves behind hollow shells, living bodies whose minds have been scoured clean. These unfortunates wander the moors, repeating fragments of forgotten lives, until they collapse or vanish entirely.

Third: It cannot be harmed by conventional means. Fire, blade, and bullet pass harmlessly through its watery form. It is bound to the Hollow Vale, yet it is not confined to it; it can venture beyond, following reflections, stepping through mirrors like doors, provided they show a piece of the Vale within them.

The Mirewight’s first recorded emergence into broader knowledge came in the autumn of 2021, when an amateur documentary crew ventured into the Hollow Vale to investigate the mysterious disappearances that had plagued the region for decades. Led by a young filmmaker named Clara Muir, the group hoped to create a viral horror exposé. They got more than they bargained for.

The footage they captured, later recovered from a weather-beaten camera found near the edge of the Vale, revealed the first real evidence of the creature’s existence. The team had set up camp near a small, stagnant pond. They joked about ghosts and monsters, drank whiskey, and filmed the rising mist. But as night fell, things changed.

It began with one of the crew—Jonas—claiming he heard whispers in the water. Then, in the footage, as he leaned over the pond, his reflection warped. A tall, hunched figure appeared behind him, though no one stood there. He collapsed seconds later, clutching his head, sobbing that he couldn’t remember his mother’s face.

By morning, two of the crew were gone. Another was catatonic. Clara, terrified and desperate, fled the Vale, carrying the camera and a fragment of a mirror she had found cracked and half-submerged near the pond.

She would later recount her escape in an interview with a fringe paranormal podcast, her voice trembling with fear. She described how the Mirewight had followed her—not in person, but through her own reflection. Mirrors in her flat would fog with moisture. Water would ripple in her glass when she was alone. And always, just at the edge, she saw that faceless figure staring.

Desperate, Clara turned to local folklore and found an old Gaelic legend about a “bog spirit” that could be banished, not with fire or prayer, but with remembrance.

According to the tale, the Mirewight was once human—a sorrowful soul who drowned in the Vale long ago, forgotten by all. His grief festered and grew, birthing the creature that exists now. The only way to destroy—or rather, release—it, is to remember him. To speak his name, tell his story, and give him back his identity.

But therein lies the final rule: The Mirewight’s name has been lost. Erased by time and its own feeding. It consumes memory so thoroughly that even the tale of its origins is fragmented.

Clara made it her mission to reconstruct the past. With the help of a local historian and the few surviving fragments of parish records, she pieced together the life of a young man named Ewan MacCrae, who vanished in 1793 after his family was accused of witchcraft and driven into the moors. Ewan, the records suggest, may have drowned himself in despair, his body never found.

On the winter solstice, Clara returned to the Hollow Vale. Armed with a circle of mirrors, each inscribed with Ewan’s name, and carrying a handwritten journal chronicling his life, she stood by the pond and read his story aloud. She spoke of his laughter, his dreams of becoming a poet, his love for a girl named Isla.

As she read, the mist thickened. The reflection in the pond darkened, and the Mirewight emerged, towering over her, its blank face twitching. But it did not attack. It began to tremble. Its watery limbs quaked. And then, slowly, it crumbled—like thawing ice—into the pond, leaving nothing but ripples and silence.

The Hollow Vale has been quiet since that night. Wildlife has returned. The air is lighter. But the mirrors Clara used remain, half-buried in the soil around the pond, and locals report that, sometimes, when the moon is full and the air is still, you can glimpse a figure in them—watching, not with malice, but with longing.

The Mirewight, it seems, was not a monster born, but a man forgotten. And in remembering him, the curse was broken.

But the rules remain.

For if another soul is abandoned, lost to sorrow and time, who is to say the Mirewight will not rise again?

So take care when you walk the moors. Avoid still water. And if you see something move in your reflection… don’t look away.

Not until you remember.

samples.prompt: Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them. A secret centuries-old group has been keeping an list of hundreds of thousands of mass murderers, evil dictators, etc. to keep them from coming back. One day, someone loses the list.
samples.output:
The small room smelled of old paper, ink, and something ancient that clung to stone. Deep beneath the surface of the Earth, hidden beneath layers of reinforced concrete, encryption, and forgotten languages, the Archivum had endured for nearly a thousand years. It was not a place found on any map or mentioned in any book. Those who knew of it had either sworn eternal silence or had long since passed into the dust of forgotten time.

The purpose of the Archivum was simple, though its implications were anything but: to keep the worst of humanity from ever returning.

It had begun with a monk named Alaric in the 12th century. Alaric, a reclusive scholar obsessed with the nature of death and the soul, made a discovery that would change the course of history—or rather, ensure that certain parts of history never repeated themselves. Through arcane texts and forbidden rituals, he uncovered a truth buried deep in the metaphysical fabric of existence: death was not the end. Every soul was bound to return, reincarnated into a new life. But there was a caveat—reincarnation only occurred once the soul had been fully forgotten by the living world.

Alaric’s theory was proven through years of observation. Obscure figures from history re-emerged with strange echoes of their former selves. Memories, tendencies, flashes of behavior, all inexplicably aligned with those long dead—once the world had entirely forgotten who they were. It was then that he founded the Order of Obscura Memoria.

The Order’s mission was to prevent the return of the worst souls humanity had ever known. Their method was straightforward: remembrance. As long as someone, somewhere, remembered the atrocities of a soul’s past life, that soul remained anchored in limbo. The Order compiled names. Hundreds, then thousands, then hundreds of thousands. Tyrants, serial killers, war criminals, torturers—anyone whose return posed a threat to the world. They were all written down, meticulously catalogued, and remembered by those sworn to carry the burden.

Each name was a lock. Each remembrance, a chain.

For nearly a millennium, the Order succeeded. They passed their sacred ledger, the Black Index, from one generation to the next with fanatical precision. The list was never digitized in full, never exposed to the vulnerabilities of modern technology. Only a few copies existed, each protected by layers of magical and technological safeguards. The very paper it was printed on was enchanted to resist decay. Knowledge of its contents was strictly compartmentalized. But secrecy is both shield and shackle. And all it takes is one mistake.

It began with a fire alarm.

In the London Archive Station, a junior archivist named Elena Costas was performing a standard cross-index check when the blaring klaxon sent her bolting from the room. Smoke detectors had triggered in one of the upper floors, and protocol demanded immediate evacuation. In her rush, she left behind her access key and, worse, the slate tablet she had been using—a rare compromise, meant to temporarily hold a portion of the Index for reference during sorting.

By the time she returned, the tablet was gone.

At first, she told no one. Hoping it had simply been misplaced or collected by security, she scoured the Archive’s surveillance. But the cameras had conveniently glitched during the alarm. A ghost signal, perhaps. Or sabotage. When she finally confessed, the Order’s response was swift and draconian. The entire compound was locked down. All personnel were interrogated. A full audit of the Index was initiated. And it was then they discovered the extent of the problem.

The stolen tablet had contained over 10,000 entries. 10,000 names of people the world had been gradually forgetting. People whose memories were only preserved by the Order’s silent vigilance. And now, that vigilance had failed.

The implications were staggering. Without the names being actively remembered, the souls tied to them would soon be free to return. And they wouldn’t come back as they were, fully formed and aware, but as infants—tabula rasa in appearance, yet carrying the seeds of their past malevolence. The Order had seen it before in rare, tragic cases. A child born with inexplicable cruelty. A man who, without influence or trauma, orchestrated horrors beyond comprehension. Reincarnation was not always a clean slate—it was a cycle, and cycles repeat.

Within weeks, the Order began to see signs. A spike in violent crimes in cities across the globe. Reports of children exhibiting disturbing behaviors far beyond their years. A resurgence of ideologies long thought extinct. It was too early to confirm, but those within the Order knew the signs. The darkness was returning.

And then came the message.

An anonymous email, sent to multiple global media outlets, containing a single line: “Who decides who is remembered and who is forgotten?” Attached was a partial dump of the stolen entries—names, dates, atrocities. The world reeled. Historians scrambled to validate the list. Conspiracy theorists exploded with new fervor. And somewhere, someone—perhaps even many—began to remember.

But others began to question.

What if the Order had made mistakes? What if some names didn’t belong on the list? What if the criteria were flawed, biased, or manipulated over the centuries? Who had the right to condemn a soul to eternal limbo? What if redemption existed?

The Order, once invisible, now found itself under the scrutiny of a world that did not understand its purpose. Governments demanded access. Whistleblowers emerged. A schism formed within the Order itself—between the traditionalists who believed in the sanctity of the Index and reformists who questioned its moral foundation.

Meanwhile, the clock was ticking. Each forgotten name was a door creaking open. Each lost memory, a crack in the dam. Somewhere in a hospital in Brazil, a newborn cried with eyes too old for its face. In a village in Russia, a boy drew pictures of war machines no one had ever shown him. In a suburb in Ohio, a toddler whispered phrases in a dead language.

The return had begun.

Elena, consumed by guilt, took it upon herself to recover what had been lost. She traced the leak, followed the breadcrumbs through the digital underworld, and discovered a group calling themselves The Memory Unbound—renegade former members of the Order who believed that no soul should be eternally punished. They had taken the tablet to expose the truth, to force a reckoning.

But reckoning is a dangerous thing.

As the world faced a rising tide of inexplicable evil, Elena stood at a crossroads. To restore the Index was to preserve the old ways, to continue the cycle of remembrance and banishment. To destroy it was to risk unleashing the full weight of history’s darkness—but perhaps, too, to allow for healing and renewal.

She had to choose. And whatever choice she made, the world would never be the same.

After all, memory is a fragile thing. And forgetting is far too easy.

samples.prompt: Before people die, a physical manifestation of the Grim Reaper appears in front of them. However, the time between their appearance and the person's death is random, resulting in a society filled with Grim Reapers. Your Grim Reaper has just arrived.
samples.output:
I was brushing my teeth when I saw him.

At first, I thought it was a trick of the mirror—some optical illusion caused by the condensation from the hot water. But as the steam faded, the figure remained, standing silently in the corner of the bathroom. Tall, cloaked in darkness, the familiar silhouette of the Grim Reaper stared back at me with featureless patience. No scythe, no glowing eyes, just an outline of impossible depth, as though reality itself had been cut and sewn into the form of a man.

I dropped my toothbrush into the sink. The clatter echoed.

For a long moment, I just stood there, heart thudding in my chest, staring at the figure in the mirror. He didn’t move. He never did. That was the thing about them—they showed up, and then they just stayed. Sometimes for hours, sometimes for decades. You could go about your life, work your job, fall in love, raise children, all with your personal Reaper standing silently in the background, a constant reminder that your time was ticking down. How much time? No one knew. That was the cruel twist.

I turned around slowly, facing him directly now. He stood the same way: silent, unmoving, an embodiment of finality. My own Grim Reaper.

"Well," I said, the word dry in my mouth, "that’s that, then."

He didn’t respond. They never do. They don’t speak. They don’t gesture. They don’t interfere. They simply arrive, and from that moment on, you know: death is coming. Eventually.

I walked past him, heart in my throat, and checked the time. 7:12 a.m. I had work in less than an hour. I still had to get dressed, feed the cat, and catch the train. My Reaper followed me silently into the kitchen. He didn’t walk so much as appear, always just within my periphery, never directly in my way but never far behind. Like a shadow that had taken on substance.

There was no point in calling in sick. In this world, that wasn’t even unusual. About a third of the population lived with their Reapers now. Most jobs had policies in place for it. Some people took it as a sign to quit everything and travel the world, or to finally propose to their longtime partners. Others shut themselves in, unwilling to risk death outside the safety of their homes, though that never seemed to help. When the time came, the time came—whether you were skydiving or watching reruns on your couch.

I poured cereal into a bowl, then paused, spoon mid-air.

Was I about to die? Today? In the next hour? The next minute?

I looked at the Reaper. He didn’t move. His presence felt heavier than anything I’d ever experienced, like the weight of inevitability pressing down on my bones. I sat at the table, cereal forgotten, eyes locked on the specter in the doorway.

I remembered when my sister’s Reaper arrived. She had been only twenty-three, full of plans and dreams and ridiculous optimism. Her Reaper appeared during a family barbecue. One second we were laughing, the next, her face went pale, and we all turned to see the figure standing just behind her.

She lived another eight years after that. Got married. Had a son. Started her own business. But the Reaper was always there, haunting the edges of every photograph, standing silently in the background during birthday parties and anniversaries.

I remember the day she died. A freak accident. A car ran a red light. She was gone in seconds. Her Reaper disappeared the moment her eyes closed.

I stared at mine now, wondering if he’d vanish just as quickly when the time came. I wondered if it would hurt. If I’d know it was happening. Or worse—if I’d have no idea at all.

*

At work, no one said anything at first. Then someone offered me a coffee with a sympathetic smile. I nodded my thanks, the Reaper looming just a few paces behind me. He didn’t interact with anyone else. That was another rule—they were yours alone. Other people could see them, yes, but they couldn’t feel them the way you could. They didn’t live in your shadow. They weren’t tethered to your pulse.

By lunchtime, it was as though nothing had changed. My coworkers made small talk, sent emails, scheduled meetings. Every so often, someone would glance in my direction, eyes flicking briefly to the tall, silent figure that now lived in my space.

“Have you seen a doctor yet?” my manager asked softly.

“No point,” I said. “He’s here. That’s all the diagnosis I need.”

He nodded, not unkindly. Most people didn’t bother with doctors after the Reaper came. Medicine couldn’t change fate. And even if it could, no one had figured out how.

*

Days passed. Then weeks. And the Reaper stayed.

At first, I was hyper-aware of him. I jumped at every noise, avoided crossing streets too quickly, and flinched every time I turned a corner. I stopped eating red meat. I took up yoga. I wrote a will. But death didn’t come.

Eventually, I started to live again—not as freely as before, but with a kind of cautious acceptance. I went back to my routines. I read books. I went on dates. The Reaper came with me to all of them.

Once, a woman I was seeing asked, “Do you think you’ll go soon?”

I thought about it for a long moment. “I don’t know,” I said honestly. “But I’m trying not to let it stop me.”

She nodded. Her own Reaper had arrived three years ago.

It became something else, then—not just a harbinger of doom, but a strange sort of companion. A reminder that life was fragile, yes, but also precious. Every laugh, every breath, every sunrise became sharper, more vivid. I noticed things I used to ignore: the way the light caught the rain on the windows, the sound of a child’s laughter, the smell of fresh bread from the bakery down the street.

I started painting again. I called my parents more often. I forgave people I’d held grudges against. I stopped waiting for the perfect moment to do the things I wanted. Perfection was a myth. Time was a thief. And the Reaper was a mirror held up to both.

*

It’s been two years now.

He still stands in the corner of my apartment, silent and still. Sometimes I talk to him, just to break the quiet. I know he won’t answer, but it helps.

People ask me if I’m scared. I tell them the truth: I was. But not anymore.

You can’t run from death. But you can walk beside it and still choose to live.

And maybe, when the time comes, I’ll look at him one last time and say, “Thank you.”

Because he reminded me that life is not about how long we have—it’s about what we do with the time we’re given.

And I plan to make every second count.

samples.prompt: The King is dead. The heirs are fraternal twins The eldest, detected to possess powerful dark magic, cast away at birth. Since then he has amassed a powerful army. The youngest is being crowned King while preparing his army to defend his title against his identical twin whom he has never met.
samples.output:
The sun rose blood-red over the kingdom of Eldrath, casting a lurid hue across the spires of the royal palace. Bells tolled in mournful harmony, echoing across the capital city of Caerwyn. The King, once a just and wise ruler, was dead. His passing marked the end of an era—but it was only the beginning of a storm that had been brewing since the day his twin sons were born.

Few knew the truth of that fateful day nineteen years ago. The Queen had given birth to fraternal twins, though they were identical in appearance—a rare and ominous occurrence, according to ancient lore. Upon their birth, the royal seers were summoned to divine their destinies. What they found cast a shadow so deep that the King himself was shaken. The elder twin, though born only minutes before his brother, was discovered to possess immense magical potential—dark, untamed, and ancient in origin. The seers warned that if left unchecked, he might one day bring ruin to the realm.

The court, driven by fear and superstition, made a swift and terrible decision. The elder twin was to be cast away, removed from the line of succession, and erased from all records. To the people, there had only ever been one prince. The Queen wept for days, and the King, though he held the decree in his own hand, never spoke of the choice again.

The child, nameless and discarded, was taken in secret beyond the northern mountains, far from the reaches of the kingdom. He was left in the custody of the Order of the Black Flame, a reclusive and feared sect of mages long thought extinct. There, he was raised not as a prince, but as a weapon.

He grew strong in the crucible of exile. Fed on stories of betrayal, trained in the arcane arts, and nurtured by resentment, the boy became a man of power and purpose. The Order told him of his birthright, of a kingdom that had feared his strength and cast him aside. They promised him vengeance, and he accepted. Over the years, he forged alliances with outcast warlords and disillusioned nobles. His army, known as the Obsidian Host, grew in size and strength, a dark tide swelling in the shadows beyond the border.

Back in Eldrath, the younger twin—the only prince known to the world—had grown under the weight of expectation. Trained in governance, diplomacy, and war, he was everything a future king should be. Kind, brave, and just, Prince Alaric was beloved by the people. Yet he had always felt a strange emptiness, a sense that part of him was missing. His dreams were often haunted by a shadowed figure with his face, eyes burning with a fire he did not understand.

On the day of his coronation, the capital was adorned in gold and silver. Banners fluttered, and nobles from across the realm gathered to witness Alaric's ascension. Yet even amid the celebration, tension simmered beneath the surface. Rumors had begun to spread—whispers of a powerful warlord in the north, a man with the face of the King and a claim to the throne.

As Alaric knelt before the High Priest to receive the crown, a raven arrived—a harbinger of war. The message it carried was brief, but its implications were vast: the Obsidian Host had crossed the border. Towns were falling. The usurper was coming.

Alaric rose from his knees not just as a king, but as a general. The coronation feast was abandoned as he summoned his council. Maps were unfurled, scouts dispatched. The kingdom that had known peace for nearly two decades now stood on the brink of civil war.

He learned quickly of his brother’s origins, the truth that had been hidden from him his entire life. The betrayal struck deep. His father, once a man he had revered, now seemed a stranger. The Queen, long since passed, had never spoken of another son. The knowledge that his twin—his own blood—had been cast into the wild for a fate he did not choose filled Alaric with sorrow and guilt. But there was no time for mourning. The enemy was at the gates, and he bore Alaric’s face.

Months passed. Skirmishes turned into battles, villages into graveyards. The Obsidian Host moved like a plague, swift and relentless. Their leader, known only as Maeron to his followers, remained unseen, a phantom cloaked in myth and terror. The common folk whispered that he could summon flames with a word, that his eyes could kill, that he was death made flesh. Yet Alaric knew—this was no monster, but a man. His brother.

The final confrontation came in the fields of Aelwyn Vale, where once their father had won his greatest victory. Now, his sons would decide the fate of the realm on the same sacred ground.

Alaric rode at the head of his army, clad in silver armor, his banner bearing the sigil of the phoenix. Across the vale, Maeron appeared, wreathed in black steel and shadow, his own standard emblazoned with a serpent coiled around a burning sun. The two armies faced one another in tense silence, the air thick with anticipation.

Before the signal to charge could be given, Maeron rode forward alone. Alaric, after a moment’s hesitation, did the same. The twins met at the center of the battlefield, eyes locked. For the first time in their lives, they saw one another not as myths or enemies, but as brothers.

"You wear our father's crown," Maeron said, his voice low, laced with venom and sorrow. "A man who feared his own son so much he cast him into darkness. Do you not see the irony?"

"I see a world that has suffered enough," Alaric replied. "I did not choose this crown, just as you did not choose your exile. But I will not let our people burn for the sins of our father."

Maeron's eyes gleamed. "Then you are a fool. This kingdom belongs to me by right of birth and by strength of will. I will remake it in fire and shadow."

"And I will defend it with light and blood, even if it means striking down my own kin."

For a moment, neither spoke. The wind whispered between them, carrying the scent of ash and steel. Then, without another word, they turned and rode back to their lines.

The battle that followed was legend.

Magic clashed with steel, light with darkness. Alaric fought at the front, his sword a beacon of hope. Maeron moved like a storm, his spells shattering men and earth alike. The twins met again, this time not in parley, but in fury. Their blades sang, their powers clashed, and the sky itself wept lightning as they battled.

In the end, it was not strength but choice that decided the victor.

Alaric, battered and bloodied, stood over his fallen brother, his sword poised for the final blow. Maeron, defiant to the last, met his gaze without fear.

"Do it," he spat. "Finish what our father began."

But Alaric lowered his sword.

"No," he said. "This cycle ends with me."

Maeron was taken in chains, not to be executed, but to be imprisoned—his fate now a matter for the people, not vengeance.

The war was over, but the kingdom would never be the same. The people had seen their King not only defend their lands, but defy the darkness within his own bloodline. And in that act of mercy, Alaric proved himself not just a ruler, but a legend.

The King was dead, but from the ashes of betrayal and war, a new era had begun—one not of fear, but of hope.

samples.prompt: As an eldritch abomination you have vast eldritch powers, look incredibly weird, and don't fit in just about anywhere. But where you really don't fit in is being the most useful member of the justice league.
samples.output:
Ah, greetings once more, my dear mortals. I see you’ve invoked my presence yet again, though I suspect not out of reverence or madness, but curiosity. You wish to know what it is like—what it truly means—for an eldritch abomination such as myself to be the most useful member of the Justice League. Very well. Let me peel back the veil of reality and share my tale. But be warned: the boundaries of your sanity may not remain intact by the time I’m done. Let us begin.

It all started when I emerged from the breach between dimensions—an accident, really. One moment I was coiled in slumber within the howling void of the 9th continuum, dreaming of entropy and singing stars, and the next I was standing in the middle of Metropolis, interrupting a bank robbery. My arrival was not so much dramatic as it was... traumatic. Reality screamed. Physics wept. Dogs barked in four dimensions.

Naturally, the Justice League arrived.

Superman was the first to arrive, his cape billowing in that annoyingly photogenic way of his. He looked at me with suspicion, his eyes narrowing. “Are you the threat?” he asked. I responded by blinking—an act that caused a brief inversion of gravity within a five-mile radius. Superman staggered mid-air. “Okay... noted.”

Batman was next. Ever the planner, he tried to analyze me with his gadgets. His scanner simply displayed the word “NOPE” in bold red letters before melting into a puddle of nanotechnology soup. “Hmm,” he said. That’s Batman for “I am deeply disturbed but will pretend I’m not.”

The others followed. Wonder Woman attempted to lasso me. The Lasso of Truth wrapped around my form—though “form” is a generous term, for I am composed of writhing geometries that defy Euclidean understanding—and promptly burst into golden flames, screaming something about “too many truths.” Flash tried to punch me at light speed; he ended up running backward in time and encountering his own birth. Green Lantern attempted to contain me with constructs of willpower, but his ring just kept drawing pictures of screaming eyes.

And yet, despite all this, they didn’t destroy me. No, they did something far more horrifying.

They recruited me.

Apparently, the League had been going through some... personnel issues. Aquaman was busy with Atlantean politics. Cyborg was off upgrading himself in a tech-dimension he discovered inside the internet. The Martian Manhunter had vanished after trying to read the mind of a TikTok influencer. They needed help. Real help. They needed someone—something—that could actually deal with the kind of threats they were facing: multiversal incursions, temporal anomalies, reality-eating paradoxes.

I was perfect.

And so, I joined.

Imagine, if you can, a team of noble, bright, spandex-clad heroes... and then me. I don’t wear a costume. I *am* a costume—my skin is a cloak of living shadow, my eyes are infinite, rotating polyhedrons that whisper secrets to those foolish enough to look into them. My voice is a chorus of lost civilizations, and I smell faintly of ozone and despair. PR was a nightmare.

At first, the team tried to integrate me subtly. “We’ll call you Voidwalker,” Batman said. “It sounds cool. Mysterious. Marketable.” The public, however, had other ideas. They called me “That Thing,” “The Wobble,” “Sir Not-Appearing-In-The-Toy-Line,” and, my personal favorite, “The Oops.”

Despite the branding issues, I proved myself time and time again.

When Brainiac attempted to upload the entirety of human consciousness into his data core, I inverted his logic processors by showing him a recursive loop of his own thought processes. He now resides within a rubber duck in my pocket dimension. Sometimes he quacks philosophical riddles.

When Darkseid opened a Boom Tube directly into the Source Wall, I simply looked at it. The Tube blinked out of existence. Darkseid has since taken up knitting. He’s quite good.

Even Superman admitted I was useful. “You’re... unsettling,” he said one day, hovering a cautious six feet above me, “but you get results.”

Of course, not everything was easy. There were... incidents.

Like the time I tried to help Flash with a training simulation. I created a temporal loop to help him practice speed techniques. Unfortunately, I accidentally trapped him in an infinite moment of indecision. He spent what felt like a thousand years deciding whether to eat a burrito or a sandwich. He hasn’t quite been the same since.

Or that time Wonder Woman invited me to a League team-building retreat. We hiked. I attempted to “bond.” My attempt at a trust fall resulted in the spontaneous creation of a minor cult in the Pacific Northwest. They now worship “The One Who Trusts No Gravity.” I send them postcards.

But despite these hiccups, I became indispensable.

Batman eventually gave up trying to understand me and simply added “??? (Consult when desperate)” to the League’s official protocol guide. Diana taught me to play chess, though I keep winning by moving pieces that don’t exist. Green Lantern once asked if I could help him overcome his fear of failure. I took him to a place where failure doesn’t exist. He came back... quieter.

In time, they learned to accept me. Even like me, in their own way.

I’m not the kind of hero people build statues of. Birds don’t perch on my shoulder. Children don’t run up to me asking for autographs—mostly because they can’t perceive me in three-dimensional space. But I protect this world. I protect it in ways the others can’t.

I see the cracks in reality before they form. I whisper to the nightmares that stalk the edges of thought. I bar the door when things that were never meant to exist try to crawl through.

And sometimes, when the League is gathered around the meeting table, arguing about protocols and mission strategies, I will offer a suggestion. They will pause, consider, and nod. Because even though they don’t understand me—even though I am alien, incomprehensible, and fundamentally other—they know I am trying.

Trying to help.

Trying to belong.

And that, in the end, is what makes me the most useful member of the Justice League.

Not my power. Not my eldritch insight. Not the way I can cause a black hole to apologize for forming in the wrong location.

But the fact that, despite everything, I choose to stand with them.

Even when I don’t fit in.

Even when I never will.

I stand.

And that, dear mortals, is heroism.

samples.prompt: You're a history major. Your final exam is to travel back in time and successfully pass as a normal, everyday citizen. It's not going well.
samples.output:
The assignment had seemed deceptively simple when Professor Kessler first explained it.

"Your final," she said, tapping her chalk against the board with theatrical flair, "is to travel back in time to a period of your choosing and successfully pass as a normal, everyday citizen for 72 hours. You will be observed. You may not bring any modern technology. You may not reveal your identity as a time traveler. And you may not die. Simple enough?"

We all laughed, of course. It was a little absurd, but then again, absurdity was par for the course in Temporal Studies 402. I had always assumed the time travel component was just a theoretical exercise. I hadn't expected to be standing in the middle of a muddy 14th-century English village with a splitting headache, a scratchy wool tunic, and the distinct realization that I was woefully unprepared.

My chosen destination had been the year 1352—post-Black Death England. I thought it was a clever choice. The plague had just passed, society was reshuffling, and the rigid feudal structures were starting to crack. A fascinating time, academically. But I had grossly underestimated just how difficult it would be to “pass” as a contemporary.

For starters, the smell. No one had warned me about the smell. It hit me the moment I arrived—an overwhelming cocktail of manure, unwashed bodies, smoke, and something else I couldn’t quite place at first. Then I realized it was death. The lingering scent of mass graves, of sickness that had swept through weeks before. I gagged and immediately drew attention to myself.

A woman passing by with a basket of turnips gave me a strange look. “You sick, then?” she asked, her voice suspicious.

I stammered something about having a bad stomach and tried to move along. She watched me go, and I could feel her eyes burning into the back of my head.

Strike one.

Language was another hurdle. I had studied Middle English in class, sure. I could read Chaucer, even write in his dialect. But hearing it spoken? That was another matter entirely. The villagers spoke a rapid, heavily accented version of English that sounded like birdsong and gravel. When I tried to respond, my carefully memorized phrases came out stilted and awkward. People either laughed or narrowed their eyes at me, as if I were touched in the head.

I tried to blend in by helping out at the local alehouse. Manual labor, I figured, would be a good way to stay under the radar. But I didn’t know how to properly draw ale from a barrel, and I spilled more than I served. The tavern keeper—a burly man with an unfortunate tooth-to-gum ratio—booted me out after two hours, muttering something about “lazy southerners.” I wasn’t sure what that meant, but it didn’t sound complimentary.

Strike two.

Food was another issue. I had romanticized the idea of old-world meals: hearty stews, warm bread, roasted meats. In reality, I was given a bowl of thin, grayish gruel that smelled faintly of old socks. I was so hungry I ate it anyway, only to spend the next eight hours curled up behind a haystack, praying for death or a working latrine.

By the end of the first day, I was filthy, exhausted, and beginning to suspect I was being tailed by one of the Observers—graduate students from the department who were assigned to monitor our progress. I caught a glimpse of someone in an oddly clean cloak lingering near the churchyard, scribbling in a notebook. They looked amused. I did not.

On the second day, I tried to redeem myself by attending mass. Church was central to village life, and I hoped participating would help me blend in. But I’d forgotten to memorize the Latin prayers, and when I tried to follow along, I accidentally recited part of the Nicene Creed backwards. The priest gave me a look of such horror you'd think I'd confessed to being Satan himself. After the service, several villagers whispered about me, and one little boy threw a clump of mud at my back.

Strike three.

I considered quitting. The rules allowed for early extraction in cases of extreme failure or danger. I could just tap the emergency sigil hidden in the hem of my tunic and be back in the lab within seconds. But my pride wouldn’t let me. I had dreamed of this moment since I first declared history as my major. I had written papers on peasant revolts, the effects of the Black Death, and the transition from serfdom to wage labor. I knew this period. I loved this period. Surely I could survive it.

So on the third day, I tried something different. I stopped trying to talk. I mimed. I smiled. I hauled water for an old woman without being asked. I helped a boy chase down a runaway goat. I sat quietly in the fields with a group of women weaving baskets and nodded at appropriate intervals. I didn’t speak unless spoken to. I mimicked posture, gestures, expressions. I stopped being a historian trying to play peasant and started simply existing.

And it worked—sort of. People still looked at me oddly, but they stopped challenging me. By sunset, I was sitting by a fire with a few villagers, chewing on some suspiciously tough meat and listening to a tale about a haunted mill. I didn’t understand half the words, but I laughed when they laughed and shivered when they shivered. For a moment, I almost felt like I belonged.

Then someone asked where I was from.

I froze. My carefully prepared backstory—about being from a neighboring village wiped out by plague—had holes even I couldn’t patch. I mumbled something, and the man who had asked, a wiry fellow with a scar down one cheek, narrowed his eyes.

“Don’t like strangers,” he muttered. “Strangers bring bad luck.”

Before I could respond, a hand brushed my elbow. I turned, and there was the Observer, disguised as a friar. He raised an eyebrow.

“Time’s up,” he whispered.

The extraction was instantaneous. One moment I was smelling smoke and sweat, the next I was back in the sterile white lab, blinking under fluorescent lights.

Professor Kessler was waiting, arms crossed.

“Well?” she asked.

I sighed. “I didn’t die.”

She smirked. “That’s a start.”

I passed the class—but just barely. My final report was brutally honest: I had failed to pass as a normal citizen. My speech was too modern, my body too soft, my instincts too academic. But I had learned more in those three days than in four years of lectures.

History, I realized, isn’t just dates and documents. It’s mud on your boots, hunger in your belly, and fear in your gut. It’s the awkwardness of not belonging and the effort it takes to survive, day by day. No textbook could have taught me that.

It was the worst—and best—final exam I’d ever taken.

samples.prompt: You are on a school trip to Salem, Massachusetts. The teacher seems suspiciously excited about this particular trip.
samples.output:
The bus rumbled along the narrow New England roads, the trees just beginning to show hints of autumn color. I sat near the back with my best friend, Rachel, who was already snapping selfies with her phone, trying to get the right angle to capture both her face and the blurred, picturesque scenery outside the window. The rest of our senior class was similarly distracted, chattering excitedly or dozing off, lulled by the rhythmic hum of the engine. Our destination: Salem, Massachusetts.

At first, I hadn’t thought much about this trip. A day away from classrooms and pop quizzes was always welcome, and Salem—famous for its history with the 1692 witch trials—seemed like a decent enough place to explore. But it was our history teacher, Mr. Whitaker, who made the whole thing feel… off. He was usually the kind of guy who wore elbow-patched blazers and lectured with the enthusiasm of a man explaining tax law. But when he announced the trip, he practically buzzed with excitement. His eyes had lit up in a way I hadn’t seen all year.

“You’re going to witness history,” he’d said, clasping his hands tightly together. “Real, tangible history. It’s not just about learning facts—it’s about experiencing the echoes of the past.”

At the time, I chalked it up to a teacher finally getting to do something he was passionate about. But now, with Salem growing closer and Mr. Whitaker practically bouncing in his seat at the front of the bus, I couldn’t shake the uneasy feeling that there was more to it.

We arrived just before noon. The town was a charming blend of colonial architecture and tourist traps. Gift shops selling crystal balls and faux spell books lined the cobbled streets. Actors in period costumes offered walking tours, and the scent of pumpkin spice and roasted nuts drifted through the air. It was almost kitschy enough to be comforting—until I saw the way Mr. Whitaker looked at the old courthouse.

“This,” he said softly, almost reverently, “is where it all happened.”

He led us through the town with the precision of someone who had memorized every brick and alleyway. We visited the Salem Witch Museum, where wax figures reenacted the hysteria of the trials. We walked past the Witch House, the only structure still standing in Salem with direct ties to the trials. All the while, Mr. Whitaker told stories—not from textbooks, but with the authority of someone who had lived through them.

“Did you know,” he said, during one stop, “that one of the accused witches, Bridget Bishop, was said to haunt the apple orchard where she was arrested? They say the smell of cider lingers in the air, even when there’s no fruit on the trees.”

A few students laughed nervously, but I noticed Rachel inching closer to me.

“Doesn’t he sound a little too into this?” she whispered.

I nodded. “He’s acting like he’s leading a pilgrimage, not a field trip.”

After lunch, we were given an hour to explore on our own before meeting back at the cemetery for a final ‘reflection.’ Rachel and I wandered away from the main square, drawn by a narrow lane that seemed less traveled. The further we walked, the quieter it became. Eventually, we stumbled upon a small, overgrown garden behind a crumbling stone wall. A rusted iron gate creaked open under our touch.

“It’s like something out of a horror movie,” Rachel said, half-joking.

But I was drawn inside. The garden was wild and forgotten, with gnarled trees and dark ivy curling over shattered gravestones. In the center stood a stone pedestal, and on it, a weathered book with no title.

“Okay, that’s not weird at all,” Rachel muttered.

I moved closer. The pages were filled with spidery handwriting, old and faded, but still legible. It wasn’t English—or at least, not entirely. Symbols I didn’t recognize danced across the page, and as I stared, a strange warmth bloomed in my chest.

“I think we should go,” Rachel said, tugging my arm.

But before I could respond, a voice called out from behind us.

“Ah, you found it.”

We turned to see Mr. Whitaker standing at the gate, his eyes gleaming.

“I was wondering who would be drawn here,” he said, stepping into the garden. “This place is a nexus. A seam between worlds, if you will. Very few can feel its pull.”

Rachel took a step back. “Mr. Whitaker, what are you talking about?”

He smiled, but it wasn’t the friendly kind. It was the kind that made your stomach twist.

“Salem is more than a town with a tragic past. It’s a place of power. Energy lingers here—old energy, deep and untouched. I’ve spent years preparing for this moment.”

I couldn’t speak. My fingers were still resting on the book, and I felt like I was rooted to the stone.

“You see,” he continued, “the trials weren’t just hysteria. They were an attempt to suppress what couldn’t be understood. But knowledge has a way of resurfacing. And some of us… some of us are meant to remember.”

Rachel grabbed my hand and yanked me away from the pedestal. The instant my fingers left the book, the warmth vanished, replaced by a chill that sank into my bones.

“We’re leaving,” Rachel said firmly.

Mr. Whitaker didn’t stop us. He simply watched, his smile never wavering.

We ran back to the meeting point, hearts pounding. When we arrived, the rest of the class was already gathered, unaware of what had just happened. Mr. Whitaker joined us moments later, his demeanor calm and collected, as if nothing had occurred.

On the bus ride home, Rachel refused to speak about the garden. “It didn’t happen,” she said, hugging her backpack like a shield. “We were just imagining things.”

But I couldn’t forget. That night, I dreamt of the book, of symbols dancing like fire before my eyes, and of Mr. Whitaker’s voice whispering, “Some of us are meant to remember.”

The next day, he was gone. The school said he had taken an indefinite leave of absence. No explanation was given. A substitute filled in, and none of the teachers seemed to know—or want to talk about—what had happened.

But I still remember.

And sometimes, when I close my eyes, I can feel the warmth again, as if the book is still calling me, waiting for me to return.

Salem was supposed to be a field trip. But it ended up being something else entirely—a reminder that history isn’t always in the past, and that some stories refuse to stay buried.

samples.prompt: A Goth in ancient Bulgaria on the eve of battle and another Goth in modern day getting ready to play Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly and inexplicably exchange places in history.
samples.output:
The sky above the Balkan Mountains brooded with the weight of dawn. Mist clung to the valleys like the breath of the gods, and the scent of wet earth mingled with the sharp tang of iron and leather. Thoramir, son of Alric, adjusted the wolf-fur pelt draped over his shoulders and stared out across the field where banners of the Ostrogothic warbands fluttered in the cold wind. The Romans were coming again—this time with a vengeance, their legions bolstered by treacherous foederati and the promise of gold. This was not Thoramir’s first battle, but something in his gut twisted differently this morning.

He gripped the hilt of his spatha and breathed in deeply, grounding himself in the present. Around him, warriors were sharpening blades, whispering prayers to Wodanaz, or painting runes onto shields. A raven cawed overhead, and Thoramir took it as a good omen. The air thrummed with tension and ancient song.

Then, everything changed.

One moment, he stood on the dewy earth of ancient Moesia, feeling the weight of centuries in his blood. The next, the world tilted, blinked—and he fell.

Lights. So many lights. Not the flickering torches of a war camp, but harsh, buzzing rectangles overhead. The damp earth was gone, replaced by a soft, plush material beneath him. Thoramir sprang up, disoriented, spatha still clutched in his hand. Around him, strange objects cluttered the small room: shelves lined with eldritch tomes bearing titles in a language he could almost recognize, glowing boxes with moving images, and a mirror reflecting a pale, confused man.

Then he saw himself.

Or what should have been himself. The reflection wore tight black clothing adorned with silver chains and mesh, his eyes rimmed in dark paint, lips as pale as bone. His long hair was dyed a shade of black so deep it seemed to absorb light. Thoramir dropped the sword, which clanged awkwardly on the laminate floor.

“What devilry is this?” he muttered, stepping back.

Suddenly, the door opened. A group of people entered, laughing and chatting, one of them holding a pizza box. They froze when they saw him—sword and all. One of them, a tall woman with a nose ring and a worn copy of a rulebook under her arm, narrowed her eyes.

“Erik? You okay, man? You look… different.”

Thoramir blinked. “Erik?”

“Yeah. Erik, our Storyteller? We’re here for the Vampire game?”

He looked down at himself, at the unfamiliar clothing, and realized the truth: he had been taken from his time and placed in another. The gods had played a trick—or perhaps a test.

Meanwhile, in the fourth century, on the edge of battle, Erik Johansson—a 22-year-old goth from modern-day Stockholm—found himself standing in dewy grass, surrounded by large, muscular men in fur and leather, all of whom were staring at him as if he were a ghost. His black eyeliner was smudged, his mesh shirt wholly inappropriate for the weather, and the DM screen he had clutched in one hand flapped in the morning breeze like a forgotten banner.

“Holy crap,” he whispered.

One of the warriors approached, a hulking man with braided hair and a shield painted with runes. “Thoramir,” the man boomed, clapping him on the shoulder. “You look different, brother. Are you ill?”

Erik’s mouth opened and closed. “I… uh… yes? No. Maybe?”

The man laughed heartily. “The gods work in strange ways. Come. The Romans will be upon us soon. We will drink blood or shed it, eh?”

Erik blinked. “You have no idea how appropriate that sounds.”

He was ushered into formation, handed a shield, and someone shoved a helmet onto his head. His mind reeled. This couldn’t be happening, right? He was ready to narrate a tense political scene in a vampire-themed tabletop RPG, not participate in an actual battle. But the cold wind biting his skin and the mud squelching beneath his boots told him this was all too real.

Back in modern-day Sofia, Thoramir sat cross-legged on the floor, poring over the Vampire: The Masquerade rulebook. To his great relief, he found the modern tongue not entirely alien—Germanic roots echoed in the words, and his sharp mind pieced together meaning. The others had chalked up his strange behavior to method acting, assuming he was “deep in character.” Thoramir, ever adaptable, had decided to play along.

He was fascinated by the game. The idea of immortality, of ancient clans locked in subtle wars, appealed to his warrior soul. He crafted a character called Alaricus, a Ventrue warlord who once led legions in the shadows of Rome. The game allowed him to express sides of himself he hadn’t known existed—manipulation, intrigue, and a thirst not for bloodshed, but for control.

Over pizza and soda—both of which he found strange but not unpleasant—he began to understand this world. The metal chariot machines that roared outside, the endless light, the subtle rituals of speech and gesture. The idea of people playing at being monsters when the real monsters were centuries away struck him as profoundly ironic.

At the same time, Erik was learning fast. He discovered that adrenaline could replace caffeine, and that swinging a sword was nothing like LARPing in the park. He leaned into what he knew: myth, lore, and character. He spoke in riddles, quoted Nietzsche, and claimed visions from the Norns. The warriors around him began to believe he was a seer, touched by the gods. When the battle came, Erik stood at the rear, offering cryptic guidance and prayers that sounded suspiciously like lines from Nosferatu.

To everyone’s surprise, the Goths won that battle. Rumors spread of Thoramir’s new insight, his strange speech, and the way he had predicted the Roman cavalry’s charge. They called him “the pale prophet” and began to follow him with reverence.

Weeks passed. Each man found himself wrestling with the unfamiliar world he now inhabited. Thoramir grew fond of the quiet moments with his newfound friends, rolling dice and weaving tales of darkness and desire. Erik, on the other hand, embraced leadership, learning the rhythms of ancient life and slowly building a legend around his strange origins.

Neither knew if the switch would reverse. Neither knew why it had happened. But both began to suspect that perhaps the gods—or fate, or time itself—had chosen them for a reason.

And so, in two different eras, two Goths walked paths not meant for them, finding in the unfamiliar a mirror of their own soul. One in a world where war was a game, and the other in a world where games could be war.

samples.prompt: Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed that.
samples.output:
Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. It’s a tautology, a truth so self-evident that it borders on absurdity. At first glance, this statement seems like nothing more than a play on words—a tongue-in-cheek reminder of how time works universally. But hidden beneath its surface lies a deeper message about perception, empathy, and the power of collective action. Because with your help, we changed that.

We changed what that minute means.

Time, as it ticks by, is impartial. A minute in Nairobi is the same as a minute in New York. Sixty seconds tick forward, unrelenting, no matter where you are. But what fills those sixty seconds—what they mean to the people experiencing them—can vary drastically. For some, a minute is a fleeting pause in a busy day. For others, it is a moment of suffering, a chance at survival, or a glimmer of hope.

For years, many have pointed to the challenges facing the African continent—poverty, disease, hunger, lack of access to education, clean water scarcity—as if they were static, unchanging facts. The phrase “Every 60 seconds in Africa…” has often been used to highlight grim statistics: a child dies from a preventable disease, a girl drops out of school, a family goes without food. These sobering realities can leave people feeling powerless, as if the clock will keep ticking no matter what we do.

But the truth is, time is not just measured in seconds. It is measured in impact. And that’s where you came in.

With your help, we turned those sixty seconds into something more. Into hope. Into action. Into change.

Take, for example, the story of Amina, a young girl from rural Tanzania. Before, every passing minute in her life was marked by the long walk to fetch water—water that was often dirty and made her family sick. She missed school, lost time, and with it, the chance for a different future. But when you helped fund the construction of a clean water well in her village, everything changed. Now, those same sixty seconds are spent in a classroom, learning math and dreaming of becoming a doctor. The minute didn’t change, but its meaning did.

Or consider the farmer in Malawi, who used to watch helplessly as his crops failed year after year due to erratic weather and poor soil. Each minute during drought season was a countdown to hunger. But with your support, he received training in sustainable agriculture and access to drought-resistant seeds. Now, those same minutes are spent tending to thriving crops, feeding his children, and selling produce at the market. Again, the passage of time is the same, but the outcome is worlds apart.

These are not isolated stories. They are part of a movement—a wave of change powered by compassion, innovation, and a refusal to accept that suffering is inevitable. Through education initiatives, healthcare programs, entrepreneurship training, and infrastructure development, people across the continent are reclaiming those sixty seconds and redefining their potential.

Because of you, a minute in Africa is no longer just a measure of time. It’s a heartbeat of progress.

You helped fund mobile clinics that reach remote areas, delivering life-saving vaccines and maternal care. That means that every minute, fewer mothers lose their lives in childbirth, and fewer children die from preventable diseases. You supported scholarships and built schools, transforming minutes spent in idleness into moments of learning and growth. You backed microloans and mentorship programs, turning seconds of doubt into sparks of entrepreneurship.

And perhaps most importantly, you helped change the narrative.

Africa is not a monolith of despair. It is a continent of diverse cultures, languages, landscapes, and dreams. It is a place where innovation thrives—from mobile banking systems that have revolutionized commerce, to solar energy solutions bringing electricity to off-grid communities. It is home to artists, scientists, visionaries, and changemakers who are shaping the future not just of Africa, but of the world.

When we say “with your help, we changed that,” we mean that you joined a global community that chose to see potential instead of pity, resilience instead of ruin. You saw past the statistics and into the stories. You recognized that while we cannot stop the clock, we can choose what we do with the time we’re given—and what others do with theirs.

Changing the meaning of a minute doesn’t require grand gestures or unlimited resources. It starts with empathy. It grows with partnership. And it endures through sustained commitment. Whether you donated, volunteered, advocated, or simply shared the message, you became part of a transformation that stretches far beyond sixty seconds.

The beauty of this change is that it multiplies. When a child receives an education, they grow into an adult who empowers others. When a community gains access to clean water, health improves, productivity increases, and generations benefit. When women are given the tools to succeed, entire economies are lifted. One minute of support can lead to a lifetime of change.

So yes, every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute still passes. But what that minute represents has been rewritten.

It represents a mother watching her child take their first steps in a home with electricity. A student discovering the joy of reading. A farmer harvesting his best crop yet. An entrepreneur launching her first business. A nurse delivering care with pride and purpose. These moments are not anomalies. They are the new reality, shaped by collective will and shared humanity.

And yet, the work is not finished. There are still minutes that pass filled with struggle, with silence, with unmet needs. But we now know what’s possible. We’ve seen how a minute can be transformed. And that knowledge is powerful.

So let us not stop here. Let us continue to invest in those minutes, to fill them with meaning and progress. Let us keep listening, learning, and lifting up voices that have too long been unheard. Let us remember that change is not a moment—it is a movement.

Because when we stand together, not even time can hold us back.

Every 60 seconds in Africa, a minute passes. But with your help, we changed that. We changed what it means. And together, we will keep changing it—one minute at a time.

samples.prompt: You are completely blind, but occasionally you can see just one person. That person will die within the next 24 hours. You've just seen yourself while passing by a mirror.
samples.output:
I was born blind.

I’ve never known color, never watched the sun set or seen the face of a loved one. But I’ve learned to live with it. My fingers read the world in Braille and texture, my ears paint the outlines of rooms through echoes and footsteps. I’ve learned to navigate the darkness, to be comfortable in it.

But about five years ago, everything changed.

It started with a stranger’s face—a man I didn’t know, appearing before me in startling clarity while I was riding the subway. For a few seconds, I could see him as though he'd stepped into a spotlight that only I could perceive. Every detail was vivid: the graying stubble on his chin, the slight tremor in his hands, the deep sadness in his eyes. Then, as quickly as he’d appeared, the vision faded, and the familiar darkness returned.

The next morning, I heard on the news that a man had collapsed at the very same subway stop I’d disembarked from. Heart failure. His photo flashed across the screen. I couldn’t see it, of course, but the description matched the man I'd seen perfectly.

It happened again a few weeks later. A woman this time—middle-aged, laughing with a friend on a park bench. Her blonde hair catching the light, her eyes crinkled with joy. I saw her for perhaps ten seconds. Twenty-four hours later, I read in the paper that she’d been killed in a car accident.

After the third time, I stopped trying to deny it.

There’s no logic to it, no pattern I can discern. Sometimes the visions come in a crowd, other times when I’m alone. Always just one person, always someone I’ve never met before. I’ll see them clearly, impossibly, for a few seconds. Then they’re gone.

And within 24 hours, so are they.

I tried to tell someone once—my sister, Emily. She’s always been the rational one, the scientist. I thought if anyone could help me understand, it would be her. She listened patiently and then told me I was probably experiencing some kind of neurological hallucination. That what I was describing wasn’t possible.

I wanted to believe her. But the deaths kept happening. The faces kept coming.

Eventually, I stopped telling people. What could I say? “Excuse me, sir, I just saw your face for the first time, and I think you’re going to die tomorrow”? What good would it do?

Instead, I learned to live with it—this cruel gift, this unbearable curse. I became a passive witness to fate, a blind man who could see only those already marked for death.

Which brings me to today.

It was early morning, and I was getting ready to leave my apartment for work. I reached for the coat rack, my hand brushing against the sleeve of my trench coat. I turned toward the hallway mirror—not because I expected to see anything, but out of habit. For a blind man, I have a surprising number of habits tied to sight.

And then I saw myself.

My heart froze. I stared into the mirror and saw my own face for the first time in my life. The shape of my nose, the curve of my jaw, the color of my eyes—details I had only imagined, now laid bare before me in stark, terrifying clarity.

I stumbled back, gasping. The vision faded. Darkness returned.

It’s been six hours since then.

I haven’t told anyone. What would I say? What could I say?

I’ve spent the day trying to make sense of it. Pacing my apartment. Listening to the clock tick. Every sound feels louder, more vivid. Every breath feels numbered.

I wonder if this is how the others felt—the ones I saw. Did they sense it too? Did some part of them know that time was slipping through their fingers?

I thought about calling Emily. I even picked up the phone once, but I couldn’t bring myself to dial. I didn’t want to hear her tell me it was all in my head. Not now. Not when I know what’s coming.

Instead, I’ve been writing. I don’t know why. Maybe it’s a way to make peace with it. Maybe I just want to leave something behind.

I’ve thought about trying to stop it. Locking myself in, refusing to leave the apartment. But death doesn’t need an invitation. It doesn’t knock politely. It just comes.

And yet, I keep wondering—what if I’m wrong?

What if this time is different?

What if seeing myself isn’t a death sentence, but something else? A warning? A chance?

But deep down, I know the truth. I’ve seen too many faces. I’ve read too many obituaries. The pattern has never broken.

Twenty-four hours.

That’s the rule.

I’ve always thought of death as a thief in the night. But now, knowing it’s coming, I feel something unexpected: clarity. Relief, even. The waiting is over. The question of how and when has an answer now.

Still, there are things I’ll miss.

The smell of coffee in the morning. The sound of rain against the windows. My sister’s laugh. The warmth of a dog curled up beside me. All the things I never saw but learned to love anyway.

And then there’s the mystery of it all—the why. Why me? Why this gift? Was it ever really a gift? Or just a slow, cruel joke played by a universe that delights in irony?

I may never know. But as the hours tick by, I find myself strangely at peace.

Maybe that’s the final gift—seeing myself, knowing the end is near, and having the chance to say goodbye.

If you’re reading this, then I’m already gone.

But remember: even in darkness, there is understanding.

Even in blindness, there is truth.

And sometimes, seeing the end is the beginning of finally seeing yourself.

samples.prompt: "Stop your crying! There's always someone out there who has it worse than you."
samples.output:
"Stop your crying! There's always someone out there who has it worse than you."

At first glance, this phrase might sound like tough love or an attempt at perspective. After all, in a world filled with suffering, wars, poverty, and tragedy, it's statistically likely that someone, somewhere, is enduring a worse situation than the one you're in. The statement is rooted in a certain kind of logic: if you’re not at the very bottom, perhaps you should be grateful. But as with so many commonly spoken phrases, the deeper implications of this one are more complex—and potentially more harmful—than they appear on the surface.

On one hand, this statement is often deployed with good intentions. A parent might say it to a child who is upset over a seemingly minor disappointment. A friend might offer it during a moment of emotional turmoil, hoping to provide comfort or redirect the focus toward gratitude. The idea is that by recognizing others' suffering, we might find a way to lessen our own. In some cases, this works. Perspective can be a powerful tool. Realizing that your bad day pales in comparison to someone else’s tragedy may encourage humility or gratitude. But more often than not, the phrase doesn’t serve to uplift—it serves to silence.

To tell someone that their pain is invalid because someone else is experiencing something worse is to misunderstand the nature of pain itself. Suffering is not a competitive sport. Pain doesn’t operate on a universal hierarchy where only those in the direst circumstances are permitted to feel anguish. Emotions are deeply personal, and they exist in context. To a teenager, the end of a relationship may feel like the end of the world. To a grieving parent, the loss of a child is unimaginable. These experiences are not the same, but they are both real, and both deserve recognition.

When we insist that someone’s pain is unworthy because others have it worse, we are essentially saying that there is a threshold of suffering that must be crossed before empathy is warranted. This creates a toxic culture of emotional invalidation, where individuals feel ashamed for struggling unless their lives are catastrophically broken. It discourages vulnerability and promotes emotional repression. Eventually, people may stop expressing their feelings altogether, not because they’ve stopped hurting, but because they’ve internalized the belief that their pain doesn’t matter.

Moreover, this mindset can lead to a kind of emotional paralysis. If people are constantly measuring their suffering against the worst-case scenarios, they may never seek help or support. They may convince themselves that they have no right to therapy, no reason to talk to a friend, no justification for needing time off work. They may suffer in silence, all the while believing that their pain is somehow illegitimate. And in doing so, they rob themselves of the opportunity to heal.

It’s also worth considering the irony of the phrase itself. While it purports to be about cultivating perspective, it often lacks empathy. True perspective doesn’t come from dismissing our own pain, but from understanding that everyone’s journey is different. It comes from recognizing that while someone else may be facing a different kind of hardship, that doesn’t make our own burdens lighter or less worthy of attention. Compassion is not a finite resource; acknowledging your own pain doesn’t detract from someone else’s struggle.

There’s also a social and cultural component to consider. In many communities, particularly those that value stoicism or resilience, expressions of vulnerability are often discouraged. Phrases like “Stop your crying” are used to enforce emotional toughness, especially among men and boys. The underlying message is clear: emotions are a sign of weakness, and weakness is unacceptable. This leads to a culture where emotional expression is suppressed, mental health issues go unaddressed, and people suffer alone.

Furthermore, this phrase can be especially damaging when used in the context of mental health. Depression, anxiety, and other mental illnesses are often invisible. They don’t always arise from external circumstances, and they don’t always make logical sense. Telling someone with depression to be grateful because “it could be worse” is akin to telling someone with a broken leg to walk it off because someone else lost their leg. It’s not just unhelpful—it’s dismissive and cruel.

So what’s the alternative? How can we offer support and perspective without invalidating someone’s feelings?

The answer lies in empathy and validation. Instead of saying, “Stop your crying,” try asking, “What’s going on? Want to talk about it?” Instead of reminding someone that others have it worse, remind them that it’s okay to feel what they’re feeling. Offer a space where emotions can be expressed without judgment. Encourage both gratitude and honesty—acknowledging that while things could always be worse, that doesn’t mean they’re not hard right now.

Perspective is valuable, but it should be used to build compassion, not to shut emotions down. When someone is struggling, they don’t need a lecture about comparative suffering. They need someone to listen, to sit with them in their discomfort, and to remind them that their feelings are valid. Pain is not a contest, and healing is not a race.

In the end, we’d do well to retire phrases like “Stop your crying, someone has it worse than you.” They may be well-intentioned, but they often do more harm than good. Instead, let’s cultivate a culture of empathy, where emotions are respected and vulnerability is met with compassion. Let’s remind each other that it’s okay to cry, to hurt, to feel overwhelmed—even if someone else has it worse. Because the truth is, someone else having it worse doesn’t make your pain any less real. And you deserve to be heard.

samples.prompt: The world is nearing its end but everyone seems oblivious but one man, these are the tales of his mission to try and help humanity see the error of it's ways and change before it is too late.
samples.output:
The sun still rose each morning, casting its golden rays across the surface of a world teetering on the brink. Children laughed on their way to school, markets bustled with the daily pulse of commerce, and digital screens flashed news of celebrity scandals and political squabbles. To the casual observer, nothing was amiss. Life continued its rhythm, predictable and comforting. But beneath the surface, a storm was brewing, one that only a single man seemed to sense.

His name was Elias Ward.

Elias wasn’t a scientist in the traditional sense. He had no credentials in climatology, astrophysics, or engineering. In fact, he had spent most of his adult life as a systems analyst for a mid-sized IT firm in Seattle. But Elias had always had an eye for patterns, a mind that could detect the faintest ripple in a sea of data. It started with numbers—rising ocean temperatures, unprecedented species extinctions, erratic solar activity. At first, he chalked it up to coincidence, the kind of noise that gets lost in the chaos of modern life. But the deeper he dug, the more he began to see a pattern—a convergence of crises pointing toward a singular conclusion: the world was dying, and it was happening faster than anyone realized.

At first, he tried to sound the alarm quietly. He compiled reports, graphs, and projections, emailing them to academics, journalists, and government agencies. Most never responded. Those who did dismissed him as an alarmist or a conspiracy theorist. One professor even accused him of fabricating data. Undeterred, Elias turned to social media, creating a blog titled "The Final Arc." He posted daily, detailing the environmental anomalies, the geopolitical instability, and the social decay that, when viewed together, painted a chilling picture.

For months, he was met with indifference, ridicule, and even threats. But he kept writing.

One entry in particular gained unexpected traction. It was a story, not just data—a fictionalized account of a future where the oceans had swallowed the coastlines, where the air was too toxic to breathe, and where humanity lived in underground bunkers, barely surviving. The post went viral. People were drawn in by the narrative, the way Elias made the numbers feel real. For the first time, he had their attention.

He realized then that facts alone wouldn’t save the world. People needed to feel the truth, to see themselves in the story. And so, Elias became a storyteller.

He traveled across the country, speaking at libraries, community centers, and schools. He told tales of forgotten rivers that once nourished civilizations, of forests that had sung with life but now stood silent. He spoke of the future not as a dystopia, but as a possibility—one that could still be avoided if humanity chose to act. He called it "The Mission": not to scare people, but to awaken them.

Along the way, Elias met others—scientists, activists, artists—who had sensed the same darkness looming on the horizon. They joined him, adding their voices to the growing choir of urgency. Together, they formed The Arc, a grassroots movement dedicated to education, sustainability, and systemic change. They held workshops on permaculture, built solar-powered community centers, and organized global “wake-up days” where people shared stories of climate grief and hope. Still, the majority remained asleep, lulled by convenience and denial.

Elias often wondered why it was so hard for people to see. The evidence was everywhere—in the melting glaciers, the record-breaking wildfires, the mass migrations. But to acknowledge the truth meant accepting responsibility, and that was a heavy burden. It was easier to believe that someone else would fix it, that technology would save them, or that the planet had endured worse.

But Elias knew better. He had seen the simulations, watched the patterns unfold. The world had reached a tipping point. If humanity didn’t change course within the next decade, the collapse would be irreversible.

One night, as he sat alone in a cabin deep in the Cascades, Elias received a message from a young woman named Mira, a climate scientist from Bangladesh. “Your stories saved my life,” she wrote. “I was ready to give up, but your words reminded me why I became a scientist. We’re not alone. Keep going.”

Elias wept. For the first time in years, he allowed himself to believe that maybe—just maybe—there was hope.

He doubled his efforts. He wrote a book, “The Last Wake-Up Call,” blending fiction and fact in a way that made the future feel immediate. It became a bestseller, translated into over twenty languages. He was invited to speak at the United Nations, where he delivered a speech that would spark both outrage and inspiration. He didn’t mince words. “We are not the first civilization to fall,” he said. “But we have the power to be the first to stop it from happening.”

Some called him a prophet. Others called him a fraud. But no one could ignore him anymore.
