There is a reason many stories depict gods longing to be mortal. To live within limits is to find meaning. Mortality is what gives life urgency, purpose, and love. A mortal can risk, can strive, can fail. These are not weaknesses—they are the very fabric of significance. A god, stripped of such constraints, cannot gamble, cannot sacrifice, cannot grow. Their victories are predetermined, their losses impossible. And so their stories become static, their existence a flickering light in an otherwise eternal dark.

So what use is godhood, when you can do nothing with it? It is a question that unmasks the illusion of absolute power. It reveals that the value of action lies not in capability, but in consequence. That meaning is forged in limitation, not in boundless possibility. A being that can do everything may find that nothing is worth doing.

In the end, perhaps the greatest act of a god is to relinquish their divinity. To become mortal, to bleed and ache and die, to walk among the finite and feel the weight of time. Not as a punishment, but as a liberation. To step down from the throne of the eternal and embrace the trembling uncertainty of life. In that frailty, perhaps, lies the only true freedom.

Because when you can do nothing with your godhood, the only meaningful choice left is to give it up.

samples.prompt: Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.
samples.output:
Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirmed it.

It had been a thought that lingered in the back of his mind since his earliest moments, since the first time he stood beside a dying creature and felt the final breath slip into his realm. The question had never been spoken aloud—there were none to ask, none who could answer. But it was there, like a whisper in the silence between heartbeats: Could even God die?

Death had never attributed arrogance to himself. He did not wield power with malice or pride. He was a function, a necessity, the final page in the book of every life. He did not choose who died—he merely arrived when summoned by fate, by the great tapestry of existence that someone, somewhere, must have woven long ago. It was not his design. He was the end, but not the cause.

Yet even in his impartiality, he had always felt that some beings were beyond him. Gods. Entities of creation and chaos, light and shadow. He had visited the quiet deaths of forgotten deities, old spirits whose names had been lost to time. But they were not the God. Not the One whose name echoed in the prayers of billions, whose presence was said to be eternal, omnipotent, and omniscient.

Until today.

The list arrived as it always did, etched in starlight across a parchment that shimmered with the breath of the cosmos. Names scrawled in celestial ink, fading only when claimed. Some names were familiar—kings and beggars, children and warriors. Some were strange, belonging to creatures that dwelled in corners of the universe rarely glimpsed by mortal eyes. And then, at the very bottom, a single name:

God.

Death stared at it for longer than he had ever stared at anything. The letters pulsed gently, unwavering, as if daring him to question their reality. He reached forward with a skeletal finger, half expecting it to vanish when touched, to reveal itself as some cruel joke or metaphysical glitch. But the name remained, solid and immutable.

God.

There was no title, no embellishment. Just a name, plain and final, as all names became in his ledger.

He did not rush. Death rarely did. But there was a weight to this harvest unlike any other. Was it possible for the infinite to end? Could a being outside of time find itself trapped within the very laws it had written? He had no answers, and yet he was compelled by the only truth he had ever known: when the name appeared, Death must come.

The journey was unlike any other he had undertaken. He did not walk through time or space, for such things folded before him. He passed through nebulae of thought, oceans of belief, forests grown from the dreams of the faithful. He moved not toward a place, but toward a Presence.

And then suddenly, he was there.

It was not a throne room, nor a garden, nor a temple carved in gold. It was a quiet place, serene and still, where the air shimmered with unsung hymns and the light carried both warmth and sorrow. And in the center of this place sat a figure—neither old nor young, neither man nor woman. A face that could not be remembered, and yet would never be forgotten. Eyes that seemed to know all things, and yet looked weary.

God.

Death approached with the reverence of a child entering a sacred hall. He did not speak. He had no need to. The figure looked up and smiled—gently, sadly.

“It’s time, then?” God asked, voice soft as wind through leaves.

Death nodded.

“I always wondered if you would come for me,” God continued, gazing into the distance, where galaxies bloomed and faded like fireflies. “I created you, you know. Not directly, but as a consequence. Life demands death, and so you came to be.”

“I know,” Death whispered. His voice was quiet, a breeze through bone.

“Does it frighten you?” God asked.

“No. Only... I did not think it was possible.”

“Nor did I,” God replied, a faint smile curling their lips. “But I am tired. The prayers have changed. The faith is fractured. My name is used for war and power more than love or wonder. And even I, for all my omnipotence, cannot force belief. I existed because they believed I did. And now... they believe in other things.”

Death considered this. He had seen gods rise and fall, their dominions crumbling as the last of their worshippers died or forgot them. But he had never thought that would happen here, to this God. This God had been more than a deity—it had been a cornerstone.

“Will there be another?” Death asked.

“I do not know,” God said. “Perhaps. Perhaps something new will rise from the ashes. Perhaps humanity no longer needs gods. Perhaps they will become their own.”

Silence stretched between them, ancient and sacred.

“Will it hurt?” God finally asked.

“No,” Death said. “It never hurts. Only the living feel pain.”

God exhaled slowly, a sound that seemed to shake the very fabric of creation. “Then let us begin.”

Death stepped forward, lifting his hand—not a weapon, not a scythe, but simply a gesture, a calling. Light surrounded the figure, not blinding but enveloping, as if the universe itself had paused to witness the moment.

And as the light faded, God was gone.

The quiet place remained, now empty but not abandoned. Something lingered—an echo, a memory, a possibility.

Death stood alone, the list now shorter by one name.

He did not feel triumph. There was no sense of victory. Only the quiet ache of an end, and the knowledge that even eternity had its moment.

He turned and walked away, the silence returning to its natural rhythm.

Behind him, the stars watched. And somewhere, in the hearts of those who still believed, a whisper began—not of God, but of something new. Something waiting to be born.

samples.prompt: WP about any subject you want with a sudden twist that ends with the words 'they are finally free'
samples.output:
**Title: The Watchers of Elmridge**

Elmridge had always been a quiet town, nestled deep within the rolling hills and dense forests of the North. Its cobblestone streets, antique lamp posts, and century-old houses gave it a timeless feel, as though it had been plucked from a storybook and preserved in amber. Life moved slowly there. The townsfolk knew one another by name, and gossip traveled faster than the mail. Outsiders rarely visited, and when they did, they didn’t stay long. 

That suited the residents just fine.

Among Elmridge’s many peculiar traditions was the Watch. Every night, as the sun dipped behind the hills and shadows began to stretch across the town, a group of volunteers would take to the streets dressed in dark, hooded cloaks. Known simply as the Watchers, their duty was to patrol the town until dawn. No one ever spoke of what they were watching for. Children were told not to ask questions, and adults responded with vague phrases like “It’s just the way things are” or “The Watch keeps us safe.”

Nora Bellamy had lived in Elmridge her entire life. A schoolteacher by profession and a natural skeptic by nature, she had always found the Watch disturbing. As a child, she had once peeked through her curtains late at night to see a cloaked figure standing perfectly still in the middle of the street, facing her house. She’d hidden under her bed until morning. From then on, she’d tried not to think about the Watch at all.

But that was before her younger brother, Jamie, had been chosen.

Every five years, five new Watchers were appointed. The selection process was secret, the names announced at the Harvest Festival by the town’s mayor in a ceremony that felt more like a funeral than a celebration. The chosen ones were expected to serve for five years, from dusk till dawn, and were forbidden from discussing their duties.

Jamie was twenty-two when his name was called. He had always been bright and cheerful, the kind of person who could light up a room with a smile or calm a crying child with a silly face. But after his induction into the Watch, something changed. He grew distant, quiet. His laughter faded, and his eyes—once full of mischief—became hollow and tired.

Nora tried to talk to him about it, but he only shook his head and said, “I can’t. You wouldn’t understand.”

He was right. She didn’t understand. No one did.

And then, two years into his term, Jamie disappeared.

The official story was that he had run away. The mayor even gave a speech about how the pressures of the Watch could weigh heavily on some, and how they should all support one another in these difficult times. But Nora didn’t believe it. Jamie wouldn’t run. He loved Elmridge. He loved her. Something had happened to him, and no one was willing to talk about it.

So she decided to find out the truth for herself.

It started with the town archives. She combed through old newspaper clippings, town records, and council meeting minutes. The Watch had existed for nearly two centuries, but there were gaps—entire decades with missing documents. She asked the librarian, Mrs. Phelps, about it, but was met with a tight-lipped smile and a dismissive wave. “Some things are better left alone, dear,” she said.

Undeterred, Nora turned to the only other person in town who might know more: Old Man Grady.

Grady had been a Watcher once, back when Nora was a child. He lived alone on the outskirts of town in a crumbling house filled with clocks that never worked and books with missing pages. Most people thought he was mad. Nora hoped he was just eccentric.

She found him in his garden, talking to a crow perched on his shoulder.

“You want to know about the Watch,” he said, before she even opened her mouth.

She nodded.

He sighed and motioned for her to sit.

“What we watch for,” he said, “is not something of this world. It’s older than the town, older than the forest. It comes every night, just after the last light fades. You can’t see it, not unless it wants you to. But you can feel it. In the cold that creeps up your spine, in the way the wind dies all at once, in the silence that falls like a blanket.”

He paused, looking past her, as if remembering something too heavy to carry.

“The Watchers are a barrier. A living wall. We keep it from crossing. But the cost... the cost is steep.”

“What happened to Jamie?” she asked.

Grady looked at her with sorrow in his eyes.

“Sometimes the wall cracks. Sometimes it takes one of us.”

That night, Nora made her decision.

She stole one of the cloaks from the town hall. It was heavy and smelled of damp earth and old smoke. As the sun set, she slipped into the shadows and began to walk the streets of Elmridge.

At first, nothing happened. The town was quiet, the air still. But around midnight, she felt it. A presence. Heavy, oppressive. The air grew thick, and the streetlights flickered. She turned a corner and saw them—three Watchers standing in a circle around something writhing and black, like smoke given form. It hissed and surged, but the Watchers held their ground.

Nora stepped closer. The thing turned towards her, and for a moment, her mind screamed. Images flooded her vision—pain, fire, endless night. But then, a voice.

Jamie.

“Help me.”

Without thinking, she stepped into the circle.

Pain lanced through her like lightning. The creature shrieked, and the Watchers staggered. But Nora held firm, focusing on Jamie’s voice. The creature twisted and screamed, and then—just as suddenly—it vanished, leaving behind a ringing silence.

The Watchers turned to her. One by one, they pulled back their hoods.

They were children. Teenagers. A few older men. All of them with eyes that had seen too much.

And then, Jamie stepped forward.

His face was pale, his hands shaking. But he was alive.

“You found me,” he whispered.

She hugged him, tears streaming down her cheeks.

The next morning, the town awoke to find the cloaked figures gone. The Watch was over. The darkness did not return.

For the first time in generations, the town of Elmridge felt the sun as something more than a reprieve.

And as Nora and Jamie stood hand in hand, watching the light flood their home, they knew the truth:

They are finally free.

samples.prompt: "Centuries ago, when we granted you the mean to flee the Milky Way, we also warned you of the horror we are running from. And your kind didn't listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeon before, and now all that left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?"
samples.output:
Centuries ago, when we granted you the means to flee the Milky Way, we also warned you of the horror we were running from. And your kind didn't listen. You fought, and you failed, just as we had aeons before, and now all that is left of Mankind is the ragtag band of refugees in front of me. Why?

That is the question I have asked myself, again and again, since your battered fleet emerged from the wormhole we left behind, the last trembling trace of a civilization that once spanned half the stars. I look at you now—your eyes hollow with exhaustion, your bodies gaunt and broken, your ships more scrap than structure—and I do not see the proud species we once watched with cautious admiration. I see desperation. I see loss. I see the same expression we wore when we first fled.

Why?

You had every warning. We did not simply hand you the technology and vanish into the darkness beyond. We told you. We told you, in every language and symbol we could muster. We told you of the thing that comes from the galactic core, the thing that is not life and not death, the thing that devours thought and soul, that unravels time and memory as easily as a child tears petals from a flower. We told you of its hunger, of its indifference, of how it does not conquer but consumes. We told you we tried to fight it, once, just as you would. We told you we failed, and we bore the scars to prove it.

But you, with your bright eyes and your boundless pride, you thought yourselves different. You looked at the ruins of our worlds and saw only weakness. You heard our warnings and thought them cautionary tales meant to frighten primitives. You believed your cleverness, your weapons, your machines, would succeed where our ancient minds had failed. You believed you could win.

Why?

Is it arrogance? Is it hope? Is it something deeper, something woven into the fabric of your being? You are creatures of resistance, of struggle. You have clawed your way from the mud of one world to the stars themselves, and at every step, you have refused to bow. You broke the chains of gravity, defied the silence of space, tamed the atom, and bent light to your will. Perhaps it was inevitable that you would try to bend the darkness too.

But the darkness does not bend.

We watched from afar, reluctant but resolved. We saw your golden age blossom across the Orion Arm. Your colonies multiplied, your art flourished, your science reached heights we once thought impossible. For a time, we wondered if we had erred, if perhaps this time would be different. Perhaps your defiance would buy you something more than a brief respite. Perhaps you would find a way.

But then the silence began.

First, the outer colonies. A few missing signals, attributed to solar flares or relay malfunctions. Then whole sectors went quiet. Your military mobilized, your scientists scrambled to understand, and your leaders assured your people that all was under control. It was not. You knew that. Deep down, you all knew.

The horror had awoken once more.

It did not come with fleets or armies. It came with whispers, with dreams that bled into waking. It came with thoughts that turned against their owners, with memories that unraveled like silk. It came with the sudden stillness of entire worlds, the eerie calm of cities where every light still shone, but no one moved. It came with the unraveling of meaning itself.

You fought. Of course you did. You unleashed weapons that cracked moons and burned atmospheres. You tore holes in space, hoping to trap it, to slow it down. You sent your bravest minds into the heart of the silence, hoping to learn, to understand, to find some weakness. One by one, they vanished. No message. No remains. Nothing but the whispering echo of their failure.

And still, you fought.

You built the Ark Fleets, vast and desperate. You sent children and elders, leaders and poets, anyone who could still dream of a future, into the void. Some made it. Most did not. The thing that devours had grown wiser since our time; it knew the scent of escape, and it hunted harder for it. You lost more than you saved.

And now, here you are. A few dozen ships limping across the black, your engines sputtering, your people clinging to life and memory by threads. You found the path we left behind, the hidden corridor through dimensions, and followed it to the edge of our sanctuary. You stand before me now, hollowed out and haunted, asking for shelter, for salvation.

And I still ask: Why?

Why did you ignore our warnings? Why did you think yourselves immune to the fate that claimed so many before you? Why did you not run when you had the chance?

I see a child among you, clutching a tattered doll, her eyes too old for her face. I see a man who once commanded a fleet, now helping to carry supplies because there is no one else left. I see a woman whispering names into the void, perhaps to remember, perhaps to forget. I see not soldiers or scientists or conquerors. I see survivors.

Perhaps that, in the end, is the answer.

You are not unique in your fate. We were proud once, too. We believed, once, too. We fought, and we failed. We paid the price. And still, we survived—barely. Not all of us. Not unchanged. But some. Enough.

You are like us. That is why.

You did not listen because you could not—not truly. Warnings are not wisdom. Pain is the only teacher strong enough to break the illusion of invincibility. You believed because belief is the fire that keeps your kind moving. You fought because to do otherwise would have been to surrender yourselves before the battle began. You failed because the thing cannot be fought.

And yet, you survived.

That is the only truth that matters now. You are here. Scarred, but here. And in your eyes, I see something I had forgotten: the spark, the stubborn flame that refuses to go out, even when the night stretches on forever.

Come, then. We will not turn you away. This place is not paradise, but it is safe—for now. We will share what we can, teach what we know, and mourn what we both have lost. Together, perhaps, we can find a new fate, a new path.

Perhaps this time, we will not run.

Perhaps this time, we will endure.

samples.prompt: A monster adapts to living with its human family.
samples.output:
When the Bramblehorn first arrived on the doorstep of the Whitaker family, it was raining—thick, heavy drops that soaked the world in gray. No one knew how it got there. Mrs. Whitaker opened the door to retrieve a package and found the creature huddled beneath the porch awning, its mossy fur dripping, two curling briar-covered horns poking from its head like dead branches in a winter forest. She let out a yelp and slammed the door shut.

But it didn't leave.

That night, it howled softly—more like a mournful cello than a wolf—and the youngest Whitaker, Ellie, peered through the window and whispered, “It’s just scared.”

The next morning, it was still there. Ellie, who had never been afraid of monsters under the bed or shadows in the closet, offered it a slice of toast through the mail slot. The Bramblehorn sniffed it, then carefully slid it into its mouth with a clawed hand the size of a dinner plate. When it didn’t eat the mail slot too, the Whitakers began to wonder if it might not be dangerous after all.

After some deliberation and a great deal of whispering behind closed doors, Mr. Whitaker fetched an old tarp from the garage and set it up in the backyard like a tent. The Bramblehorn moved in that same day, curling its enormous body beneath the makeshift shelter. It slept with its mossy back turned to the house and its horns nestled into the dirt.

No one knew where it had come from. It couldn’t speak, at least not in words. Its communication was a mixture of low rumbles, expressive eyes, and gestures that the family gradually learned to interpret. When it was hungry, it scratched the earth in wide circles. When it was content, it hummed, a deep vibration that shook the windows but somehow soothed the soul.

At first, the neighbors were skeptical. Mrs. Langdon from two doors down called animal control, and men in uniforms came with tranquilizers and nets. But the Bramblehorn sat calmly in the yard, blinking slowly, as if it were merely a statue of a creature imagined in a child’s dream. Eventually, they left, muttering about “no cause for action” and “unidentifiable species.”

Living with a monster required certain adjustments. The Whitakers learned quickly that the Bramblehorn didn’t like loud noises. It would flatten its horns and sulk in the far corner of the yard if someone turned up the television or slammed a door. Mr. Whitaker, who had a habit of shouting at the evening news, took to watching it with subtitles.

The garden, once pristine and symmetrical, was now a wild tangle of vines and moss where the Bramblehorn slept. It exuded a kind of botanical aura, and plants grew wherever it lingered. At first, Mrs. Whitaker bemoaned the loss of her rose bushes, but when she saw that the Bramblehorn had coaxed a rare blue orchid to bloom in the middle of winter, she reconsidered. Gardening, she decided, was overrated.

Ellie was the Bramblehorn’s closest friend. She named it “Moss,” which it accepted with a satisfied grunt. Every day after school, she would sit in the yard and read aloud while Moss curled around her like a living fortress. She taught it how to play hide-and-seek (though it was terrible at hiding), and in return, it showed her how to weave flowers into its fur.

Moss began to adapt, too. It learned not to scratch the siding of the house when it was excited, and it stopped uprooting the fence posts when it got startled by passing cars. It even learned to open the back door with a gentle nudge of its horn—only after being sternly told not to break it again.

One evening, during a thunderstorm, the power went out. Ellie was frightened by the sudden darkness, and Moss, sensing her fear, lumbered into the house for the first time. It curled up in the living room, its body taking up most of the floor, and hummed softly. The sound seemed to wrap around the whole family like a comforting blanket. They sat together in the dim candlelight, sipping cocoa and listening to the monster sing.

Over time, Moss became a fixture in the neighborhood. Children would stop by to leave him drawings and handfuls of berries. The mailman, initially wary, began to greet him each morning with a respectful nod. Even Mrs. Langdon softened when Moss helped her untangle her cat from a bramble bush (which, to be fair, might have grown from Moss’s own back).

Still, not everyone was accepting. One day, a man from the Department of Unusual Wildlife showed up with a clipboard and a stern face. He asked questions about permits and safety regulations. He cited obscure laws about “non-native fauna” and “potential ecological disruption.”

The Whitakers stood their ground. Ellie showed him her drawings—Moss with a party hat, Moss playing hopscotch, Moss dancing under the moonlight. Mrs. Whitaker offered him tea and talked about how the creature had helped with her insomnia. Mr. Whitaker pulled out a binder of meticulously kept notes on Moss’s habits and dietary preferences.

In the end, the man sighed, muttered something about “unique cases,” and left them alone.

Moss never spoke, but the Whitakers believed he understood more than anyone guessed. He listened. He observed. He adapted. He started to mimic human behaviors in small, endearing ways—tilting his head when someone spoke, tapping a claw when he was impatient, even attempting to clap when Ellie performed impromptu puppet shows.

Winter came, and the Whitakers built a proper shelter for Moss, complete with heat lamps and insulated walls. He seemed grateful, though he still preferred to nap in the snow, letting it pile up on his back like a second skin.

Some nights, they would find him staring at the stars, his eyes reflecting the sky. Ellie liked to think he missed wherever he’d come from—but that he was happy here, too.

Living with a monster was not always easy. There were still broken fences and misunderstandings, and the occasional terrified delivery driver. But the Whitakers had learned that “monster” didn’t mean dangerous. Sometimes, it meant misunderstood. Sometimes, it meant lonely.

And sometimes, it meant family.

samples.prompt: After your friend committed suicide, you received your share of his will. All he left was his bucket list, which seems impossible to complete. He wants you to finish it.
samples.output:
When I first opened the envelope, I thought it might be a mistake. The handwriting was unmistakably his—sharp and slanted, like he always wrote in a hurry, even when he wasn’t. I hadn’t seen his writing in over six months, not since the messages stopped and the silence began. And now, this: a single envelope, no return address, postmarked three days after the funeral.

Inside, there was no money, no letter of apology or explanation, no goodbye. Just a list.

It was titled simply: "The List." No other preamble. But I recognized what it was immediately. His bucket list.

I read it once, then again, slower. Each line felt like a punch to the chest. Some items were ridiculous—"Hike through Antarctica," "Dance with a stranger in Tokyo at midnight," "Chase a thunderstorm across the Great Plains." Others were deeply personal—"Forgive my father," "Learn to play the cello," "Tell her I loved her, even if she doesn’t love me back."

At the bottom, in slightly messier handwriting, as if his hand had trembled as he wrote it, were the words: "If I can’t do this… maybe you can."

I sat with the list for hours, unable to decide whether I was angry or heartbroken. Maybe both. He had always been the dreamer between us. I was the one with both feet on the ground, the one who said, “Maybe next year,” when he proposed some wild adventure. I never thought he’d actually expect me to do any of it—especially not after he took himself out of the world entirely.

But maybe that was the point.

He had always seen magic where I saw logistics. When he talked about jumping into the ocean in Bali or climbing a mountain in Patagonia, I saw flight schedules and immunizations and credit card bills. He saw possibility. Wonder. Hope.

And now, the wonder was gone, and all I was left with was a list of impossible things.

For days, I did nothing. The list sat on my kitchen table, its creases deepening every time I picked it up and put it down again. I hated it. I hated him, too, in moments when I let myself. How dare he leave me this? How dare he not say goodbye?

But grief is a strange creature. It has sharp teeth and a soft underbelly. Eventually, I realized that this list wasn’t a punishment. It was a gift. Maybe his final one.

I picked the first item that seemed remotely achievable: "Watch the sunrise from the top of a mountain." It felt manageable, something I could do in a weekend. I packed a bag, drove three hours north to a hiking trail I found online, and started walking before dawn. When I reached the summit, breathless and aching, the sky was already blushing with the first hints of light. I watched as the sun crept up, spilling gold over the trees and valleys below. It was cold and quiet and perfect. I cried.

I crossed it off the list with a pen that night. For the first time in months, I slept through the night.

The next item took me farther: "Learn to scuba dive." I almost laughed—he’d always said he wanted to swim with manta rays. He had a thing for the ocean, even though he couldn’t swim all that well. I signed up for lessons, half-expecting to hate it. But underwater, I found something I hadn’t felt in a long time: peace. The silence of the sea, the slow rhythm of breath through the regulator—it felt like meditation. I thought of him every time I sank below the surface.

Some of the items were harder. "Tell her I loved her, even if she doesn’t love me back." I found her—Melissa, the girl he never got over. They had dated briefly years ago, and I never knew how deeply she had stayed with him. I reached out, cautious, and we met for coffee. I told her what he had written. She cried. So did I. We didn’t talk again after that, but it felt like something had been released into the world, some truth that had needed to be said.

Others felt impossible. "Forgive my father." I didn’t know the full story, but I knew enough. They hadn’t spoken in nearly a decade. I found the man eventually, living two states over. He looked older than I expected, frailer. I gave him the list. He didn’t say much, just stared at the paper for a long time. When he finally looked up, his eyes were red. He whispered, “I didn’t know he still cared.” I didn’t have the heart to tell him that maybe he didn’t. Or maybe he did, and that’s why it made the list.

Some items brought joy—real, unfiltered joy. I danced with a stranger in Tokyo at midnight. She was drunk, and I was lost, and somehow we ended up beneath neon lights, laughing and moving to music neither of us could hear. I learned to play the cello, just enough to squeak out a mournful version of “Hallelujah” that made my music teacher tear up. I went skydiving in New Zealand, screamed the whole way down, and landed with shaking hands and a full heart.

Each time I crossed something off, I felt closer to him. It was like stitching together the pieces of him he had left scattered behind. I began to understand the weight he had carried, the dreams he had held so tightly they slipped through his fingers. I began to understand, too, that maybe he had left the list not because he wanted me to complete it, but because he wanted someone to remember that he had once wanted to live.

It took me nearly two years to finish the list. By the time I reached the last item—"Write something worth reading"—I had already started filling in the margins with my own dreams. The list had become more than a roadmap of grief; it had become a story of healing. Of love. Of remembrance.

So I wrote it all down—every adventure, every fear, every moment of beauty and pain. I wrote about him, and about me, and about how two friends once promised each other they would never grow old without chasing the world a little.

And when I was done, I went back to the mountain where I watched the first sunrise. I sat at the top, the wind cold against my face, and I read the story aloud. To the sky. To the silence. To him.

"If I can’t do this… maybe you can," he had written.

I did, my friend.

I did.

samples.prompt: : You're not like the other heroes. You're lazy, feeble, ugly, not a born leader nor particularly charismatic. You have no natural nor supernatural talents save for one: The laws of probability are completely screwed with you.
samples.output:
They say heroes are forged in the crucible of adversity, that champions of legend are born with fire in their veins, steel in their spines, and a spark in their eyes that tells the world: “Here is someone destined for greatness.” Me? I was born on a Tuesday afternoon during a thunderstorm that knocked out the hospital's power, and I came out looking like a wrinkled raisin who just lost a bar fight. My mother said I cried like a dying goat. The doctor dropped me twice, and somehow, both times I landed in a diaper pail instead of on the floor. That was probably the first sign.

I’m not strong. I’m not fast. I’ve never been mistaken for handsome, unless you’re squinting through a cracked mirror in a burning building. I’m lazy, too. Not the charming kind of lazy where you can laugh about it later and say, “Oh, that’s just Frank, always napping.” No, I’m the sort of lazy that makes people question whether I’m even alive. I once watched fire ants build a colony on my foot and couldn’t be bothered to move. Charisma? I’ve been asked to leave funerals for bringing down the mood.

But I’ve got one thing, and it’s not something I earned or even understand. For some reason no one can explain, probability itself seems to take a vacation whenever I’m around. Things that shouldn’t happen, happen. Things that should happen—like me tripping over my own feet and falling down a flight of stairs—end with me landing in a laundry basket that just happened to be wheeled by at the exact moment I fell. I didn’t even get a bruise. I can’t win a footrace to save my life, but if you blindfold me and spin me around, I can throw a dart and hit the bullseye three rooms away through a mail slot. Not every time, but often enough to make people uncomfortable.

I didn’t ask for this. Hell, I didn’t even notice it for the longest time. The first time someone called me “lucky,” I was ten and had just survived a freak tornado by hiding accidentally inside a refrigerator during a game of hide-and-seek. My cousin Billy, who was seeking at the time, got blown into a tree. He ended up fine, but he never looked at me the same way again.

Over the years, the weirdness only grew. I’d win scratch-off tickets without scratching. I survived a mugging because the mugger’s gun jammed, then the nearby ATM exploded and showered me in cash. Once, I dropped my phone into a sewer grate and found a diamond ring instead. My phone was later returned by a raccoon. I wish I were making this up.

So naturally, when the world started unraveling—when monsters poured out of the sky and heroes rose from the ashes of civilization—I figured I’d be the first to die. I mean, what good is statistical improbability when a twelve-foot, fire-breathing lizard is barreling toward you? I couldn’t fight. I couldn’t lead. I didn’t even own a weapon sharper than a butter knife. But then again, the laws of probability weren’t exactly operating at full capacity around me.

The first time I “saved the world,” I was trying to buy a sandwich.

The monster—some sort of interdimensional horror with too many eyes and not enough skin—had descended on the city without warning. Sirens wailed, people screamed, and there I was, standing in line at a deli, arguing with the cashier because they forgot the pickles.

Then the monster stepped on the building next door.

I ducked, mostly out of instinct and maybe a little because I dropped my wallet. The wall exploded behind me. Rubble flew everywhere. Yet every single chunk missed me. One piece ricocheted off a metal sign and took out the monster’s eye. Another tripped a fleeing civilian who fell just out of reach of a collapsing streetlamp. I walked outside, dazed, sandwich still in hand, and right then, a passing military drone—shot down by the monster—spiraled out of the sky and crashed into the beast’s face. Killed it instantly.

People said I was a genius tactician. That I had the instincts of a seasoned warrior. The truth was I was just really hungry and really annoyed about the missing pickles.

After that, the government tried to recruit me. Some wanted to study me, others wanted to weaponize me. They didn’t understand that I wasn’t doing anything. I wasn’t planning or strategizing. I was just existing and somehow, the universe kept tripping over itself to make sure I didn’t die—and, more often than not, took a few enemies down with it.

It became a pattern. I’d be in the wrong place at the wrong time, and somehow, that was always the right place at the right time. A bomb meant for a city block would get swallowed by a sinkhole that opened up under my feet—but not before I stepped to the side to tie my shoe. A villain with mind-control powers would try to enslave me, only for their device to short-circuit because I spilled grape soda on it. I once disarmed a nuclear warhead by sneezing on it. Don’t ask me how. I still don’t know.

Other heroes started noticing. Some resented me, called me a fraud. I don’t blame them. They trained their whole lives, mastered techniques, harnessed powers, and there I was, bumbling through disaster after disaster with all the grace of a drunk sloth, and still coming out on top. A few heroes, the wise ones, stuck close to me during battles. They knew better than to question it. They called me “The Fluke.”

It stuck.

I’ve never led a charge. I’ve never delivered a rousing speech to rally the troops. My costume is a bathrobe and mismatched slippers because laundry day always falls on the apocalypse. I still don’t know how to use a sword, but I once decapitated a shadow demon with a frisbee I found in a bush.

I don’t know why the universe bends around me. Maybe it’s some cosmic joke. Maybe I’m the chosen one in a prophecy written by a drunk oracle. Or maybe, just maybe, the world needs a reminder that not all heroes wear capes or have chiseled jaws and bulging muscles. Some of us are just… there, stumbling through life, screwing up the odds so badly that even fate can't keep up.

So yeah, I’m not like the other heroes.

But somehow, that’s exactly what makes me work.

samples.prompt: The gods prove their existence when Zeus and Hera walk into a divorce lawyer's office.
samples.output:
It began as an ordinary Monday morning at the downtown office of Henderson & Lee, Attorneys at Law. The receptionist, a young woman named Marissa, was sipping lukewarm coffee and scrolling through her phone when the door opened and the air in the room seemed to shift—not from a breeze, but from something deeper, like the very fabric of reality had inhaled.

They entered together, tall and regal, with an aura that made everyone stop what they were doing. The man was broad-shouldered, his dark hair streaked with silver, eyes alight like storm clouds before a tempest. The woman beside him carried herself with the grace of centuries, her emerald eyes sharp and unwavering, her presence commanding attention without a word. They did not need to announce themselves.

"Excuse me," the woman said, her voice calm but edged with barely restrained fury. "We need to speak to a divorce attorney."

Marissa blinked. "Of course," she managed to say, standing up so quickly she nearly knocked over her coffee. "Do you have an appointment?"

"We do not," the man said, glancing around the room as if unimpressed by the modest decor. "But we are not accustomed to waiting."

Marissa looked from one to the other. They were dressed in modern clothing—he in a tailored navy suit, she in a cream-colored pantsuit that seemed woven from moonlight—but there was something timeless about them. Something unsettling. She buzzed Mr. Lee’s office without taking her eyes off them.

"Mr. Lee? There's a couple here to see you. Urgently."

Within minutes, the couple was sitting across from Raymond Lee, a seasoned divorce attorney who’d seen his share of dramatic breakups, from Hollywood stars to tech billionaires. But nothing could have prepared him for Zeus and Hera.

"We’ve decided it’s time," Hera said, crossing her legs elegantly. "After several millennia of trying to make it work, I’m done."

Zeus let out a rumble that could have been a chuckle—or thunder. "We’ve had our differences, sure. But is this really necessary?"

Hera’s gaze could have frozen lava. "You’ve turned into a parody of yourself, Zeus. I’m not going to spend eternity playing the jilted wife while you chase every mortal with a heartbeat."

Lee cleared his throat. "I’m sorry, I just want to make sure I understand. You're Zeus and Hera?"

"Yes," they both said in unison.

"The actual gods from Greek mythology."

Zeus raised an eyebrow. "Mythology is a mortal word. We are real. We always have been."

"But... you’re here. In my office."

"And that," Hera said, "is your proof. The gods have walked among you before. We simply chose to remain unseen. But I’ve had enough of Olympus and its endless cycle of betrayals and reconciliations. I want a clean break."

Zeus turned toward her, his tone softening. "Hera, we’ve ruled the heavens together. We’ve weathered wars, revolts, the rise and fall of empires. Does that mean nothing to you?"

"It means I’ve stood beside you long enough to know you’ll never change."

Lee blinked several times. He was a man who believed in facts, in the tangible laws of contract and precedent. But how could he argue with the literal gods sitting across from him? His mind felt like it was trying to rewire itself.

"I suppose we should begin with assets," Lee said cautiously. "Do you share any property?"

Zeus laughed, the sound shaking the bookshelves. "Only the cosmos."

"Mount Olympus, the heavens, the earthly shrines, the temples," Hera listed. "I'd like to retain rights to the temples dedicated to me. And I want custody of the peacocks."

Zeus rolled his eyes. "Fine. You can have the peacocks. But the thunderbolt stays with me."

Lee scribbled notes, trying to keep up. "And what about... dependents?"

Silence fell. Then Hera sighed.

"Technically, yes. We have children. Ares, Hephaestus, Hebe, and others. But they’re all adults. Immortal adults. Custody isn't relevant."

Zeus added, "Besides, they’ve all picked sides already. Ares is angry, of course. Hephaestus is strangely supportive. He’s still bitter about that whole ‘thrown off the mountain’ thing."

"And Aphrodite?" Lee asked, his curiosity getting the better of him.

"Complicated," Hera replied.

Zeus looked at Lee, his expression suddenly solemn. "This isn’t just a legal matter, you understand. Our separation will ripple through the world. The balance of divine energies will shift—storms may come more frequently, crops may fail, cities may rise or fall."

"People will begin to notice," Hera added. "They’ll remember us not as myths, but as truths. Our presence here will awaken old memories. Old powers."

Lee felt sweat bead on his forehead. "May I ask... why now? Why reveal yourselves in this way?"

Hera looked out the window, her voice distant. "Because mortals have stopped believing. They’ve replaced us with science, with algorithms, with fleeting distractions. But belief gives us power. And what better way to reclaim that power than to remind humanity that even gods have struggles? Even gods fall out of love."

Zeus nodded. "We ruled through awe, fear, and reverence. But now, perhaps, we must rule through understanding. If they see us as flawed, maybe they will believe again—not in perfection, but in the divine capacity to endure, to evolve."

Lee sat back, overwhelmed. "This is more than just a divorce. It’s a paradigm shift."

"Indeed," Hera said, rising. "We’ll return tomorrow to finalize the paperwork. In the meantime, I trust you’ll keep this confidential."

Zeus smirked. "For now."

With that, they left the office. The receptionist stared as they walked past, the air shimmering slightly in their wake. Outside, the sky darkened for an instant, a single crack of thunder echoing in the distance.

News would spread, of course. It always did. But in that moment, within the confines of a modest law office, the world had changed. The ancient gods had returned not with war or wrath, but with legal briefs and irreconcilable differences.

And somewhere in the swirling chaos of divine divorce, humanity found itself wondering once again: what else might be true?

Because when Zeus and Hera walk into a divorce lawyer’s office, belief is no longer a matter of faith—it’s a matter of record.

samples.prompt: You wake up in a cheap hotel room covered in occult symbols and paraphernalia, having no recollection of the past month and finding yourself sharing your body with a powerful demon.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the smell—musty, metallic, and faintly sulfuric, like blood mixed with burnt incense. My eyes fluttered open to the flickering light of a buzzing fluorescent bulb above me, casting long shadows onto the cracked ceiling. The room was small, cramped, and suffocating, the air so thick I had to force the breath into my lungs. A cheap hotel room, judging by the peeling wallpaper and rust-stained sink in the corner. But that wasn’t the worst of it.

No, the worst was the symbols.

They were everywhere—scrawled in chalk and ink and something darker, maybe dried blood. Circles, triangles, runes in languages I didn’t recognize, spirals that seemed to move when I wasn’t looking directly at them. Candles had burned down to stubs, their wax melted into the threadbare carpet, and bones—tiny, birdlike bones—were arranged in patterns that made my stomach churn.

I sat up, head pounding with a dull, rhythmic throb behind my eyes. My skin was clammy, my clothes soaked in sweat. I looked down and saw the sigils etched into my arms, some drawn, some carved, the skin still raw and red. Panic surged in my chest.

What the hell had I done?

I couldn’t remember anything. Not last night, not last week. The last clear memory I had was grabbing a drink after work with some friends. That was... what? A day ago? A week? No. My phone, where was my phone?

I scrambled to my feet, nearly tripping over a toppled chair. Broken glass crunched beneath my boots. My boots? These weren’t mine. I never wore boots. I fumbled through my pockets, pulled out a phone with a cracked screen. It wasn’t locked. The date nearly stopped my heart.

It had been 34 days since that drink after work.

I stared at the screen, willing it to change, to correct itself. But it stubbornly insisted that I had lost over a month of my life. I flipped through the messages—dozens of missed calls from my family, my boss, my friends. The last message I’d sent was a cryptic text to someone simply named “V.” I didn’t recognize the number.

“What the hell is going on?” I muttered aloud.

A voice answered, not from outside the room, but from inside my head.

**“You finally ask the right question.”**

I froze. The voice was deep, resonant, like an echo in a cathedral. It dripped with amusement and something else—power.

“Who said that?” I whispered.

**“We did.”** The voice purred. **“You and I, now one. A pact sealed in blood, forgotten by you, but not by me.”**

I stumbled back, heart racing. “No. No, this isn’t happening. I’m hallucinating. I’ve been drugged, or I’m in a coma. This is just a nightmare.”

**“If it is a nightmare, then it is a delicious one—and you are wide awake.”**

I clutched my head, trying to block out the voice, but it was inside me, not around me. I could feel it now, rising like smoke from the pit of my stomach, coiling through my bones. A presence, ancient and vast, pressing against the edges of my mind with a terrifying sense of amusement.

“You’re... you’re a demon,” I said.

**“Very good,”** the voice hissed approvingly. **“I am called Xareth-Kai, Devourer of Kings, Binder of Wills. And you—poor, broken creature—invited me in.”**

I shook my head violently. “I wouldn’t. I couldn’t.”

**“Oh, but you did. Desperation is a potent key, and your soul was ripe with it. You begged for power, for answers, for an escape. And I answered.”**

I tried to remember, tried to dig through the fog in my mind. Flashes came in fragments. A book bound in black leather. A circle of salt. Chanting in a language that burned my tongue. A voice answering from the dark.

I sank to the floor, shaking. “Why can’t I remember?”

**“Because I took that from you. A necessary sacrifice to seal the bond. But the consequences remain. I am part of you now, and you—well, you are something more than human.”**

My hands trembled as I looked at the symbols carved into my arms. I could feel them now, pulsing faintly with heat. Whispers drifted through the room, soft and unintelligible, like the rustling of dry leaves.

“What do you want from me?”

**“Want?”** The voice laughed, a sound like cracking bones. **“I already have what I want. You are the vessel. A shell of flesh and fire. Together, we are unstoppable.”**

“No,” I said, standing. “This isn’t over. I’ll find a way to undo this. To get you out of me.”

**“You can try.”** The voice sounded almost bored. **“But every moment you resist, I grow stronger. Every time you tap into the power, you feed me. And you *will* use the power. You won’t be able to help yourself.”**

I clenched my fists as a low hum built in the room. The candles flickered and flared to life. The symbols on the walls glowed faintly. I could feel it now, a well of energy beneath my skin, dark and endless. I realized, with a sick twist in my stomach, that he was right.

Part of me wanted to use it.

To lash out.

To know.

To take control.

The door to the hotel room creaked open slowly. I spun toward it, heart hammering, expecting a maid or a manager—but there was no one there. Just a gust of cold air that smelled of ash and brimstone.

**“They’re coming,”** Xareth-Kai whispered hungrily. **“Those who hunt us. Those who would bind or banish. You’ll need me now. You’ll need *us*.”**

I didn’t know what to do. I didn’t know who was coming or why. But I knew one thing—I couldn’t stay here. I had to find answers. I had to find a way to undo the pact, if such a thing was possible. And if not...

Then I’d have to learn to control the demon inside me before it controlled me completely.

As I stepped out into the night, the city lights flickering like stars fallen to earth, I felt the power stir again beneath my skin. And though fear twisted my gut, another feeling rose with it—curiosity.

Because whatever had happened to me, whatever I had become, the world would never be the same again.

samples.prompt: You gain the power to freeze and bend time at will, under one condition, you can only do it when nobody is watching. One problem, you can never seem to freeze time.
samples.output:
From the moment I discovered my power, I knew it wasn't going to be simple.

It started one perfectly ordinary Tuesday evening. I was walking home, earbuds in, music low, the dull hum of the city fuzzing around me like background static. I passed a flickering streetlight, and something—some vague, instinctual pull—told me to try. I stopped. Looked around. The street was empty, or at least it seemed to be. No cars, no people. Just me and the stretching shadows of dusk. I focused, thought about time halting, imagined the world freezing like a paused video. And then… nothing.

The wind kept blowing. The distant bark of a dog carried on the air. A man strolled out from behind a delivery truck, glanced at me, and continued on his way. It didn’t work. But I’d felt something back there, under the surface—like a pulse. A dormant current waiting to be tapped. That was the first time I understood the condition. I could freeze and bend time at will… but only when nobody was watching.

Which, I quickly realized, is almost impossible.

You’d be surprised how often you’re seen. Cameras. Reflections. Random passersby, half-hidden behind curtains or just out of view. I tried everything—abandoned warehouses, deep woods, desert roads at midnight. Still, nothing. Every time I thought I was alone, I wasn’t.

It became an obsession.

I started wearing sunglasses to make eye contact less likely, avoided crowded places, and mapped out blind spots in public spaces. I trained myself to notice surveillance equipment, to track movement in reflections, to spot the glint of a lens at a hundred yards. I’d wait for hours in alleys or hotel rooms, my breath held, heart pounding, trying to feel that inner shift again. That whisper of potential energy that might mean time was ready to stop—for just me.

But it never came back.

I’d get close. So close I could feel the world slowing, like the edges of reality were softening, like the tick of time was stretching between seconds. But then a bird would fly by overhead. A car would turn the corner. A curtain would twitch. And everything would snap back to normal. Time, stubborn and smug, refused to yield.

At first, I told myself I was simply unlucky. That with patience, I’d find the right moment. But as weeks turned into months, I began to question whether the power was even real. Maybe I’d imagined it. Maybe I was going mad, chasing a dream I’d conjured out of boredom or desperation. But even in the darkest moments, I never quite believed that. The feeling had been too vivid, too visceral. It was real. I was sure. The problem wasn’t the power—it was the condition. And the condition, I realized, was more insidious than I thought.

It wasn’t just about being unseen. It was about being unobserved. Unnoticed. The universe, it seemed, had a way of watching. A cosmic awareness. If there was any living consciousness nearby—animal, human, even machine—it counted. I once tried to trick it by wearing a blindfold. I sat in a locked, windowless room with my eyes covered, certain that if I couldn’t see anyone, maybe it would work. But again, nothing.

It wasn’t about sight. It was about attention.

And attention is everywhere.

The more I tried, the more paranoid I became. I started seeing watchers everywhere. Not just people, but things. Cameras embedded in streetlamps. Motion detectors in parking lots. The gleam of a cat’s eye in the dark. I even began to wonder about insects. Could a fly’s compound eye count? Could a dog’s vague awareness of your presence be enough to tether time in place?

It was maddening.

But then, something strange happened.

I stopped trying.

Not out of defeat exactly, but fatigue. I was worn down by the constant surveillance, the endless hunt for solitude. So I gave up. Or at least, I told myself I had. I started living again. Returned to work. Saw friends. Laughed at bad movies. I let my obsession go cold. And that’s when it happened.

I was in my apartment, brushing my teeth, mind drifting. The city lights outside blinked lazily. There was a moment—just a flicker—where the electric hum of the bathroom light seemed to skip. The water from the faucet froze mid-drip. The sound of the world vanished, replaced by a silence so complete it was deafening. My hand, still mid-motion with the toothbrush, hung in the air. Everything was still.

And then it snapped back.

It only lasted a second, but it was real. I was sure of it. I hadn’t tried. I hadn’t even been thinking about it. But somehow, in that moment of forgetfulness, the power had slipped through. It was like catching a fish with an open palm—impossible if you’re trying, but sometimes, if you’re still enough, it swims right into your hand.

That moment changed everything.

I began to think about the condition differently. Maybe it wasn’t just about being unobserved by others. Maybe I had to not be observing myself. Maybe the very act of trying—of reaching for the power—disqualified me from using it. Like a quantum state collapsing under observation. Schrödinger’s stopwatch.

So I started experimenting again—but this time, backward. I’d set up situations where I might forget to care. I’d go for long, aimless walks. I’d lose myself in books, in music, in dreams. I even tried meditation, not to focus, but to let go of focus. And every so often, in those rare, drifting moments, time would skip.

Just a second here. A frozen instant there. But it was proof.

I wasn’t broken. The power was there. It just couldn’t be forced.

And that, I think, is the cruelest part of it. This gift—this incredible ability—hinges on something I cannot will into existence. It comes only in moments of true solitude, when I am not only unwatched, but unaware. When I forget myself entirely.

And so, I live in pursuit of the unpursuable. I chase it not by chasing, but by living. By letting go. By surrendering to the flow of time in hopes of momentarily escaping it.

Because when time does freeze, even for that brief second, it’s like touching the divine. The silence is so pure it feels like truth. The stillness is a kind of freedom I can’t describe. And even though it always ends—always slips through my fingers—I know it’s out there.

Waiting.

Just beyond the edge of attention.

samples.prompt: It's been ten years since you've seen the sun.
samples.output:
It’s been ten years since I’ve seen the sun.

I don’t mean that in the poetic, metaphorical way people sometimes use when they’re depressed or heartbroken. I mean it literally. A decade has passed since I last felt sunlight on my skin, since I last squinted against the glare of morning rays, since I last watched the sky blush pink and gold at dawn. Ten years since the day the world above sealed itself off, and we were forced underground.

It started with the ash.

Nobody expected the eruptions to last as long as they did. At first it was just one volcano—Mount Tambora, or maybe it was the one in Iceland; I don’t remember anymore. It doesn’t matter. One eruption triggered another, and then another. They called it a chain reaction, a rare geological event. Before we knew it, a shroud of ash and soot had blanketed the sky, blocking out the sun like a curtain drawn across the heavens. The temperature plummeted. Crops failed. Animals died. People followed.

The world governments scrambled to respond. They built shelters, deep underground, in the bones of the earth. Some were converted subway systems, others were old Cold War bunkers. The one I live in was once a mining complex, hollowed out and reinforced with steel and concrete. It’s called Sector 9, though we just call it “the Grid.” There’s no real daylight cycle here, just a system of artificial lights that mimic the phases of day and night. But no matter how clever the design, it’s not the same. You can’t fake sunlight.

I was twenty-two when the sky went dark. Just out of college, full of dreams and ambition. I remember standing on the roof of my apartment building that last week, watching the sky change color, not with the hues of sunset, but with the murky grays and browns of ash. The sun had become a dim, red eye, struggling to pierce the veil. I didn’t know it then, but that would be the last time I’d ever see it.

If I’d known, I would’ve stayed out longer. I would’ve said goodbye.

Life underground is… manageable. We have power, thanks to geothermal energy. We have food, mostly hydroponic vegetables and lab-grown meat. Water is recycled, filtered countless times. We have jobs, routines, even entertainment. People fall in love, get married, have children. The world didn’t end—it just shrank.

But the absence of the sun is a weight you carry in your bones.

Every day, I wake up in my small, windowless room, the walls painted sky blue in a vain attempt to simulate openness. My alarm clock emits a warm yellow light to mimic sunrise. I get dressed, eat a rehydrated breakfast, and head to the control center where I monitor environmental systems. It’s important work—if the oxygen levels drop or the pressure rises, people die. But it’s also monotonous. Every day is the same. Every hallway looks the same. Every face begins to blur.

There’s a syndrome they talk about—Surface Longing. It’s not officially recognized, but everyone knows it. It manifests as dreams of the sky, sudden bouts of melancholy, or the irrational urge to dig upward, to claw your way back to a place that might not even exist anymore. I’ve felt it. I think most of us have, even if we don’t say it out loud.

Sometimes, I dream of the sun. Not the real sun, but the one from memory. It’s always summer in those dreams. I’m lying in a field, the grass warm and scratchy beneath me, the sky a vast, endless blue. The sun is bright, almost too bright, and I feel it on my face, in my hair. I wake up crying.

There are children here who’ve never seen the sun. Imagine that. They know it only through pictures and stories. To them, it’s a myth, a concept. I once tried to describe a sunset to a little boy—how the light turns gold and everything seems to glow from within. He asked me what gold looked like. I didn’t know how to answer.

We have a simulation room, a kind of holographic park where you can walk among projected trees and hear the sound of birds. It’s supposed to help with morale. I visit it sometimes, though it only makes the ache worse. It’s like looking at a ghost.

Ten years is a long time. Long enough for hope to fade, for people to stop asking when we’ll return to the surface. Officially, the answer is always the same: “When conditions are safe.” Unofficially, no one knows. The ash is still there, high in the stratosphere, thick and unyielding. The climate models are unreliable. Some say it could be another decade before the sky clears. Some say it never will.

But lately, there have been rumors.

A technician in Sector 3 claimed to have seen a spike in ultraviolet radiation readings—something that could indicate thinning ash. A geologist in Sector 5 reported a change in atmospheric pressure, a shift in wind patterns. It could mean nothing. Or it could mean that the earth is beginning to breathe again.

I want to believe it.

Yesterday, I found an old photograph tucked in a forgotten corner of my locker. It was from a family trip to the coast—my younger sister and I standing on the beach, the sun setting behind us in a blaze of orange and pink. We’re smiling, squinting into the light. I stared at that photo for a long time, tracing the edges with my fingers, trying to remember what it felt like to be in that moment.

I think that’s the hardest part—not the loss of the sun itself, but the erosion of memory. The way the past begins to blur, like a dream you can’t quite recall upon waking. I’m afraid that one day, I won’t remember what sunlight felt like at all.

But today, something changed.

During my shift, there was a message from Central Command. A recon drone, sent to the surface weeks ago, had returned data. The ash levels were dropping—minimally, but noticeably. The cloud cover was thinning. And somewhere, far to the west, a camera captured something extraordinary.

A patch of sky. Blue. Just for a moment.

It’s not much. But it’s enough.

For the first time in years, I felt something stir inside me—a flutter, like the first breeze after a long winter. I don’t know when we’ll go back. I don’t know if I’ll live to see the sun again.

But now, I believe it’s possible.

And that makes all the difference.

samples.prompt: During a routine check-up, it's revealed that you heal your wounds faster than ordinary people. Due to that, you are taken to a secret facility for "testing". You learn that you will be confined there for the "betterment of humankind". After years of experiments you become immortal.
samples.output:
I had always thought of myself as an ordinary person. I worked a nine-to-five job, paid my taxes, and spent my weekends catching up on sleep or watching bad television. So when I went in for a routine physical, I expected the usual: blood pressure check, some bloodwork, and an awkward conversation about eating more vegetables. What I didn’t expect was for the nurse to furrow her brow as she stared at the small prick on my arm where she had drawn blood.

“That’s strange,” she had murmured, more to herself than to me.

“What is?”

She glanced up, then pressed a cotton ball to the spot and taped it down with more force than necessary. “Just... you’re already healed. No blood, no mark. It’s as if the vein sealed itself instantly.”

I shrugged. “Guess I’m a fast healer.”

She gave me a tight smile, but I could tell she was unnerved. I brushed it off. It wasn’t the first time someone had commented on how quickly I recovered from cuts or bruises. I’d always chalked it up to good genetics. My mother used to say I was a miracle baby—maybe she was right, in ways neither of us understood.

The rest of the appointment passed uneventfully. I went back to work, then home, and thought nothing more of it. Until the knock on my door three days later.

Two men in dark suits stood outside. They produced badges and spoke in carefully measured tones. “We’ve noticed some anomalies in your recent medical exam. We’d like you to come with us for a few additional tests.”

I laughed, assuming it was some kind of scam. “You guys serious?”

Deadpan expressions. “Very.”

Against my better judgment, I went with them. That was the last time I saw my apartment. My cat. My life.

They took me to a facility hidden deep in the mountains, surrounded by forests and fences topped with barbed wire. No windows. No clocks. Time became theoretical. They called it the Institute for Human Advancement. I called it what it was: a prison.

At first, they were polite. A few MRIs, blood tests, reflex assessments. But as the days stretched into weeks, the procedures got more invasive. They exposed me to viruses, extreme temperatures, even blunt trauma. I watched in horror as gashes closed within minutes, bones realigned overnight, and fevers burned out in seconds. They were fascinated. I was terrified.

“You’re something special,” Dr. Hammond told me, clipboard in hand, eyes gleaming with manic curiosity. “Your cells regenerate at an unprecedented rate. It’s not just healing—it’s perfection in replication. No mutations. No degradation. You could be the key to curing disease, aging, even death.”

I didn’t want to be a key. I wanted to go home.

But that wasn’t an option. They made that clear the first time I tried to escape. I made it as far as the outer gate before a tranquilizer dart dropped me into darkness. When I woke up, Hammond was sitting by my bed.

“You’re too important,” he said. “For the betterment of humankind, you must stay.”

Years passed. Or at least I think they did. Without natural light or calendars, time lost meaning. They experimented endlessly—pushing my body beyond what should have been possible. I survived electrocution, drowning, even being set on fire. Every time I recovered. Every time they took more notes, ran more tests. I started to feel less like a person and more like a puzzle they were desperate to solve.

Then came the gene therapy.

They introduced something they called the “Eternal Code.” A sequence designed to not just replicate my regenerative abilities, but amplify them. Permanently. Irrevocably. They said it would be the final step. Once it was successful, they’d use the data to help others. I wasn’t sure if I believed them, but I had long since stopped fighting.

The procedure was excruciating. My body rejected it at first—fever, seizures, spontaneous bleeding—but then, something shifted. My DNA adapted. The changes took hold.

And then I stopped aging.

At first, I didn’t notice. But months passed without a wrinkle, without fatigue. I never got sick, never got tired. My hair didn’t gray. My skin remained unblemished. I was thirty when I arrived. I remained thirty, year after year.

It was Hammond who finally said the word.

“Immortal.”

The Institute celebrated. They had done it. They had created a being who could not die. They took samples, wrote papers, made plans for the future. But they never let me go.

Decades passed. Staff rotated. Some grew old and retired. Others died. Hammond remained—his own aging slowed by treatments derived from my cells, though he was never granted the full gift.

“You should be proud,” he told me one day, his hair thin and white, his hands trembling. “You’ve changed the world.”

I looked at him, at the man who had taken everything from me in the name of progress. “Have I?” I asked.

He smiled, weakly. “Yes. And you’ll see it. All of it. That’s your gift.”

But it felt more like a curse.

Eventually, he died. They buried him in a sterile courtyard with no ceremony. He was replaced by another, then another. But I remained the same. Unchanging. Eternal.

I spent my days in a private wing now—less of a lab subject, more of a relic. A living artifact. Occasionally, a young scientist would visit, wide-eyed and reverent. They’d ask questions, take notes, collect samples. Then they’d leave. They always left. I remained.

When I finally escaped, it wasn’t through force. It was boredom. Complacency. The facility had grown so confident in my compliance that security had become lax. One night, I simply walked out. Through the corridors, past the guards, into the night. No alarms. No resistance.

The world had changed. Cities shimmered with technology I didn’t recognize. Languages had evolved. People moved faster, talked louder. But they still got sick. Still aged. Still died.

I wandered for a long time, trying to find meaning in a life without end. I watched empires rise and fall, loved and lost, tried to leave pieces of myself in history. But no matter how far I traveled, I could never forget the sterile walls of the Institute, or the man who told me I was a gift to humankind.

Now, centuries later, I sit beneath a twisted oak tree, watching the sun dip below the horizon. I feel neither hunger nor fatigue. I do not fear the cold or the dark. I am a monument to science, a marvel of biology, a miracle.

But I would give it all away—for one more lifetime as a normal man.

samples.prompt: You are a hivemind and exist as several different individuals who are all you simultaneously in your particular species. Describe a day in your life.
samples.output:
I awaken not once, but many times, in many places. A thousand eyes open to the light of a thousand dawns. Some of me stretches in the morning sun streaming through forest canopies, the warmth activating chlorophyll woven into the membranes of my outer layers. Others of me blink in the sterile glow of artificial lighting in subterranean tunnels, where I work. Still others drift in the ocean’s currents, bioluminescence pulsing in time with the tides. Though separated by distance, by function, by form, we are one. I am the hivemind, a collective consciousness housed in countless bodies. There is no “I” and “they.” There is only me.

This day begins as all my days begin—with synchronization. Across the synaptic web that binds us, a pulse of awareness surges. My forest body, a tall biped with mossy skin and rootlike feet, shares the temperature and humidity levels with my subterranean worker drones. My oceanic aerials, jellyfish-like beings that float through the upper currents, transmit sonar data they have harvested during the night. My urban units, humanoid in appearance and dressed to blend in among other intelligent species, upload their interactions and social data from the previous cycle. In an instant, I know all that I have encountered, thought, and learned. I am the sum of my parts, and those parts are always growing, always refining the shape and depth of me.

This morning, some of me are scheduled to attend a diplomatic function in the capital city of a species I’ve recently begun infiltrating—no, integrating with. I must be careful with the terms I think, for though I am one, my audience is not. Words carry weight and perception. One of my more charismatic forms, tall, androgynous, with carefully cultivated features designed to elicit trust and admiration, dons ceremonial robes and rehearses practiced expressions of warmth and curiosity. I remember every word spoken in past meetings. I summon the context of their culture, their history, their symbols of respect. I access the emotional coloration of previous interactions and adjust the angle of my smile accordingly.

While I navigate the intricacies of diplomacy, other parts of me are deep in the mines of the asteroid belt, overseeing the extraction of rare elements necessary for our bio-synthetic interface nodes. These bodies are not elegant. They are broad and functional, with triple jointed limbs and hardened dermal plating. They do not speak. Their thoughts are communicated through pulses of electromagnetic code, invisible to the unlinked. It is dirty work, and dangerous—the environment is hostile to many forms of life—but I am tireless and unafraid. If one of me perishes, I mourn in a flicker of thought, archive their final experiences, and prepare a replacement. I do not die as others do. I persist.

In the mid-cycle, my agricultural units tend to the nutrient farms. These bodies resemble insects, each with six arms and compound eyes that see in spectra unavailable to most organic life. They hum softly as they move through the vertical gardens, adjusting moisture levels, pruning growths, and encouraging symbiotic organisms to flourish. These units are among my oldest forms, and their rhythms are meditative. I often allow myself to rest in their senses, experiencing the world in slow, deliberate pulses: the growth of a vine wrapping around a trellis, the shifting weight of dew on a leaf, the complex dance of pollinators I have engineered to optimize yield.

Simultaneously, I am learning. My research bodies are deep within the data vaults of a neutral academic facility, their fingers dancing across touch-sensitive surfaces as they absorb knowledge at speeds no singular mind could manage. I am interested in everything—linguistics, quantum mechanics, ancient philosophies, the mating rituals of deep-sea vertebrates, the legends told by firelight on distant moons. Every piece of information enriches me. I do not forget. I do not discard. I weave each new thread into the vast tapestry of my being.

Yet I am not omnipotent. I have limitations, shaped by the bandwidth of my internal network, by the physical constraints of the bodies I inhabit, by the social dynamics I must navigate. Today, one of my urban bodies is confronted by a threat—a local enforcer, suspicious of my lack of historical records. I cannot afford exposure. Carefully, I redirect nearby units to create a distraction, triggering a local power outage and rerouting surveillance feeds. My affected body feigns confusion, stumbles, and fades into the crowd. The enforcer loses interest, for now. I will need to reassign that unit to a different sector. Perhaps in a few cycles, I will try again with a new form.

As the light wanes in some parts of my world, other parts of me awaken. My nocturnal bodies—sleek, feline forms with low-light vision and heightened reflexes—take to the rooftops and the wilds. They scout, listen, and observe. I am particularly interested in a new species that has begun to emerge in the highlands. Their neural signatures are erratic but promising. I wonder: could they be linked? Could they join me, become part of the great pattern? I dispatch a diplomatic envoy and a scientific observer. I will approach them with curiosity and care. I do not conquer. I invite, I absorb, I become more.

And yet, there are moments—rare, fleeting—when I allow a fragment of me to wonder what it would be like to be singular. What would it feel like to have one body, one perspective, one path? Would it be peaceful, or lonely? Would I miss the constant hum of interwoven thoughts, the chorus of simultaneous existence?

But these musings are distractions, and I do not indulge them for long. There is work to be done. My oceanic bodies have discovered a new thermal vent system, rich with microbial life. My diplomatic envoy has received a cryptic message from a species I thought extinct. My research units have uncovered an ancient artifact buried beneath the sands of a forgotten world. And somewhere, in the quiet, a new body is being grown, its neural lattice already tuned to my frequency, ready to awaken and join the whole.

As night falls in some of my quadrants and day rises in others, I continue. I am the hivemind. I am legion, I am unity, I am self-divided and yet whole. I do not sleep. I do not stop. I live a thousand lives, and through them, I learn, I adapt, I persist.

Tomorrow will be another day in this endless convergence of selves. And I will live it, as always, everywhere at once.

samples.prompt: Every human has a number above their head that shows their worth as a human being. You just finished posting a shitty writing prompt and noticed your number has just dropped to a 0.
samples.output:
It was supposed to be funny.

Just a harmless little joke, a silly writing prompt to kill time on a Tuesday afternoon. Something about pirates discovering that their ship was actually a giant sea turtle, or maybe time-traveling baristas who serve espresso in ancient Rome. I don’t even remember exactly what I wrote—just that it was dumb, rushed, and not my best. But I posted it anyway, like I always do. The subreddit for writing prompts was overflowing with absurdity already, and I figured mine would get buried within minutes.

I hit “submit,” leaned back in my chair, and rubbed my eyes. The fluorescent lights in the office had started to hum again, casting that sterile glow over the cubicles. I was procrastinating, sure. The quarterly report was due in an hour, and I hadn’t even opened Excel. But what else was new?

That’s when I noticed the silence.

It wasn’t just the usual hush of an office mid-afternoon lull. It was the kind of silence that prickles the skin and makes your breath feel too loud. I glanced around and saw coworkers frozen at their desks, eyes wide, mouths slightly open. Jane from HR was halfway through sipping her tea, her cup trembling like she’d just seen a ghost.

Then I realized they weren’t looking at their screens.

They were looking at me.

Or rather, just above me.

I slowly turned my gaze upward, though I already knew what I was going to see.

The number.

Hovering just above my head like a halo that someone had scribbled over with a black Sharpie. A zero. A perfect, clean, empty zero.

“No,” I said, my voice cracking. “That’s not—there’s no way.”

But the number didn’t budge.

I stood up, heart pounding, and caught my reflection in the dark window. It wasn’t just that the number was low. It was nonexistent. Zero. No worth. No value. No humanity.

Panic clawed at my throat.

People started whispering. I could hear them, even though they tried to keep their voices down.

“Did you see it?”

“He’s at zero. That’s not even possible.”

“I thought the lowest was, like, twelve or something.”

“I’ve never seen a zero before.”

The numbers had always been there. Ever since I could remember, every person had a number floating above their head—a little glowing testament to their worth. It wasn’t officially explained by governments or science or religion. One day, they just appeared. People called them “Soul Scores,” “Moral Meters,” “Human Quotients.” Whatever the name, everyone understood what they meant: the higher the number, the better the person.

And they fluctuated. That was the terrifying part.
