Help someone cross the street? You might go up a point.

Lie on your taxes? Down a couple.

Kick a puppy? Well, you didn’t want to know.

But a zero?

That was unheard of.

I backed away from my desk, feeling like gravity had turned against me. My legs shook. I stumbled past the copy machine, past the breakroom where Linda clutched her lunch like a shield. No one moved to stop me. They just watched.

I needed to see for myself. Maybe it was a glitch. Maybe I’d bumped my head and was hallucinating.

I burst into the restroom and stood in front of the mirror. There it was. Still there.

Zero.

The number pulsed faintly, as if mocking me. A dead, cold glow.

I gripped the sink. I thought about the writing prompt. That stupid, lazy piece of garbage I’d posted. I opened my phone, fingers trembling, and navigated to the subreddit.

There it was.

Writing Prompt: Every human has a number above their head that shows their worth as a human being. You just finished posting a shitty writing prompt and noticed your number has just dropped to a 0.

The comments were brutal.

“Wow. The prompt is the prophecy.”

“Meta trash.”

“This is the worst prompt I’ve ever read.”

“Mods, can we nuke this?”

And the upvotes—or lack thereof. Negative 1,437. I didn’t even know it could go into negative territory.

I sank to the floor of the bathroom, my back against the stall door. Somewhere in the distance, a toilet flushed. Life went on.

But not for me.

Because what did a zero mean, really?

Was I no longer human? Was I evil? Did I not matter? Would I vanish? Be taken away?

I’d heard rumors. People with low numbers losing their jobs, getting evicted, even disappearing. But a zero? That wasn’t just low. That was null. That was void.

I scrolled through my past prompts, trying to find something redeeming. Something that might add a point or two and get me off the floor.

One said: “Writing Prompt: You find out your dog is actually a reincarnated ancient philosopher.” That had done okay. 57 upvotes. Maybe that was worth something.

But the number didn’t change.

I tried to think of something good I could do, right now. I stood up and picked up a piece of paper towel someone had left on the floor. Nothing. I held the door open for a janitor. Still nothing.

It was like the universe had already made up its mind.

The number was final.

I stumbled outside. The sky felt too bright, too wide. People stepped away from me on the sidewalk, giving me wide-eyed glances. A woman with a 94 above her head clutched her child and crossed the street.

I wanted to scream. To explain that it was just a joke. That I wasn’t trying to be offensive or lazy. That I was tired. That I was trying my best like everyone else.

But what was the point?

Zero.

I went to the park. Sat on a bench. Watched the ducks.

And then a kid sat down next to me. Couldn’t have been older than six.

He looked up at the number above my head, blinked, and said, “Whoa. You’re empty.”

I nodded.

“Does that mean you’re a ghost?”

“I don’t know,” I said.

He thought about that for a moment.

“Wanna feed the ducks with me?”

I hesitated. “You’re not scared?”

He shrugged. “You don’t look like a ghost. You look sad. Sad people need ducks.”

He handed me a crust of bread.

I took it.

We sat there, throwing crumbs into the water. The ducks waddled over, quacking in delight. The kid laughed, and for a moment, I did too.

And then I saw it.

A flicker.

Not much. Just a pinprick of light above my head. A tiny, trembling glow.

It wasn’t a number yet. Not really.

But it was something.

Hope.

Maybe the worth of a human being wasn’t measured by their best idea, or their worst misstep. Maybe it wasn’t about karma or popularity or stupid internet points. Maybe it was about trying again. About feeding ducks with a kid who didn’t care about numbers. About listening. Learning. Being present.

I looked at the bread in my hand, then at the water, then at the small boy beside me.

And for the first time since I saw that zero, I smiled.

Maybe I wasn’t worthless after all.

Maybe I was just starting over.
